RAHWAY, N.J., March 23. -- There lives in modest retirement at 51 Central Avenue, Rahway, a man who in August, 1893, awoke one morning to find himself transferred from poverty to affluence by having bequeathed to him the modest sum of $4,000,000 by a man whom he had befriended nineteen years ago.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The Reichstag this afternoon, by a vote of 163 to 146, rejected the proposal of Herr von Levetzow, President of that body, that the Reichstag charge him with the duty of offering the congratulations of the Chamber to Prince Bismarck upon the occasion of the ex-Chancellor's eightieth birthday.

Mayor Strong announced the above appointments yesterday. The selection of Edwin Einstein as a Dock Commissioner came in the way of a surprise to the politicians. It was also a surprise to Mr. Einstein, who said that he did not know anything about the matter until he was sent for yesterday by the Mayor.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 23. -- A meeting was held here last week to consider the condition of crew affairs. If a Cornell crew is sent to England this season it is estimated that the expenses of the navy will be at least $10,000. This sum must be raised by subscription, and only a fraction of it has been contributed thus far.

The Pennock Electric Company is putting its system of lighting into practice, and for the last three weeks its electricians have been putting up a plant of 200 lights in one of the large factories of the Elastic Web Company at Chelsea, Mass. This factory is owned and operated by Thomas and William Martin.
Mr. William Roeber is a gentleman who combines the pastoral with the commercial function. This mixture has gotten him into two lawsuits and any quantity of hot water.

There is much of promise in the plan, described in another part of this issue of The Times, to establish an employment bureau on a co-operative basis. If it can be carried into successful execution -- and no reasons why it cannot are obvious -many existing abuses will be materially lessened and perhaps altogether removed.

The final match in the inter-club competition of the Metropolitan Chess League was played Saturday night at the Union Square Hotel between the City and the Brooklyn Chess Clubs. The latter came out victorious by the score of 4 1/2 to 3 1/2, and is now the champion of the league for the present year, and will be presented with a trophy offered by Julius Livingstone, President of the league and of the City Club.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Senor

ORANGE, N.J., March 24. -- In connection with the agitation in favor of the consolidation of the Oranges, or a Greater Orange, it might be well to state that nearly all the clergymen in the four Oranges, so far as has been learned, are in favor of the movement. The views of a number of them have already been published in the columns of The New-York Times.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 12. -- The Colonial Secretary to-day introduced in the Legislative Council, the law-making body of Jamaica, as far as this colony can make its own laws, a new tariff law. If this measure should ever receive the approval of the home Government it would be likely seriously to affect certain exports from the United States to this island.

While the contest in Connecticut between the old steam railroads and the new electric roads is a matter of great interest to the people of that State, it deserves attention in many other States, where a similar conflict of the old and the new transportation interests will eventually be seen.

Every speaker in Chickering Hall last night had some friends in the audience. The meeting was called to let men of different political faiths tell why they held their particular political beliefs. S. Hoyt Nichols was Chairman.

PRINCETON, March 24. -- Much interest is manifested both by alumni and undergraduates in the first intercollegiate debate with Harvard, which is to take place at Princeton next Wednesday evening. The committee has completed all arrangements, and is looking forward to a pleasant and successful contest with Harvard's representatives.

DENVER, Col., March 24. -- All but one member of Hose Company No. 3 lost their lives last night in a fire which destroyed the St. James Hotel. The hose company, excepting the Captain, is composed of colored men. The dead are:

BERLIN, March 24. -- The loss of an army bill could not have excited Germany more than the Reichstag's refusal to congratulate Bismarck. The moment the result of the vote was known, Dr. von Boetticher hurried to the telephone and told the Emperor, who was awaiting the news in the Old Castle.

Through the kindness of Messrs. Abbey Grau a benefit performance will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday evening, April 18, for the New-Amsterdam Eye and Ear Hospital, 212 West Thirty-eighth Street.

Word was sent to Police Superintendent William J. McKelvey of Brooklyn yesterday morning that a man had been murdered in the Fourteenth Precinct, and he at once went to the Ralph Avenue Precinct, where he gave Capt. Dunn instructions.

NICE, March 24. -- This has been another day's racing without sufficient wind, and therefore without results. Fortunately, the Ailsa, Britannia, Corsair, and Valkyrie I. were not brought out. Had they raced, they undoubtedly would have fared as they did yesterday.

From present appearances the ever-progressive sulky is destined to become a political factor. For the introduction of this novel element in the administration of public business the Constitutional Convention that revised the organic law of this State last year is largely responsible. It is not likely that the members of that body were inspired by any personal animus for the great American sport of harness racing.
BALTIMORE, March 24. -- Seven persons narrowly escaped death in a fire on West Mount Royal Avenue at 1 o'clock this morning. Two of them were badly burned and may die of their injuries.

An obituary of James Anderson appears in The London Athenaeum, and recalls an actor once well known in both England and America, but who, long before his recent death at the age of eighty-six, had passed from the memories of theatregoers. He was, however, at one time considered one of the most promising of Macready's recruits, and occupied during some years a prominent position.
Although Superintendent Byrnes has issued orders against pool or billiard playing on Sunday, there were many places open to the public yesterday.

The Republican Legislature at Albany displays a remarkable power of resistance to projects intended to afford relief to the people of this city. The bill of the Tenement-House Commission is an example. The Mulberry Bend Park bill offered by this commission has become a law, and the East Side Small Parks bill and the School Playground bill have passed and are in the Mayor's hands.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24 -- The one hundred and nineteenth Legislature has adjourned and gone home until June 4. There have been good, bad, and indifferent Legislatures in New-Jersey, but this one had about the least character of any. It was owned body and soul by the corporations, and the third house controlled the situation.

If we wish to have the principle of "home rule" in local affairs established, we shall have to stick to it, and allow it to be applied even when some temporary advantage might be gained by its violation.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 24. -- Fire which started from unexplained causes destroyed the greater portion of Reed Brothers' packing house, in Armourdale, this evening, involving a loss of about $1,000,000. As a spectacle the fire was a magnificent thing. Thousands of people gathered on the west bluff of this city to view it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 24. -- The Yale Glee and Banjo Clubs will start on their Easter trip April 11, leaving New-York by the Old Dominion Line steamer Jamestown, at 3 P.M., and arriving at Old Point Comfort the next morning, where they will give a concert on Saturday evening. The clubs, while at Old Point Comfort, will be the guests of the Hygeia Hotel.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 24. -- The college students entertained two large audiences at the Lyceum Theatre with their minstrel show Thursday and Friday evenings. It was given for the purpose of raising money to advance the athletic interests of the college, and netted a large sum. Besides the minstrel show proper there was a ballet, an "ideal football game" between supposed students from Rochester and Vassar, and an elaborate musical programme.

The third competition in the regimental team match, shot on Saturday evening at the Seventh's armory range, resulted in a tie for first honors between the teams representing Company K and Company B. Each got an aggregate score of 127. The match is open to teams of three from each company, excluding those who have armory records of 65 or better, or who have shot on a regimental team.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 24. -- An element of substantiality has been imparted to recent rumors to the effect that Cuban residents of Philadelphia were assisting their compatriots in other cities in storing and sending to the revolutionists of the island quantities of arms and ammunition. Leaders of the local agitation in behalf of Cuban independence scout this idea.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.

The April shower yesterday was not only out of date, but decidedly inopportune, according to 5,000 cyclists in the metropolitan district. It cut in two a day's pastime, sending the wheelmen speeding homeward about 2 o'clock. Up to that hour the conditions for cycling were very favorable, end thousands in Greater New-York took a turn at pedaling.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Lycurgus Dalton, Postmaster of the House of Representatives, died to-night, at his residence, in this city, of bronchial trouble.

Michael Doherty, who was a prisoner charged with having caused the death of James Carroll, walked out of the Essex Market Police Court yesterday and leisurely made his way back to his home, 273 Plymouth Street, Brooklyn. He was so long getting home that he found a Brooklyn detective waiting for him, and he was rearrested.

" Tongues of Fire" was chosen by the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage as the subject of his discourse in the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, the auditorium was filled long before the services began, and the doors were closed to the public, many persons being turned away.

-- Anna Boyd's Wedding. -- Anna Boyd, who plays the principal part in "Aladdin, Jr.," but who will be best remembered as the creator of the Widow in Hoyt's "A Trip to Chinatown," a part which she played continuously for over four years, is to be married, as published in The New-York Times of Saturday, some time this Summer to Tunis Dean, manager of the Academy of Music in Baltimore.

The distinguished author of "The Influence of Sea Power on History," Capt. A.T. Mahan, commander of the cruiser Chicago, which arrived from Europe Saturday, was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times last night what his opinions were regarding the Allianca affair.

The Agricultural Department has recently published a tabular statement which it calls "an attempt to show the world's wheat production for the years 1891 to 1894." The totals indicate a steadily increasing supply, from 2,369,746,000 bushels in 1891 to 2,590,121,000 in 1894.
The protest against the Platt-Lexow police bills, which will be formulated at Cooper Union Wednesday night, will doubtless be in the hands of the legislators before the session Thursday morning.

ALBANY, March 24. -- The event of the present week in the Legislature will occur Wednesday or Thursday, when the New-York Police bills will be reached on the calendar in the order of third reading in the Senate, and the people of New-York will definitely learn whether "reform" is to have its way or the State Republican machine is to rule them.

LONDON, March 24. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent in Moosh says in a dispatch, sub-dated at Kars, March 23, that it is certain that more than 8,000 Armenian Christians were killed in cold blood during the massacre.
BOSTON, March 24. -- New-England Republicans are not solid for "Tom" Reed for the next Presidential candidate, but a majority of the leading politicians of that party in this section are for him.

The friends of tenement-house reform in New-York and public-spirited citizens generally, are interested in the success of the legislative measures growing out of the investigations of the Tenement-House Committee, of which Mr. Richard Watson Gilder was Chairman.

William Archer, the English critic, has written for The Contemporary Review an article in which he advocates putting the London music halls under the control of the County Council. In the course of his remarks on this subject he takes occasion to express his view of the "artistic" merit of the performances given in these highly popular and much-discussed places of amusement.

The year 1895 came in with no fewer than twenty-three officers of the army marked on its calendar for retirement for age. These included two of the three Major Generals, two staff department Brigadier Generals, three Colonels of the line, and seven Colonels and two Lieutenant Colonels of the staff corps, with others of lower grades.

ORANGE, N.J., March 24. -- Preparations have been begun here rather tardily for the annual city election, which is to be held on Tuesday, April 9. The Republicans, who won a sweeping victory here a year ago, for the first time in many years, are in a dissatisfied and apathetic frame of mind, for their year's lease of life has not been a success by any means.

GLASGOW, March 13. -- That the new cutter Ailsa would beat the two-year-old Britannia in the Mediterranean was a foregone conclusion among the unprejudiced class of Clyde yachtsmen who could not blink the fact that the racing yacht in these days rarely survives twelve months, instead of twenty years, as used to be the case.
LONDON, March 24. -- The Central News correspondent in Tokio says that an attempt was made to assassinate Li Hung Chang in the street of Simonoseki this afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, March 24. -- The Greek Committee, presided over by the Prince Regal, has sent to Harvard the official programme of the Olympic games to be celebrated at Athens next year from April 5 to 15. These games are the first of a series which the International Athletic Congress at Paris last Summer decided to hold every four years in the principal European cities.

The Jasper baseball team of Manhattan College promises to be the best for years. Preparations are being made to have Manhattan Oval entirely fenced in before the first home game. In addition to this decided change, it is contemplated to erect a grand stand. The sale of season tickets under the supervision of Manager Edward C. Podwin will soon commence.

If any one will take the trouble to wade through the civil service estimates for the coming year, contained in a portly Blue Book of more than 500 pages, he will be repaid by finding a number of curious items. Here are a few taken at random: The turn-cock at Buckingham Palace is paid 1 8s a week, with 8 for acting as ratcatcher.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 24. -- The ninety-sixth session of the New-York Methodist Conference will meet in St. James's Church, this city, April 3 to 10, Bishop John P. Newman, D.D., LL.D., of Omaha, to preside. There are 312 ministers in this conference, representing a membership of 58,267. Following is the programme that has been prepared:

VICTOR, Col., March 24. -- Florence and Cripple Creek Railroad train No. 60, southbound, leaving Victor at 9:50 P.M., was stopped last night by five masked robbers just outside the city limits. The bandits went through the mail and express car, but found nothing valuable. The robbers then compelled the express messenger to take the lead, and, going through the coaches, they robbed several passengers, taking two or three gold watches and some money.

The great Worth could be generous, as well as great. In the Empire days, a celebrated Parisian fashion leader, allowed a large income by her husband in that capacity, found the year's allowance run out, and a fancy ball coming on to close the season. Much or most of that income flowed year after year into Worth's till.

UNION HILL, N.J., March 24. -- Four new bells which will shortly be placed in the steeple of the Holy Family Catholic Church, Jefferson Place, were blessed this afternoon by Bishop Wigger, assisted by Vicar General J.J. O'Connor, Chancellor Wallace, the Rev. G.N. Grieff, rector, and the Rev. R. Huelsbusch, curate.
Prof. Felix Adler lectured yesterday morning at Carnegie Music Hall under the auspices of the Society for Ethical Culture. His subject was "The New View of Childhood and Its Effects on Education."

The 150th anniversary of the departure of the New-England troops for Louisburg, Sunday, March 24, 1745, was celebrated yesterday afternoon by patriotic societies in this city, which joined with the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New-York in holding a commemorative service in St. Paul's Chapel.

ITHACA, March 24. -- The Spring recess began on Friday, March 22, at 6 P.M., and continues until Tuesday, April 2. Friday special trains left Ithaca for the annual inspection tours of the students of Sibley College. These tours were designed by Dr. Thurston, Director of Sibley College, in accordance with his attempt to give the men in technical courses as much as possible of practical work.
It has been left for a Western city to take the initiative in an attempt to promote in the schools the development of the art idea in America.

The Columbia Varsity crew has at last taken up quarters at the Macy villa, on Cathedral Heights. Under Coach Peets's supervision, the crew rows every afternoon and is showing remarkable improvement. All interested in aquatics at the college herald the approach of Spring and warm weather with joy, for it will enable the crews to go on the Harlem, and not until then can the real merits of the crews be gauged by outsiders.

Two more bowling tournaments came to a close last week, after a successful season. Parke, Davis Co.'s team captured first prize for the second successive season in the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling Association. Dodge Olcott and Whitall, Tatum Co.'s teams are tied for second prize.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.
The cornerstone of St. Paul's new Protestant Episcopal Church, on Washington Avenue above One Hundred and Seventieth Street, was laid by Bishop Potter yesterday afternoon.

The decidedly singular and interesting aggregation of people from strange lands brought here for the ethnological congress which it is intended to make a feature of the circus this season, met one another for the first time yesterday afternoon.

FORT MONROE, Va., March 25. -- The steamer City of Para, with about forty passengers aboard from New-York for Colon, lost her propeller March 21, about 500 miles out. Shortly afterward the steamer Prince William IV. came along and took the Para in tow, arriving here this afternoon.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., March 25. -- United States Deputy Marshal Conrad served warrants of arrest Saturday evening on W. Allen Haines, G.T. Uzzell, and P.J. Mugler, charged with smuggling.

Prof. Felix Adler condensed in a few words a large amount of wisdom when, putting an old phrase in new form, he said that "schools are made for children, not children for schools." Substitute "should be" for "are" and his assertion becomes much more nearly true, and at the same time points the way to real educational reform.

Since the war feeling simmered down, a few conspicuous military companies from the South have visited their comrades in the North from time to time and have made hosts of friends. Chief among them have been the Gate City Guard of Atlanta and the Chickasaw Guard of Memphis.
FRIEDRICHSRUH, March 25. -- Prince Bismarck received the members of the Prussian Diet and many members of the Reichstag to-day.

Police Superintendent William J. McKelvey of Brooklyn is positive that he will be able to clear up the mystery attending the murder of James Anderson, whose throat was cut in Hancock Street, near Evergreen Avenue, on Sunday morning.

The Corporation of Trinity Church has apparently been influenced by the missionary endeavors of The New-York Times in the corporation's interests and its tenants' interests, but to an end that was hardly expected when the attention of the public was called to the callous indifference of its Vestry to the welfare of those who occupied its ramshackle buildings with a high death rate.

The completion and formal dedication, a few days ago, of the crib or superstructure over the intake of the new conduit through which Chicago obtains water from Lake Michigan from a point four miles from shore, gave the Health Officer of the city an opportunity to emphasize the sanitary value of the improvement.
A sack of mail destined for a foreign port was about to be thrown into a wagon at the Post Office in this city a few days ago when the man who was handling it heard a weak me-a-uw from its interior.

LONDON, March 25. -- A dispatch from Tokio to the Central News says that Dr. Sato, the surgeon in attendance upon Li Hung Chang, has telegraphed to the Emperor that the Chinese envoy's wound is in good condition, and that there is no cause for anxiety regarding the result.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- No official confirmation of the attempted assassination of Li Hung Chang has been received at either the Chinese or the Japanese Legations. The general feeling here is one of profound regret that this venerable Chinese diplomat should have fallen a victim to a fanatic's bullet.
Mayor Strong yesterday appointed Stevenson Constable Superintendent of Buildings, to succeed Thomas J. Brady, and Ralph O. Williams to be Civil Service Examiner.

NEWARK, N.J., March 25. -- A baseball team has been. organized by the Central Athletic Association of earr/e),, and the followln players were signed: ' H. '. Erichson, pitcher; V. Jeff, catcher; first base, T. /IcGowan; second base, C. Greenfield; third base, G. Swiss; fielders, lq. Clauss, .. Iilton, and L. Westlake. The club would like to hear from any first-class teams for a few open dates. The Secretary is John Bone, Johnson Avenue, earney.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- It is just within the bounds of possibility that Pennsylvania and Princeton will meet upon the gridiron in November next, notwithstanding the recent decision of the Faculty Athletic Committee of the New-Jersey college to prohibit for the time being all contests between the students of the two institutions.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 25. -- The order of the Dominion Government commanding the Manitoba Legislature to pass laws granting Manitoba Catholics separate schools reached here from Ottawa yesterday, and will be taken up in the Legislature to-morrow. In all the city Methodist churches violent sermons were delivered protesting against Dominion interference with Manitoba in the matter of schools.

Frederick Conright, a newsboy, nine years old, is the one hundred and fourth victim of the misuse of electrical power by Brooklyn street-car companies. He was killed yesterday at about the time when, at the meeting of the board, several Aldermen of Brooklyn were striving to prevent a reduction of the speed limit.
SOUTHAMPTON, March 25. -- The schooner yacht Fleur de Lys, owned by Mr. George Trotter of New-York, sailed for New-York this morning.
The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted an ordinance making eight miles an hour the limit of speed for trolley cars.

PORTLAND, Me., March 25. -- A man named McCormack, a New-York merchant, who was a first-cabin passenger on the steamship Labrador, which arrived here from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, died when the ship was three days out, and was buried at sea. Nothing is known of his relatives.

HAVANA, March 25. -- Col. Santoscildes, who commands the Government force at Manzanillo, reports that yesterday troops under Col. Araoz attacked and dispersed rebel bands at Juraguana and Cayo Camacho.

Consolidation of the Astor and Lenox Libraries and the Tilden Trust Fund has led to much speculation on the part of the public at large, to say nothing of those more intimately interested, as to the best site on which shall stand the home of the New-York Public Library.

BOSTON, March 25. -- Football at Harvard has not been entirely abandoned. It has been announced by Capt. Brewer of the 'Varsity eleven that the Spring squad of 'Varsity candidates would be called out again, and would continue training during the rest of the season. Capt. Brewer says that he has decided that it is his duty to keep the men in training as long as there is any show for football.

Solomon H. Mann, the Fifth Avenue ladies' tailor, whom Loretta Hannigan of 403 West Fifty-fifth Street identified on Saturday as having induced her to permit to an operation, and whom detectives have been unable to find, presented himself yesterday morning at the office of Howe Hummel.

A number of well-known local theatrical managers met yesterday afternoon at Mr. A.M. Palmer's office in answer to a call sent out by that manager to take action in regard to remedying the billboard and lithograph nuisance. Those present were Daniel Frohman, J. Charles Davis, T. Henry French, E.G. Gilmore, A.A. McCormick, J. Wesley Rosenquest, Frank McKee, W.J. Bloch, and Charles Burnham, and Joseph Brooks and Marc Klaw, who represented the combination managers.

DENVER, Col., March 25. -- The trackage case incidental to the suit of the American Loan and Trust Company, Trustee, against the Union Pacific, Denver, and Gulf Railway Company, was called for argument to-day in the United States court, and counsel for the various parties interested discussed the situation at length.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The matter of the petition of Eugene V. Debs, President of the American Railway Union, and other officials and members of that organization, for release on habeas corpus, was the first case on the call of the Supreme Court of the United States to-day, and the argument was begun after the court had announced its opinion and judgments in several cases and disposed of a number of motions.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- Judge Payne decided to-day the case of certain citizens and taxpayers of Chicago against the Cosmopolitan Electric and Ogden Gas Companies. The action was brought by the Civic Federation for an injunction restraining the companies from doing business under their franchises, and to declare the ordinances granting them franchises void on the ground that the passage of the ordinances was secured by bribery and corruption.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The annual report of the State Board of Charities for last year was transmitted to the Legislature to-night. The institutions that come under its authority number over 500, and hold property, real and personal, amounting to about $88,500,000. In the last fiscal year these institutions had under care 238,000 inmates and expended nearly $21,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- The attempt of the Fletcher committee of the Philadelphia, Reading and New-England Railroad (Poughkeepsie Bridge) bondholders to secure an indorsement for their plan of adjustment was resumed this afternoon at the adjourned meeting of bondholders called for that purpose, held at the office of the Fidelity Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Secretary Carlisle could not be seen to-night with regard to the dispatch from New-York that the quarantine laws had been violated in taking aboard a tug from the Paris, his son, William K. Carlisle, before the steamer had passed Quarantine.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The message of the Governor was a general surprise to Senators and members. It was evident that the Governor had taken few, if any, members of the Legislature into his confidence. None of the Republican Senators would discuss it. Senator Cantor observed, "That is a corker." The Democrats in both houses enjoyed the discomfiture of the Republicans hugely.

The Cooper Union mass meeting, to be held Wednesday night, will deal with a broader subject than the passage of reform bills for New-York City. It will issue an address to the voters of the State, asking their assistance in securing home rule in cities, as guaranteed by the new Constitution.
" Yes, Sir; 'Antitoxine Bill' is what we call him, and for an antitoxine horse he hasn't got his equal in this city. He cost us $10, but he could not be bought now for $5,000."

The cycling world will be glad to learn that the world's champion, the only Zimmerman, has decided to accept the challenge issued by Hubert Houben, the Belgian wonder, to a series of three races for 25,000f. a side. The details are not complete, but "Zim" said yesterday that he'd race him, and that he was only awaiting a cablegram from Paris before making arrangements for the trip.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The State Department has learned that restrictions upon foreign commercial travelers in Russia have been modified, and that the Minister of Finance has established the following temporary rules:

Great surprise was created in the dry goods trade and the business community generally when it became known yesterday that receivers had been appointed to liquidate and close up the affairs of the old-established dry goods jobbing house of E.S. Jaffray Co.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Senior Muruaga, the Spanish Minister, was advised by his Government this evening of the acceptance of his resignation, which was re-tendered by Senor Muruaga after the establishment of the new Spanish Government.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Information received by Secretary Morton is that the Argentine Republic is fast shaping its affairs so as to become one of the United States' principal competitors in the meat trade. A private letter just received by Secretary Morton from United States Minister Buchanan says the cattle shippers are looking to a development of their trade in both Great Britain and Germany, and that their trade is unquestionably growing rapidly, too.
BOSTON, March 25. -- The Globe says that several of the champions in the New-England Amateur Athletic Union have announced their intention to withdraw and enter the ranks of professionals.
PARIS, March 25. -- Leon y Castillo, the Spanish Ambassador, has been recalled. The Duke of Mandas will succeed him.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The State Department has been officially notified that a revision of the Mexican customs tariff will go into operation April 1, involving changes in the following schedules affecting exports from the United States:

Two notable sales of down-town property were made yesterday. The first of these was by Mr. George R. Read, who sold, for James G. Wallace, to John T. Williams, the southwest corner of William Street and Exchange Place, at about $540,000. This property extends in the rear along Lord's Court. It was recently purchased by Mr. Wallace, who intended pulling down the old buildings and erecting a modern office building on the site.

While no one can truthfully say that there has not been marked progress in educational matters in New-York, there is, nevertheless, ground for the criticism made by Col. Parker that the State of New-York is doing less for education that any other State in the Union. The new education is not popular in many quarters, it must be admitted.

H. Oliver Goldsmith, thirty years old, of 436 West Thirty-sixth Street, of the firm of Baring, Moore Co., commission brokers, 54 and 56 Broad Street, was arrested yesterday on the complaint of John H. Fisher, a merchant of 50 Congress Street, Boston, Mass. Fisher charges that Baring, Moore Co. defrauded him out of $600, which he had sent them to invest in cotton.

BOSTON, March 25. -- C.W.M. Foster, the prime mover in the Jubilee yacht syndicate, said to-day: "Gen. Paine has withdrawn his offer solely, I believe, because the matter has not gone through with a rush and with the enthusiasm expected. He does not wish to be placed in the position of offering the boat to those who might feel that they could not afford to put their money into whatever chances might be going.
Mrs. Leah Bernard, who had been accused of perjury, was discharged in the Court of General Session, before Recorder Goff, last evening.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Gov. Morton sent the following special message to the State Legislature to-night, in which he asks that the measure abolishing the New-York City Police Justices and substituting nine police magistrates in their stead be speedily passed:

Some of our Republican friends seem to think the only sufficient antidote to their policy of trade exclusion is annexation. On that ground they are talking rather wildly of the great advantages our commerce would gain from annexing the Island of Cuba, with Puerto Rico thrown in.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury resumed its session yesterday morning, and before it adjourned a number of important witnesses had been examined. Among them was Charles De F. Burns, who has been Secretary of the Department of Parks for years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- For the second time since 1873, when the steamship Pennsylvania stuck on the ways, there was a delay in a launch at Cramp's shipyard to-day, and to the disappointment of 25,000 people the International Navigation Company's big new steamer St. Paul stubbornly refused to move from her wooden cradle into the Delaware River.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 25. -- William F. Davis, the professional golf player, in charge of the links at the Country Club here, has returned from Europe and reports securing for an assistant young Anderson of the St. Andrews Links, Scotland. Several clubs in various parts of the world were after Anderson, who is one of the world's promising players.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 25. -- For the first time in nearly two weeks colored laborers are loading ships on the river front without military protection. The brigade was withdrawn Saturday night, and ordered to assemble again this morning. Instead of assuming their stations on the levee the troops remained all day in their armories.

The dismissal of Mr. Brady from the head of the Building Department, which has seemed highly probable ever since Mayor Strong took office, was converted into a foregone conclusion by the disaster in Orchard Street. The collapse of a new building, the progress of which the department had watched with entire complacency would of itself have acted as an indictment of the department and put it on its defense.
JERSEY CITY, March 25. -- The Street and Water Board this morning received bids under the amended specifications of January for a new water supply. There were but two bidders.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Assemblyman Danforth E. Ainsworth of Oswego County, the Republican leader on the floor of the Assembly, to-night introduced in the lower House two bills touching the New-York City police force, which, he thinks, will solve the New-York City police problem and be satisfactory to all parties interested.

GREENOCK, March 25. -- The British steamer Durham City, Capt. Thompson, from Newport News, March 8, for Glasgow, arrived here to-day with four of the crew of the British steamer Belfast, Capt. Brown, from Darien, March 2, for Belfast, which is ashore on Jona Island, and will probably become a total wreck. Eighteen other members of the Belfast's crew are missing.

Thomas Fortune, editor of The New-York Age, delivered an address in the afternoon at a meeting of the Colored Preachers' Association, held at 137 West Forty-eighth Street. He spoke on the condition of the negro in the Southwest as he found it during a recent tour.
Mayor Strong gave a public hearing yesterday afternoon on the bill appropriating $500,000 for a new wing for the American Museum of Natural History.

While it is very desirable to have sound systems of administration, much more depends upon the character and motives of the men who do the administering. Capable and honest men, aiming only at public benefit, will make the best of a bad system, while incapable and dishonest men will do endless mischief in spite of the merits of any system that can be devised.

The refusal of the German Legislature to congratulate the most famous of living Germans upon the completion of his fourth score of years was a curious exhibition of boorishness and brutality. One can readily understand the disgust and indignation with which it was received by the Emperor.

Next Saturday, March 30, the members of the Lotos Club are to celebrate by a dinner the twenty-fifth anniversary of the club's organization. It is to be made rather an elaborate affair, befitting the importance of the occasion. Each member will be permitted to invite one guest, and a programme of unusual attractiveness has been prepared.

A decision of considerable importance has been made by Judge Baker of the United States District Court in the suit of the National Harrow Company against two manufacturers of harrows in Indiana. The defendants, it appears, were charged with having infringed upon a patent controlled by the plaintiff company, which is commonly known as the Harrow Trust.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- A partial report of the experts appointed by the courts to examine into the affairs of the Whisky Trust was made public to-day. It shows a discrepancy of $1,924,120 and an effort to hide it by erasures on the books of the company.
LANSING, Mich., March 25. -- The Michigan Supreme Court has decided that the "Anti-Fusion act" passed by the Legislature is valid.

ALBANY, March 26.--In February last Secretary W. R. Eastman of the New-york Library Association sent at list of 237 of the leading books of the 1894 to the librarians of New-York and other States, to obtain from them an expression of opinion respecting the best twenty-five books of 1894 to be added to a village library. There were 160 of the lists returned from which the following choice is indicated:
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- It is said that there is great disappointment on the part of a naval officer who did not secure a prominent billet which he had been expecting from Secretary Herbert.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- For the third time the stock of the Bell Clothing Company, which occupied a building at State and Quincy Streets, in the centre of the retail district, was destroyed by fire this afternoon.

Champion Zlmmerman did not receive the expected cable from Paris yesterday, but 'it will probably come to-day, and then, If thinE are as he hopes, his match with the young Belgian wonder, Houben, will be assured. Cycling enthusiasts everywhere expressed satisfaction yesterday over "Zim's" course In accepting the challenge, and the general opinion was that a series of graxd races would be the result.

The big rosy in the Republican camp in this city between the Platt men and anti-Platt men is not the only one. There is a minor trouble in the Platt faction which is causing some disturbance and may result in even the more complete retirement of ex-Justice Jacob M. Patterson. It comes from the prominence which is given to Abe Gruber, the little Platt man of the Twenty-third Assembly District.

BUTTE, Mon., March 26. -- Henry L. Haupt, President of the Montana Mining, Loan, and Investment Company, is on trial in the United States court here on a charge of sending non-mailable matter through the Post Office. The testimony has developed a gigantic swindling scheme, in which many prominent men are innocently involved.

FRIEDRICHSRUH, March 26. -- The sky this morning was overcast, and the temperature was several degrees lower than it was yesterday. Hundreds of police in plain clothes and a squadron of hussars were detailed as field gendarmes in view of the visit of Emperor William.

According to a dispatch received yesterday at the office of the Union Pacific receivers in this city, and given out from there, great surprise is expressed in the West at the report circulated here that the application of the bondholders' committee of the Oregon Short Line 5 per cent, issue for a separate receiver had been granted.

ALBANY, March 26. -- The Special Committee that has been at work for two months on the new Congressional district apportionment has finished its work, except in the New-York City and Kings County districts. The work has been done well, from a Republican standpoint. Out of the thirty-four districts, at least twenty have been prepared with the especial view of being controlled by the Republicans.

Gov. Morton's special message to the Legislature regarding measures affecting this city leaves nothing to be desired so far as the Police Magistrates bill is concerned. In regard to that he is clear and explicit. It is a "necessary step," he says, "toward municipal reform," and he does not hesitate to favor its prompt passage.

HEMPSTEAD. N. /.. ]arch 26. -- The second run across coulry after the hounds was participated in by the members of the Aeadowbrook Hunt Clt/ to-day. The stiff breeze that ,'as blowing across the Hempstead plains was very cold and penetrating, but did not prevent an excellent, lull of eight miles by the huntsmen. The meet was at the Mlneola Fair Grounds at 3:30 P. M.

BURLINGTON, N.J., March 26. -- The New-Jersey Methodist Episcopal Conference adjourned to-day, after Bishop Merrill had announced the ministerial appointments. The following is the full list of appointments:

ALBANY, March 26. -- Richard Watson Gilder sat by the side of Leader Danforth E. Ainsworth in the Assembly this morning and had the pleasure of seeing advanced to third reading the reform New-York Tenement-House bill which was spoken of by Mr. Ainsworth in these words:

Three games were played yesterday in the amateur billiard tournament at Maurice Daly's Brooklyn Academy. J.B. Stark defeated Frank Keeney in the afternoon by 26 points, in addition to the handicap of 50 points.

There is no doubt of the general and intense popular interest in the mass meeting to be held at the Cooper Union to-night. The misfortune is that there is no more spacious place available for it in order that the people might be more fully represented in the actual attendance.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- It is now officially known at the German Embassy that Baron von Saurma-Jelisch, who has represented the German Government here for the last two years, will be succeeded in a few weeks by Baron von Thielmann, the present German Minister at Munich.

Justice Davy, sitting in the Supreme Court, yesterday made it plain to the lawyers who appear before him that he is on the bench to transact the business of his court in the most expeditious manner consistent with fairness all around, and that he does not intend to fool away time that belongs to the public.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- It is agreed by all who are familiar with the facts that Senor Muruaga, the Spanish Minister, has reason to thank his stars that the change in the Spanish Ministry occurred at a time when the period of his usefulness in Washington had terminated.

Mrs., or Miss, Alice Mabel Bacon, her signature naturally does not inform me, has almost taken my breath away in her article of your issue of this morning. "Credulous Mr. Villiers." I like a good fight -- even with a lady, in print -- if I may be permitted to say so. But do the public care about it I wonder?

BUFFALO, March 26. -- Considerable discussion has been going on over the question of the disposition of the one-thousand-five-hundred-dollar reward which was offered for the arrest and conviction of the murderers of Montgomery Gibbs. The Cleveland detectives claim that they are entitled to the whole amount, but, as Assistant Superintendent Cussack of this city figured prominently in the case, it was naturally supposed that he would come in for a portion.

We recently published summaries of detailed statements of the actual cost of producing wheat in Argentina and of carrying it to a seaport. These statements were prepared by three wheat growers, and the cost of production and carriage were 35, 37, and 40 1/2 cents a bushel respectively.

Hardly a dissenting voice is raised against the selection of Bryant Park as the best possible and nearly perfect site for the great library that is soon to be New-York's glory and ornament. The arguments in its favor are numerous, weighty, and definite; those against it are few and vague.

President Benjamin Norton and Superintendent Daniel J. Quinn of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad, Brooklyn, were represented in their trial yesterday before Judge Moore, in the Court of Sessions, on the charge of having violated the ten-hour law, by Col. A.E. Lamb and ex-Judge Morris, Assistant District Attorney Maguire appeared for the prosecution.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 27 -- 3 A.M. -- A fire which originated in the building occupied by the A.F. Tanner Furniture Company and Landauer Co., dry goods, is still raging and threatens to become one of the most destructive fires ever known in this city.
Announcement was made from Albany yesterday that Gov. Morton had signed Senator Wolff's bill for the manufacture and use in this city of diphtheria antitoxine and other antitoxines.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., March 26. -- The propeller Metropolitan of the Central Vermont Line and the tub T.A. Scott collided about 4 o'clock this morning off Bartlett's Reef Lightship. The Metropolitan sustained damages that came near sending her to the bottom. She got into New-London, however, where her cargo was taken out and transferred to the steamer Block Island.

ALBANY, March 26. -- There is a question in the minds of many whether Jacob V. Jacobs of Troy, appointed as Deputy Superintendent of Public Works, will assume the position on April 1. At its meeting last week the newly-constituted Civil Service Commission adopted a resolution transferring the position of Deputy Superintendent of Public Works from Class B to Class A.
Street Cleaning-Commissioner Waring made public yesterday afternoon the following letter, which he has sent to several contractors in this city:

Just after what seems to be the final decision of the Faculty of Harvard that that university shall play no more intercollegiate football comes the announcement that arrangements are perfected for another intercollegiate sport in the form of a debate with Princeton. This contest, being intellectual in its nature, doubtless enlists the cordial co-operation of the Faculties of both institutions.

The League for Political Education held its fourth general meeting last evening at the residence of the President, Mrs. Henry M. Sanders, 433 Fifth Avenue. Nearly all the 200 members were present, as well as a large number of guests. Mrs. C. A. Runkle, Vice President of the league, presided.
If the weather proves suitable, the grand street parade of the Barnum Bailey Circus will take place to-night, passing along the following route:

Richard Croker will sail for Europe on the steamship Majestic to-day. Mrs. Croker and two of his younger boys will accompany him. He will remain away until late in September, at any rate. He goes to England to supervise the work of managing the string of racers which he recently sent over there.

The efforts made by Health Officer Doty to clear steamships arriving at Quarantine up to 9 P.M. have met with the approval of all shipping people. These were unanimous yesterday in proclaiming the Innovation to be one of vast advantage to the commercial interest of the port.

Piscator's hibernation has ended. A few bright, clement days have fired the true angler, the contemplative man, whose saving creed is that it is not all of fishing to fish, with the enthusiasm of the old days, his dreams and day thoughts have wandered affectionately to the delights of the gentle art, and he is eager to "wet a line."

GLASGOW, March 16. -- The excitement among Clyde yachtsmen over the issue of the race at Cannes for the Goelet-Bennett Cup on March 14 has eclipsed every reminiscence of yachting rivalry the Clyde has witnessed. The result of the racing between Thistle and Volunteer provoked much enthusiasm, but then the enthusiasm was all on one side and all associated with the prospects of the Clyde challenger.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Lincolnshire Handicap of 1,000 sovereigns, added to a sweepstakes of 20 sovereigns each, was won to-day at Lincoln by C. Duncan's Euclid. Col. North's El Diablo was second, and Baron de Rothschild's Amandier was third.

Mr. Bernhard Stavenhagen, pianist, and pupil of Liszt, and Master Jean Gerardy, violoncellist, have been "on the road." While off in that mysterious country, from whose bourne so many travelers fail to return, except on foot. Master Gerardy has achieved sufficient physical maturity to don trousers which extend to his ankles.
ORANGE, N.J., March 26. -- School Commissioner George P. Roberts of the Second Ward, in discussing the desirability of a consolidation of the Oranges, said to-day:

WASHINGTON, March 26. -The naval experts who have been examining the plans and bids for torpedo boats, have submitted a report to Secretary Herbert. The award of contract for three boats of this type may be expected within a few days if the opinions expressed by the technical examiners are sufficiently definite to aid the Secretary in reaching a conclusion.
The most horrible accident since the introduction of the trolley system in Brooklyn occurred last night in front of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, at Court and Congress Streets.
Charles Stewart Smith sent to Albany yesterday a letter addressed to Senators Lexow, Bradley, Cantor, O'Connor, Pound, and Robertson, and to Lieut. Gov. Saxton, Committee on Police Investigation.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 26. -- Attorney General Hancock to-day gave a hearing on the application of G.W. Hey of Syracuse, that he bring an action under Section 1,781 of the Code for the removal from office of President Matthew J. Dolphin of the International Postal Supply Company of New-York City. This corporation manufactures stamp-canceling machines in use in Government offices throughout the country, and has a capital of $2,000,000.

Congressman Lemuel Ely Quigg's appeal to Mayor Strong to reappoint John H. Crowe City Marshal revived yesterday numerous reminiscences as to Mr. Crowe's political career. From these reminiscences it appears that there have been times when even a Democrat has been useful to Lemuel Ely.

The Rapid-Transit Railroad Commissioners in executive session yesterday adopted without amendment of note the resolution, made public last Friday, on the routes and general plan of construction for the proposed rapid-transit system.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Gov. Morton has approved Senator Robertson's bill incorporating the Trustees of scenic and historic places and object and to provide for the care of certain property of the State.

Eight men are now in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, as the result of the murder of James Anderson Sunday morning. Four are charged with having killed him and the other four are held on charges of vagrancy, being wanted as witnesses. They will be taken before Justice Harriman, in the Gates Avenue Police Court, this morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 20. -- The University nine practiced outdoors to-day, the first time this season, in preparation for their first game, which will be played here to-morrow with the Columbia College team. Capt. Brooks will play a large number of men to-morrow, in order to see how the most promising new candidates show up.

BOSTON, March 26. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the American Bell Telephone Company to-day it was voted to change the by-laws so as to make the Board of Directors thirteen instead of twelve. President Hudson read the annual report while a vote was being taken for the Directors.

Traders worked to-day to bring about a reaction under the impression that one was due, and that with little effort a lower level might be secured. The result was a material falling off in the volume of business, the total transactions being only 210,655 shares, against 332,023 yesterday, and small fractional declines, as the rule, at the close.

Arthur Dyer has built a sloop yacht for W.E.C. Eustis of Boston at the Deep Haven yards at Lake Minnetonka. The new boat is now on her way to Boston, where she will be raced early in the season, and it is probable that if the new boat is a success Mr. Eustis will take her to England to try her there.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The white cap cases from Alabama were under argument in the Supreme Court to-day, after the Debs habeas corpus case had been taken under consideration.

There were no vacant seats at Durland's Riding Academy last night, and the second day's programme of the horse show was carried along smoothly. The regular patrons of the academy were out in force, and many other fanciers of the various types of horses used for riding and driving were interested spectators of this equine dress parade.

John Shaw, sixty-six years old, of 139 West Eighty-fourth Street, buyer and confidential clerk for Neuss, Hesslein Co., 90, 92, and 94 Franklin Street, fell from the Western limited express bound to Chicago, in the Park Avenue tunnel, near Sixty-seventh Street, at 4:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon and was killed.

The annual meeting of the New-York Mc-All Auxiliary was held yesterday afternoon in the lecture room of the Broadway Tabernacle, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. Addresses were made by the Rev. Charles Cuthbert Hall, D.D., of Brooklyn, the Rev. Edward G. Thurber, D.D., of the American Chapel in Paris, and the Rev. Joseph R. Deryee of Grace Reformed Church.

It is very fortunate that the Japanese fanatic who assaulted Li Hung Chang did not succeed in killing him. The assault is in itself sufficiently calamitous for Japan. If an envoy under the national protection had been done to death by one of her people, the prestige which Japan has gained by the war would have received a shock as severe as that inflicted upon it by the massacre at Port Arthur.

George D. Burton, who has had business prominence in Boston, and has heretofore enjoyed a good reputation, is under arrest charged with obtaining $15,000 from Brouwer McGown, brokers, at 2 Wall Street, by fraud.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Tokio correspondent of the Central News telegraphs that Li Hung Chang's condition is progressing favorably. The assassin's bullet penetrated the bone one-third of an inch, but the wound, the surgeons now say, is not serious
At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday the following resolution, introduced by Alderman Windolph, was adopted.
The Amherst College Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs opened their annual Spring tour in the Berkeley Lyceum last night before a large audience.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the German Ladies' Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans was celebrated in Music Hall last night in the presence of a large and distinguished assemblage.
Adam A. Cross is again a Captain of New-York police, and George Smith, who had been a ward man, is now a patrolman.

Telegraphic dispatches are to an intelligent newspaper reader what bread and meat and plum pudding are to a hungry man. They are at once the substantial filling and the artistic trimming. News is the backbone, the life, the spirit of a newspaper. Readers of this paper who perused the telegraphic symposium in the issue of yesterday morning will readily agree with these propositions.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Senator Mullin to-day introduced a bill which aims to better protect public morals, defend the innocence of youth, prevent the degrading of women and girls, protect the honor, and preserve the respect due to women. It provides as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Col. Thaddeus H. Stanton has been promoted to the post of Paymaster General of the Army to succeed Brig. Gen. William Smith, retired. Col. Stanton was made Deputy Paymaster General in 1890. His record from the time he entered the army in 1861 is exceptionally good. He enlisted in the First Battalion, District of Columbia Volunteers, in 1861.

ALBANY, March 26. -- It is now conceded that the Lexow police bills will come up in the Senate on Thursday morning, a notice of a call of the House having been issued this afternoon by Senator O'Connor. It is equally certain that the bi-partisan Police Commission bill will pass, and that the Reorganization bill will be killed.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The United States and Venezuelan Claims Commission made an award to-day in favor of the United States for $141,000, without interest, as indemnity for the Venezuelan Steam Transportation Company of New-York, whose steamers, Hero, Sanfernando, and Nutnas, were seized on the Orinoco, in 1871, and $300, with interest from that time, for each of the company's officers at Port Sturges and Maurinus.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The army engineer officers, especially those in charge of river and harbor work, have viewed with much interest recent efforts to secure an appropriation from Congress, evidently in opposition to the advice of the War Department people. The history of the case is interesting as showing a method of securing Congressional favors.
The large auction sales of real estate held yesterday were the centres of interest to speculators and men in the business. Several notable transactions at private sale were, however, reported.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury held short session yesterday, during which, however, a number of witnesses was examined. Foreman Leggett did not reach the Criminal Courts Building until after 11 o'clock, and at 1:30 an adjournment was taken until this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Hawaiian Minister, Mr. Thurston, aware that he had overstepped the limits of propriety in the discharge of his duties as the representative of the Dole Republic, and being confident that his usefulness was impaired, if not destroyed, allowed the fact to become known a short time ago that he was regarded with disfavor by the Department of State.

In March, 1891, a bill was introduced in the Minnesota Legislature with the intent to prohibit the exhibition of women's legs on the public stage. Much was made of this "anti-tights bill" in the press dispatches, and it was, first and last, the cause of much presumably innocent merriment.

WASHINGTON, D. C., ,M[arch 26. -- Ofiqcial confirmation of the shooting of LI Hung Chang at Shimonoseki was received at a late hour at the Japanese Legation last night. The dispatch' was written by Mr. ,%/lutsu, the Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs. It is dated Sunday last, and reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Attorney General Olney, in his argument in the Debs habeas corpus case to-day, based his claim for United States jurisdiction in the premises on grounds not previously stated. He said: "The single question now is whether the court below had jurisdiction of the case made by the original bill."

The Equitable Mutual Fire Insurance Corporation, of which Edward M. Knox, the well-known hatter, is President, and James R. Skinner Co. are the managers, has come to grief. Selden R. Hopkins, an expert accountant, who was employed to examine the books and papers of the concern, says in his report:

The twelfth annual convention of the Kings County Woman's Christian Temperance Union was held yesterday in the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, at Clermont and Willoughby Avenues. The attendance was large.
Prof. Felix Adler of the Society for Ethical Culture lectured last night, at the Hebrew Institute, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, on "The Influences of Organized Labor."

ALBANY, March 27. -- At the Leland Opera House to-night Robert Mantell produced a new play called "The Husband," an adaptation by Espy Williams of Tom Taylor's "Retribution." The play is in four acts, with the scenes laid in La Rochelle and in Paris, France.
Mrs. Louisa Ann Burl has brought twenty-seven suits in the Court of Common Pleas to impress her dower rights on about $500,000 worth of property to which Capt. Benjamin Richardson passed title.

BALTIMORE, March 27. -- The British steamship Laurestina arrived here this afternoon from Santiago de Cuba. From her crew the story of the killing of John Lowe, one of their number, at Santiago, March 19, was learned in detail.

President Benjamin Norton and Superintendent Daniel J. Quinn of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company, Brooklyn, who were indicted by the Grand Jury for violating the ten-hour labor law, and who have been on trial for three days, were acquitted yesterday by a jury in the Kings County Court of Sessions, before Judge Moore.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The ram Katahdin developed remarkable speed at the contractors' trial, near Bath, Me., yesterday, running repeatedly over a measured mile at the rate of 17.82 knots per hour. The following telegram regarding the performance was received at the Navy Department this morning from Chief Engineer Entwistle, who represents the Government in charge of the vessel:

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 27. -- The trouble over the Manitoba school case and the passing of the remedial order for separate schools in the Province of Manitoba is the origin of trouble which has brought on a political crisis in the Cabinet.

GREENWOOD, Ky., March 27. -- Two robbers dead and a third mortally wounded is the result of an attempt to plunder southbound Passenger Train No. 3 on the Cincinnati Southern Road (Queen and Crescent System) at 2:30 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Among the reports of committees when the House was called to order to-day was that of the Committee on Banks. It reported adversely the Bold bill, compelling fraternal beneficiary orders to deposit $100,000 with the Superintendent of Insurance for the protection of policy holders.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 27. -- Albert Schulke of Westwood was shot, but not seriously hurt, by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Theodore Schulke, at Hillsdale, this morning. Mrs. Schulke says she mistook her brother-in-law for a tramp, and, having recently been much annoyed by knights of the road, she took no chances, and shot on sight.

NASHUA, N.H., March 27. -- The Nashua Savings Bank has been closed by the Bank Commissioners. The officers say depositors will be paid in full. They assign as the cause of the suspension the depression of 1893 and the consequent shrinkage in the value of securities, together with the enactment of unfavorable legislation by the State.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Unless all signs go wrong, the Republican machine is back upon the track, with practically all hands aboard. There is abundant evidence to-night that a modus vivendi has been established between Mayor Strong and the Platt forces. How long it may last must be a matter of pure conjecture.

LONG ISLAND CITY, March 27. -- The war being waged by City Treasurer Lucien Knapp of Long Island City against Mayor H.S. Sanford and the General Improvement Commission goes merrily on, with Mr. Knapp in the lead.
It is probable that within a short time the proposed system of street-car mail service will be introduced in this city.

The closing of the season's exhibition drills of the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club was given last evening at Vanderbilt Avenue, near Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. A thousand members and friends were present.

Samuel Esterich, an expressman, was arrested yesterday, on a charge of poisoning a rival's team of horses, the arrest being made under cimcumstances calculated to discourage practices of that kind, even among the most revengeful.

At a meeting of the Park Board yesterday a resolution was adopted stating that the board disapproved of the bill now before the Legislature taking the charge of the police out of the hands of the Park Department.
With the failure of the Victoria Hotel yesterday one of the most famous hostelries in this country -- in fact, its reputation was international -- will probably pass out of existence.

Quite a number of trotters changed hands at auction yesterday in the Bull's Head district, and the quality of the stock offered was above the average. As a result, the buyers were out in force, and the market was steady to the last. L.H. Dahlman sold forty-five head, and only one of the lot failed to bring $100.

FRIEDRICHSRUH, March 27. -- The Halberstadt Cuirassiers, with the regimental band, marched to the railway station this morning to await the arrival of Prince Hohenlohe. The Chancellor arrived at noon and was received by Prince Bismarck, who wore the uniform and helmet of the cuirassiers.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 27. -- Lieut. Nathan C. Twining of the navy has succeeded Lieut. Albert C. Dieffenbach as Inspector of Naval Ordnance here. Lieut. Dieffenbach, who has been stationed in Hartford for two years, has been ordered to the Olympia, which will go into commission April 1.

LONDON, March 27. -- The Pall Mall Gazette says that M. Baduel, the director of the Buffalo-Seine racing paths, has offered to back the American bicycle rider, Zimmerman, against Houben for 1,000 a side for a race at any distance. Houben's adviser, M. Cranicks, has the highest opinion of the latter rider's powers, but expresses fear that his friends will be unable to raise such large stakes.

A gentleman of long experience n public life, and who is probably more intimately acquainted with the practical relations between the civil service and politics and with the steady progress of reform than any other New-Yorker, writes us:

ORANGE, N.J., March 27. -- Freeholder George R. Stagg of West Orange, in conversation with the correspondent of The New-York Times to-day, said he was heartily in favor of the consolidation of the Oranges as proposed.

PARIS. March 27. -- An American named Adam Reed Waddle, who is residing at the Hotel Scribe, was wounded in the Gare du Nord this morning at 11:40, by another American named Edward O'Brien. The latter fired from a revolver six shots, all of which took effect.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 27. -- A delegation consisting of R. Bond, Colonial Secretary; E.P. Morris. G. H. Emerson, and W.H. Horwood sailed this morning at 10 o'clock for Ottawa to ask for confederation with Canada.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27. -- Judge Green, in the Federal Court, to-day refused the motion for a preliminary injunction in the case of the American Graphophone Company vs. The United States Phonograph Company. The plaintiff corporation averred that the latter company was infringing on its inventions and patents in the manufacture of a machine to record and reproduce speech.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 27. -- A free postal delivery system is to be established in Kingston, and although the people have got exactly what they have asked for for years -- that is, free delivery from both ends of the city -- a vigorous protest is entered.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- In the opinion of Yale men who have watched critically the practice work of the university baseball nine, the team Yale will put forth in the Varsity series of games this year will be the strongest all-around set of players that has supported the blue in some time.

Although M. Worth's death would seem to the uninitiated to be a terrible loss to the sartorial art, it is much less important than it would have been some years ago, for of late rival houses have greatly increased in power, and Worth's is no longer as pre-eminent as for over half a century it undoubtedly was.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- If the Brazilian Minister, Senor Mendonca, is to be appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court of his country, as stated in a Buenos Ayres dispatch, the fact is not known to him. Minister Mendonca is entirely satisfied with his duties as the Brazilian representative at Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The coast defense vessel Monterey, which arrived at San Francisco yesterday, after several months spent in testing Puget Sound coal, has been ordered to cruise along the coast of South and Central America, continuing on the Pacific station.

That perennially popular prerunner of the circus season, the limelight (formerly torchlight) parade, started through this town last night when there was a bitterly cold wind blowing, and the dust was swirling in clouds through the streets. Consequently, some of the visitors from the tropics, who do not wear any clothes to speak of, and some of the animals particularly susceptible to the weather, were obliged to remain at home.

The Bank Clerks' Bowling League held its first annual banquet at the New Amsterdam Hotel, Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue, last night. It was the first time the league has given out prizes at a banquet, but judging from the success of last night's gathering the close of future tournaments will be celebrated in like manner.
May I ask you to permit me to correct a misapprehension that may arise from the form of certain statements attributed to me in an interview printed this morning?

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- In Criminal Court No. 2 this morning Nathaniel Wilson, attorney for H.O. Havemeyer and John E. Searles, made a motion to advance for trial the cases against them for refusing to answer questions asked by the Senatorial Sugar Trust investigators. Mr. Wilson said it was imperative to Mr. Havemeyer's business interests that his trial should take place before April 15.

Commissioner Kerwin conducted the trials of delinquent policemen at headquarters yesterday, considering among other cases those of Roundsman Orin H. Sims of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station, and Patrolman Jacob M. Young of the East Sixty-seventh Street squad.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., March 27. -- The body of James Kelly, one of the men who yesterday escaped from the Mercer County Workhouse, was found this morning in bushes close to a road near the workhouse. He had been serving a short term for drunkenness and disorderly conduct.

The Metropolitan Traction Company is soon to extend its cables system to the Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street lines that are under its control. This is another important step in carrying out the Metropolitan Traction Company's plan of adopting for all its lines the most aproved methods for transportation.

Regarding the statement telegraphed from Buffalo that the New-York Central management had determined to equip its Niagara Falls Branch with electric power, President Depew said yesterday: "That matter is now under consideration. We learned that a local company had been formed for the purpose of building and operating an electric railway between Buffalo and Niagara Falls, paralleling our own line.

-- We have been accustomed to so much meretricious work from the modern Italian painters, fairly flooding our markets, that it is pleasant to chronicle a change to the more serious pictures now on view at the gallery of A. Preyer, on Fifth Avenue. This house now shows sixty-five examples, recently received from the better known of the younger men, and the collection is interesting and instructive, not to say refreshing.

The little colony of actresses and actors living near Broadway, between Twenty-third and Thirtieth Streets, was thrown into a state of excitement last night by the news that two theatrical people, one of them an actress who had played in several good companies in this city, and the other an actor who had been out of an engagement for about a year, had been found dead in a room in West Twenty-fourth Street.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27. -- A certificate of incorporation of the New-York and Hudson River Navigation Company was filed in the office of the Secretary of State today. The principal office of the company is to be in New-York, and its branch offices in Jersey City. The capital stock is $500,000, divided into 5,000 shares of the par value of $100.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27. -- The steamer Australia arrived from Honolulu shortly before 9 o'clock this morning. It brought no news of action by the Hawaiian Government on Secretary Gresham's request for the recall of Minister Thurston. It is understood that the Secretary's letter had not reached Honolulu when the Australia sailed.
NEWARK, N.J., March 27. -- Charles E. Haskins has reported to the police of Harrison a robbery of which he was the victim nearly a month ago.

MADRID, March 27. -- The latest dispatches from Havana have alarmed the Government. They indicate that the insurrection is spreading rapidly, and is already beyond the control of the local commanders.

It is really too bad that certain painters of eminence have permitted themselves to be the dupes of some showmen who in their effort to "give the public what it wants" have placed themselves under the ban of decent, public opinion and in reach of the law. Few men in this community are more respected than William M. Chase, J. Wells Champney, and J.G. Brown.

Messrs. Bennett Graft have exchanged, for W.B. Baldwin, at $25,000, the five-story apartment house 1,088 Park Avenue, with Lindsay Johnsen, for the three-story and basement limestone-front dwelling 330 West Seventy-first Street, 18 by 56, and extension by 100.5, at $27,250.

RICHMOND, Va., March 27. -- This afternoon the New-York regulars were defeated here by the second club by a score of 16 to 15. All the pitchers were in the box, and were batted freely. During the game Catcher Smith had a finger broken, which will disable him for some time. A swift ball thrown across the plate struck him on the end of one of his fingers, breaking it, and causing him great pain.

LONG ISLAND CITY, March 27. -- Ex-Mayor Patrick J. Gleason was lined $10 to-day by Police Justice Duffy for assaulting John Griffin, a former motorman on the electric railroad until recently owned by Mr. Gleason.

Judging from the crowded house at Durland's Riding Academy last evening, the horse show increase in popularity as it progresses. The programme for the third day had many attractive features, and it was midnight before the eight classes had been decided. The ring was in charge of James H. Sammis and Baron Paul Vietrighoff, and the competitions were so keen that the interest kept up to the last.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Mr. Thurston, the Hawaiian Minister, departed from Washington this afternoon at 3:15 o'clock for Boston, whence he will go to San Francisco. He had received no notice of recall, nor had he heard anything from Hawaii on the subject up to the time of his departure. Frank P. Hastings is left as Charge d'Affairs.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday the committee decided to recommend to the club that the added money to the Suburban Handicap be fixed at $5,000. This is about one-fifth of last year's added money. The value of added money in other fixed stakes will be reduced in like proportion if the recommendation is adopted. The reduction is the outcome of the racing uncertainty.

Ex-Congressman Timothy J. Campbell, who once pleaded that a little thing like the Constitution should not come between friends, is now trying to place the Constitution between himself and Judge McAdam, whose friend he has been for twenty-five years.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27. -- The first intercollegiate debate between Harvard and Princeton was held in Princeton's new commencement building to-night. The debate was arranged by a joint committee representing the Harvard Union and the Wendel Philips Club of Harvard and the Cliosophic and American Whig Societies of Princeton. The question was:
The question of the payment of income tax by non-resident aliens does not, in the opinion of Edward Grouse, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of New-York, admit of doubt.

Fifty-two members of the Knickerbocker Whist Club of this city met a like number of players representing the Brooklyn Whist Club in a friendly match at the St. Cloud Hotel last evening and defeated them by 4,400 to 4,382 points. As the score shows, the match was very close, only 18 points separating the teams. The Brooklyn team was made up of representatives of a number of clubs.
POUGHKEEPSIE, March 27. -- The students at St. Stephen's Episcopal College, at Annandale, have complained for some time of the rigorous discipline of the Rev. George Anthony, one of the Faculty.

The full report of the proceedings in the suit of the National Harrow Company (a combination chartered in New-Jersey and having its principal office in Utica) against two dealers in agricultural implements doing business in Chesterton, Ind., shows that the court's decision must be regarded as perhaps the most remarkable in the very long list of cases involving combinations for the restraint of trade and suppression of competition.
With tremendous emphasis a demand was made last night upon the State Legisture to give the people of this city the reforms for which they voted last November.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The news comes here from Buffalo that the Public Printer has appointed Francis A. Crandall of Buffalo to be Superintendent of Documents, under the new bill providing for the printing and distribution of documents. This is an appointment provided to be made by the Public Printer, and Mr. Benedict has chosen the man who was spoken of as likely to get the office which Mr. Benedict holds.

STAPLETON, S.I., March 27. -- Four hundred ladies, representing the Presbyterian Churches in the Presbytery of Brooklyn, gathered in the First Presbyterian Church here to-day as delegates to the twenty-third annual meeting of the Woman's Home and Foreign Missionary Society.

NICE, March 27. -- In a rough sea and strong wind the Britannia defeated the Ailsa to-day. The Britannia, however, was much better sailed, and outmanoeuvred her opponent. The Ailsa proved tender, and, as yachtsmen here said, had too much sail when the wind suddenly increased.

Garbage disposition under the plan outlined by Col. Waring, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, with the additional inducement of the lucky contractor being permitted to use free of charge, an economical process for purifying foul, effluent water, controlled in this country by Col. Waring, became yesterday a topic of interest among those to whom such matters are of more or less concern.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The full text of Great Britain's ultimatum to Nicaragua is as follows:

Claims were made yesterday that checks of La Follette Coal and Iron Company, drawn on the Franklin National Bank, had been refused payment. They were signed by Eugene Davis, general manager of La Follette Company, and had been passed by A.G. Moyer, who was on March 19 appointed a clerk in the office of the Commissioner of Jurors by Major Plimley.
LONDON. March 27. -- The Times's correspondent in Simonoseki says:

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 19. -- The Legislative Council made short work to-day of the Government's proposed tariff. After a brief debate, the measure was thrown out by a vote of 6 to 3, and the scheme to create a surplus in the colonial revenues and incidentally hit the United States a blow for withdrawing from the reciprocity arrangement with Jamaica came to naught.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- The firm of Malcolm Waterbury, which did an extensive "bucket-shop" business in Illinois, Missouri, Nebraska, and Iowa, made an assignment to-day to George Wiley, a Board of Trade man.
