It is now plain that Mayor Strong offered ex-Sheriff James O'Brien an appointment as Police Commissioner soon after he took office, and that the Mayor's present understanding is that the ex-Sheriff will not take it.

William Caesar, the West Indian negro who was arrested on Tuesday for the murder of Mary Martin, the colored woman with whom he was living at 148 West Twenty-seventh Street, was remanded in the Tombs Police Court yesterday until this afternoon. He broke down when arrested and confronted with the evidences of his crime, and since his incarceration has "gone all to pieces," as one of his custodians said.

Antitoxine was the subject of several papers and discussion at the Academy of Medicine last night. Joseph D. Bryant, M.D., President of the Council, presided, and the large lecture room was inadequate to accommodate the largest and most representative audience that ever attended a stated meeting of the organization.

We are continually encountering proofs of British insularity, but we were nevertheless not prepared to hear that the result of the municipal election in Chicago was determined by British influence. Least of all were we prepared to hear this from The London Daily News, which commonly takes much more care than most of its contemporaries to inform itself before speaking of American affairs.

The members of the Brooklyn Women's Dumb Animal Aid Association held a fair in the Pouch Mansion, in Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, Wednesday. The fair was in aid of the Brooklyn Building Fund of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and a goodly sum of money was realized.

MADRID, April 4. -- Gen. Martinez Campos started from here last evening en route for Cuba. The members of the Cabinet and a large number of Deputies, Senators, Generals, and other distinguished persons bade him farewell at the station, the platfrom of which was packed with enthusiastic people who cheered for Martinez Campos and Spanish Cuba.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4. -- Twenty-five more Deputy Sheriffs have been sent by Sheriff Serviss to the scene of the strike at the Staten Island Terra Cotta and Lumber Company at Spa Springs, near Woodbridge, to protect the property of the company. The employes of the company left work because their wages had not been paid.

STAPLETON, L.I., April 4. -- Joseph Keppler of New-York, son of the late editor of Puck, and Miss Lulu Eva Bechtel, daughter of the late George Bechtel, the wealthy brewer of Stapleton, S.I., were married to-night in the First Presbyterian Church.

The salaries of a number of employes of the Dock Board were reduced considerably yesterday, the saving to the city being over $24,000 a year. It is expected that the salaries of others will be cut down within a short time. The board also intends to make some removals and to abolish some offices.
Keen up-town competition has forced another famous down-town hotel out of the business. The Brevoort House, at Fifth Avenue and Waverley Place, will close on the 15th of this month.

Desirous of commemorating the occupation of Manhattan Island by the Dutch, the Holland Society of New-York proposes, with the permission of the City Fathers, to erect a monument to the memory of William the Silent. Riverside Drive is the spot upon which it is hoped to place the work when completed.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 4. -- The Democratic State Committee held an important meeting this morning. There was a full attendance.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- The Supreme Court handed down its decision to-day in the cases against John W. Wartman, the Camden attorney at law charged with fraud by numerous clients. The Supreme Court found him guilty and disbarred him, ordering his name stricken off the attorneys' roll.

ALBANY, April 4. -- A final hearing on the New-York City Police Justices bill, which abolishes the Justices and provides for nine Police Magistrates, was had before the Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon. It was opened by Senator O'Connor, reading a letter from Miss Foster, (the Tombs Angel,) earnestly opposing the measure.

We breathe oxygen in, and coal out. Experiments show that eight ounces troy of solid carbon are given off by a pair of human lungs every 24 humans. That would be 6 1/2 tons in a life of 75 years. What would that amount of carbon be worth in the form of diamond? A diamond is pure carbon.

BOSTON, April 4. -- There was a novel kind of ship launch at East Boston this afternoon -- the launching of the float which will carry the theatre of the Floating Palace Amusement Company. This is the latest thing in theatres, and Manager Laskey, who has the affair in charge, is confident that it will be a success.
That distinguished jurist and shining light of Tammany Hall. Police Justice "Barney" Martin, has concluded "to vindicate" himself.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- A stir was created among Philadelphia sugar men to-day by an order issued by the Sugar Trust directing them to stop handling all imported sugars. A number of brokers say they will not be materially affected by the order, as they ordinarily handle but little of the imported product.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The plan to provide quick entry to steamships arriving in New-York Harbor after sunset has not yet been completed. Collector Kilbreth, consulted with Secretary Carlisle and Assistant Secretary Hamlin this morning regarding the details of the plan, and considerable progress was made, but he was obliged to return to New-York without instructions to put the plan in immediate operation.

The manifesto of Mr. Platt, to which the name of Edward Lauterbach is appended, is melancholy reading for friends of good government, whatever their party preference may be, and it must be especially so to Republicans who sincerely desire that the party to which they belong may be an instrument for good government and thereby command the confidence of intelligent and honest citizens.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oklahoma, April 4. -- Five men robbed a Rock Island passenger train at Dover last night.

PATERSON, N.J., April 4. -- The Grand American Handicap, the chief event of the year for the crack wing shots of the country, was opened to-day at Wlllard Park, and ten rounds were shot before lqeferee Pentz ordered an adjournment until to-morrow. About 800 persons were on hand to witness the sport.

Phillip Flint, a German butcher, twenty-four years old, of 160 Essex Street, attempted to commit a burglary and murder early yesterday morning at 323 East Houston Street. His failure was due to the breaking of his knife blade at a critical moment.

All of the members of the association of lake transportation lines met in the Trunk Line Association offices in this city yesterday and agreed on the distribution of lake and rail traffic -- package freight -- east-bound, for the approaching navigation season.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, reports that the total imports of sugar during the month of March, through the ports of Baltimore, Boston, New-Orleans, New-York, Philadelphia, and San Francisco represented a total of 390,985,970 pounds. Of this total, 6,899,701 pounds were of beet sugar, dutiable; 35,910,984 pounds entered free of duty from the Hawaiian Islands, and 345,473,436 pounds were can sugar, dutiable.
LONDON, April 5. -- Oscar Wilde has been arrested. He was taken to a cell in the Bow Street Station.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt left here for New-York this afternoon, accompanied by his faithful follower Lou Payn. Before starting, however, Mr. Platt transacted a quantity of business of a legislative character. He spent last night, not at the Executive Mansion, where he had originaly intended, but as the guest of Speaker Fish.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- It is believed that the fever will make great inroads upon the Spanish forces during the heated term, which is now commencing in Cuba. Of the 40,000 Spanish troops who will serve in the island this year, fully 85 per cent. are unacclimated, and these, it is thought, will suffer terribly as a result of the insufficient protection which will be given to them in the field.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 5. -- The Legislature of this State passed a bill authorizing East Orange to elect a township President, with the power to veto the acts of the Township Committee, and giving him other prerogatives.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The flagship the Royal Arthur of the British squadron in the Pacific, which arrived at Panama yesterday morning, has ben cruising along the coast of South America, having left Coquimbo, Chile, Feb. 27, and after a month's stay at Callao, proceeded north.

MOBILE, Ala., April 5. -- At the South and West Grain and Trade Congress the Committee on Credentials reported nine States represented. N.B. Thistlewood of Cairo, Ill., was chosen President, and W.T. West of Mobile and H.H. Smith of New-Orleans Secretaries. In taking the chair Capt. Thistlewood urged the South and West to organize for mutual interchange of trade.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Not the least remarkable feature about the Standard Telephone Company is the secrecy with which operations have been conducted. It is even doubtful if the Bell Company knows much, if anything, about what has been done by its rival in aggregated capital, if not yet its rival in the actual operation of telephone lines.

Richard Watson Gilder, Health Commissioner Edson, and others prominently identified with the movement to secure tenement house reform, appeared before Mayor Strong yesterday at a public hearing one one of the Tenement House Commission's bills -- that providing for additional small parks on the lower east side.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 5. -- The Massachusetts Mill Committee has completed its inspection of the four largest mills in South Carolina, and arrived in Charlotte to-night on its way to Columbia, S.C., and Augusta, Ga. The committee continues to find much that is of interest and is members freely express themselves as pleased with the conditions that exist in the South.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 5. -- A session of the Branch Supreme Court was held at the Court House this morning. Justices Dixon and Lippincott were on the bench. Nathan R. Fowler and William Reen, two of the ballot-box stuffers of 1889, who have not yet been punished, were arraigned. They were sentenced in 1892, Fowler to six months and Reen to fifteen months in the penitentiary.

The scheme for setting aside the popular vote and electing the Governor by Legislative committee which has been going on in Tennessee since the beginning of the year continues to produce "bad blood" in the politics of that State, from which the Democratic Party is sure to suffer.

The annual report of the DepartmSnt of Public Parks for 1894 came to light in The City Record yesterday. It was signed: by Commissioners Clausen and Tappen. It cliffered from ordinary annual reports in that a determined effort was evidently made to make it somewhat poetic. Here is one extract;

We do not know what have been the recent relations of Mr. James S. Clarkson with Mr. Benjamin Harrison. When they were of sufficient contemporary interest to attract the attention of the newspapers they were reported as quite friendly, and though Mr. Harrison, who was then President of the United States, may have thought Mr. Clarkson's efforts in his behalf somewhat of a misfit, we are not aware that he ever suspected him of duplicity.

PATERSON, N.J., April 5. -- The Grand American Handicap ended to-day at Willard Park, and a new star has risen among the wing shots of the States. At the close of the twenty-fifth round three men were tied for first money. They were J.H. Messner of Pittsburg, Penn.; J.A.R. Elliot of Kansas City, Mo., and Frank Class of Morristown, N.J.
PARIS, April 5. -- M. Hanotaux, Minister of Foreign Affairs, spoke in the Senate this evening concerning Sir Edward Grey's statement in the House of Commons last week.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Secretary Gresham left Washington this evening by steamer for Fort Monroe, where he will spend Sunday, returning to this city, according to his present intention, on Monday morning. Although the Secretary professes to feel as well as ever, he has taken a few days at the seashore in deference to the deep concern manifested by his family and close friends, who are certain that he is overworked.

The Platt Commissioners did not find time to demonstrate what they could do for the cause of municipal reform until yesterday, when Commissioner Kerwin suddenly bobbed up in the Police Board meeting, and offered a motion for an investigation, which was adopted.

LONG ISLAND CITY, April 5. -- Rosa Collins, seventeen years old, daughter of Capt. G.L. Collins of 102 Halsey Street, this city, left her home on the morning of Feb. 6 to go to a nearby grocery store. She has not been seen since.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 5. -- Marcos Morales, the leader of the Cuban colony in Philadelphia, to-day received a letter from the New-York bureau of the revolutionary party containing verification of the report of Gen. Maceo's landing on the east end of the island, near Baracoa.

Several increases of wages -- some of them affecting large groups of employes -- have been reported in the last few days. The most important of these advances are those which have been made in the coke district of Western Pennsylvania and in two prominent woolen mills. The list is as follows:

There is a lesson for other States in the recent experience of certain savings banks in New-Hampshire. The Nashua bank, the Connecticut River Bank at Charlestown, a bank at Newport, and another at Keene have recently been closed. The first two, at least, are old institutions, one of them having been in existence more than forty years.

Dr. Charles P. Kreizer of 124 West Forty-first Street was arrested yesterday morning and taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court, on a warrant sworn out by his wife, Letitia, who asserts that last Friday he caught her by the throat and tried to throw her over the banisters, and that he took $635 out of her bureau drawer.

F.T. Walton, known somewhat familiarly as "Plunger" Walton, who holds verbal contracts with Street-Cleaning Commissioner Waring to remove street rubbish, has already aroused the anger of the residents of Paradise Park, the police of the Sixth Precinct, the Health Department, and Controller Ashbel P. Fitch, because of his peculiar methods of disposing of street refuse.

-- The Rev. Dr. William H. De Puy, who has been assistant editor of The Christian Advocate of this city for nearly a quarter of a century, is to retire from it on the 1st of May, that he may give his entire attention to other literary enterprises in which he has long been interested. He is to be succeeded on The Christian Advocate by the Rev. Stephen J. Herben of Chicago.

JACKSONVILLE, April 5. -- United States District Attorney Clark and United States Marshal McKay state that they attended the meeting merely out of idle curiosity, took no part in the proceedings whatever, and do not think they have violated any of the proprieties.

J.B. Stark of the new Manhattan Athletic Club won the amateur billiard tournament. He gets a silver cup and a trophy worth $150. Frank Keeney of the Oxford Club won the second prize, a trophy worth $100, Fred Oakes of the Liederkranz Club won third prize, a trophy worth $75, and Dr. Miller of the New-York Club and Arthur Townsend of the Catholic Lyceum divided the fourth prize between them.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- The Grand Trunk Railroad, which has been the leader in the recent heavy cutting of east-bound grain rates, to-day gave notice to the Inter-State Commerce Commission that it wilt cancel its 12-cent rate on grain between Chicago and New-York April 13. The rate has been in force via the Grand Trunk, Lehigh Valley, and Erie since last Monday, and was originally put in on oats.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 5. -- A few moments after the House opened this morning Mr. Ainsworth unburdened himself, and said in substance that if he was not to have the confidence of his colleagues he wished some one else to take his place as leader of the Republicans on the floor of the Assembly.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Gov. Morton has signed the Saratoga Charter Amendment bill. It goes into effect immediately, and legislates out of office the existing Village President and the two Trustees in the three wards. It creates six wards and provides for the election of thirteen Trustees next Tuesday, two from each ward, excepting the Fourth, and three from that.
PHILADELPHIA, April 5. -- The weekly report of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, issued yesterday, reads as follows:

A business meeting of the Board of Governors of the Kings County Tennis Club was held Wednesday evening at the house of F.M. Penreigh, 363 Macon Street, Brooklyn. A considerable number of new members were admitted, as the smaller tennis clubs in the neighborhood are gradually being swallowed up by the Kings County Club, which has now become one of the most powerful of the local clubs.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- There was to be an interesting test of a new shell at the Indian Head Proving Grounds to-morrow, but delay in the receipt of the projectile will postpone the trial until next week. The shell is a thirteen-inch common steel projectile made by the Sterling Steel Company of Pittsburg, Penn.

WHITESTONE, L.I., April 5. -- Miss Edith E. Armstrong, a teacher in the public school here, accused of severely punishing William Joyce and Edward Gleason, pupils, with a whip on March 14, has prepared a sworn affidavit setting forth the incidents that led up to the punishing of the two boys.

The death of Judge Randolph B. Martine, which, it was thought, might tend to heal the breach between Recorder Goff and his associate Judges in the Court of General Sessions, promises to have exactly the reverse effect. Just before leaving the bench yesterday the Recorder had these remarks spread on the records of his court:

The Democratic State Committee of Illinois has called a State Convention for June 4. In its call the committee has urged the Democratic voters to secure a full attendance at the County Conventions, so that their expressions of opinion may have authority. The question of most importance is that of silver.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 5. -- The Executive Committee on the annual League of American Wheelmen meet were in consultation here today. Chief Consul Gentle of Elizabeth and Fred J. Kerr of Newark met with the local committeemen. Chairman Ayres of the Hotel Committee reported that he was in receipt of communications from bicycle clubs all over the country asking for accommodations, an indication that the meet will attract thousands of wheelmen.
SOUTHAMPTON, April 5. -- The arrival of the Normannia at this port this morning has supplied details of the rescue of the crew of the British ship Arno in midocean March 24.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5. -- When the Senate investigating committee resumed its session this morning, Hugh Kinnard, the Newark dealer in paints and oils who had the contract for painting the Capitol, was recalled to the witness stand. He was first asked by Mr. Corbin, counsel of the committee, whether he had been able to discover the whereabouts of Merrick Marten, his partner, who is said to have mysteriously disappeared last November.

NICE, April 5. -- The trotting races of the Nice international meeting, over the Nice race course at Saint Laurent du Var, began to-day. The track is a circular one, 1,650 meters around. Its width is variable. The roadway is of turf, and in fair condition. It is, at least, dry. The distance of the track from Nice is about eighteen kilometers, and there are two railway stations near it.

William H.Wiggins died yesterday morning at his residence, 300 St. James Place, Brooklyn, after an illness of three months. He was seventy-three years old. For nearly half a century he had been a familiar figure down town. His business character was of the highest and he joined to it qualities that endeared him to a wide circle of acquintances.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 5. -- Chairman A.C. Hill announced to the New-York East Conference to-day that the Committee of Inquiry was ready to make its report in the Roche-Mains matter. He stated that the committee was unanimously of the opinion that the matters in dispute between Drs. Mains and Roche were not sufficient to justify an inquiry.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 5. -- The Crescent Wheelmen held their first important meeting of the season of 1895 last night. An amendment to the constitution, which provides that hereafter the iniatiation fee of the club shall be $4, one-half of which shall be used to make the applicant a member of the League of American Wheelmen.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Late last night Secretary Herbert cabled orders to Admiral Kirkland of the flagship San Francisco, now at Palermo, Sicily, to sail immediately for Smyrna, Asia Minor, and to have both the vessels of his squadron visit Alexandretta and Adana to confer with the United States Consuls and resident American citizens.

The Hamburg-American steamship Fuerst Bismarck, which took nearly 200 passengers on an excursion to the Orient two months ago, returned to port yesterday. Her original complement of excursionists had been depleted three-fourths when the vessel reacher harbor. Her other tourists decided to avail themselves of the company's offer to return by any other vessel of the line and have lingered in foreign ports.

Dun's Review will publish to-day a complete statement and analysis of business failures for the first quarter of the year. It shows a gratifying improvement in comparison with the first quarter of last year.

NEW ORLEANS, April 5. -- Five persons were killed and a number were injured by an explosion of powder in the grocery and ship chandlery of Charles J. Salathe, Decatur and Ursuline Streets, early this morning. Following is a list of the dead:

NEWPORT, R.I., April 5. -- A new pier, of small dimensions, is to be constructed at once at the torpedo station, for the purpose of supporting a Howell torpedo-firing tube. A pier for a Whitehead tube was constructed last year, and the one now to be built will lie directly alongside of it.

The bill abolishing the police courts of the city and providing for a new system of police magistrates and for a new Court of Special Sessions has been "hung up" nearly three months in the Senate, for reasons having no relation to its merits, and at the final hearing on Thursday the original pretext for opposition was abandoned and a number of others equally flimsy were adopted.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 5. -- Regarding the deliberations of the conference between Newfoundland delegates and the Dominion Government, it has been agreed that, as in all such diplomatic proceedings, secrecy shall be observed until both Governments consent to disclosure of the result, but it is understood the basis of negotiations will be the informal offer made to Newfoundland by Canada through Sir Charles Tupper in 1888.

Lieut. Gov. Charles T. Saxton was the guest of the Logan Club at its headquarters, 255 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night. A reception was tendered to him, which many of the prominent Republicans of the city attended.

The City Vigilance League, of which Dr. Parkhurst is President, and which, according to the doctor, was one of the most powerful factors in the overthrow of Tammany Hall, has been regularly incorporated.

The Bethel Colored Church, in Sullivan Street, was crowded to suffocation at noon yesterday by throngs of idle persons, who gathered merely out of morbid curiosity, to attend the funeral of Mary Martin, the negress for whose murder William Caesar is in custody.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5. -- A man and a woman were found dead in a room of the Palace Hotel this afternoon. A bullet in the heart had killed the woman, and one in the brain had ended the life of the man. The couple came to the hotel last night and registered as "Mr. Reta and wife, San Francisco."

NEWARK, N.J., April 5. -- The Atalanta Wheelmen's two-men bowling teams resumed play Wednesday night in Montgomery's alleys in their tournament, which is now nearing the close. Horry and Booraem still lead. President E. Allen Smith made the large score of 232, and "Count" Celestino Olozaga and Ernest F. Millar distinguished themselves by rolling well.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury met together for the last time as an official body yesterday morning at 10:30. All the business which had been brought before it during its long session had been disposed of on Thursday, and it only remained for the jurors to come into court, hand up what indictments had been found, and make their final report before being discharged.
Jesse M. Gregory, a longshoreman, shot his wife, Clara, in the apartments of her sister, Mrs. Jettie Martin, on the top floor of 423 Eighth Avenue, last night.

William Foster, a well-to-do master plumber of 281 Alexander Avenue, died at his residence yesterday morning from the effects of an accidental gunshot wound received last Monday morning while cleaning his gun. Mr. Foster was a member of the Forest Lake Gunning Club of Pike County, Penn.

This is the third volume of the new edition of the works of the great Russian master of philosophical fiction -- the master of a whole race of writers of England, America, and France Some one said, years ago, that Henry James went to Europe and imitated Turgenev, while W.D. Howells staid at home and imitated James.

The North German Lloyd steamship Havel, which has been fitted with two steel lifeboats of a new type, made a test of the boats yesterday. The invention is a very simple one. The chief quality claimed for it is the rapidity with which boats fitted with the apparatus can be made ready for lowering.

Most inconsiderate, from the point of view of a Boston gas manufacturer who wants to represent Delaware in the National Senate, is the selection of this particular time of 600 Hungarians, who have been working for months and for nothing in a Jersey factory, to call the world's attention to the ill effects which complete lack of food has upon the human structure.

ALBANY, April 5. -- But ten Senators were present when the Senate was called to order this morning. Senator O'Connor said one New-York paper had distorted the discussion on the Police Magistrates bill before the Judiciary Committee yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Postmaster Dayton of New-York City was again at the Post Office Department to-day, conferring with officials looking to the improvement of the mail service in New-York. He submitted a proposition to First Assistant Postmaster General Jones, made by an attorney named Foster, to erect a building in the vicinity of Thirtieth Street and Broadway, to be occupied by Station E.
Substantial confirmation was furnished here yesterday of the dispatch from Chicago announcing the advent of a big telephone company, to take the field and solicit business throughout the country.
Mr. Cornelius W. Luyster has sold to George W. Sturges, at about $75,000, the four-story Belleville stone and brick dwelling 236 West Seventy-second Street, 25 by 60 by 102.2.
Edward Eugene Lockwood declares that his father, Le Grand Lockwood, left an estate worth millions of dollars, all of which has disappeared in the administration of the property.

One of the most important matters to be considered by the Trunk Line and the Central Traffic Association Presidents at their meeting in this city next Tuesday is the threatened disruption of the very harmonious east-bound passenger situation.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- This statement was given out at the Department of Justice this afternoon:

Nothing Mr. Daly has done since last November has been so successful as his revival of "The Honeymoon." It is a pity that in the theatrical business best thoughts so often come late. Tobin's comedy is not, to be sure, a master work to be cherished and reverenced, but it is a good acting play. provided the actors be at hand, and it has worn surprisingly well. Last night the actors were at hand.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Secretary Morton has revoked the commission given W.E. Von Johannsen of California as honorary representative of the Agricultural Department abroad, but not on account of the rumors connecting Mr. Von Johannsen with alleged sharp practices in San Francisco and elsewhere.

Collector Kilbreth returned yesterday from Washington, where he had been to discuss with the Treasury officials the plans for the improvement of the customs service here, and for facilitating commerce. He seemed to feel that his visit had helped the plans.

The labors of the Extraordinary Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, originally appointed in the early part of January to investigate the Police Department besmirched by the revelations before the Lexow committee, were brought to a close yesterday.

The funeral of David M. Stone, for many years editor and proprietor of The Journal of Commerce, was held in the Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

Messrs. Kerwin and Murray seem bent upon devoting the closing days of their service as Police Commissioners to making sure that they shall not be regretted. There has never been any real danger. In announcing his purpose of removing them, the Mayor not only did not anticipate public opinion, but he acceded very tardily to its demands.

When the final maps of sections 2, 3, and 4 for the street improvement of the annexed district were approved by the Board of Street Opening and Improvements under Mayor Gilroy the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company objected to the laying out of streets on its property between East One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street, Beengay Street, and the East River.

A song recital was given by Miss Carlotta Desvignes, contralto, assisted by Mlle. Flavie Van den Hende, 'cello, in the Waldorf ballroom, yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, before a large number of society people. The following programme was rendered:
KINGSTON, N.Y., April 5. -- In the New-York Methodist Conference nine members were advanced to Elders' orders.

PATERSON, N.J., April 5. -- The people of this city have discovered a gigantic fraud in the registry lists for the election Tuesday. The fraud is in the Sixth Ward, where 300 names have been fraudulently placed upon the list.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., April 5. -- The Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference, at its annual session at Bethel Church this morning, proceeded with routine business and listened to appeals for aid for the various church societies and benevolences. The attendance was the largest of the session.
KINGSTON, N.Y., April 5. -- In the New-York Methodist Conference nine members were advanced to Elders' orders.

The joint Senate and Assembly committee appointed to investigate the various State departments in this city resumed its hearing at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday morning. Those of the committee present were Senator Higgins, Chairman; Senator Smelzer, and Assemblyman Cutler. The inquiry into the department of gas meter inspection was taken up.

BERLIN, April 6. -- The dispute between France and England regarding the upper Nile region is watched here with the keenest interest. Nothing since the Anglo-Belgian agreement and the Emperor's interference to frustrate it has caused such general comment among the colonial enthusiasts throughout the Empire.

Yachtsmen are going to have a busy season this year. The racing will begin earlier than ever before, and last until October. Owing to the different yacht clubs on the Sound having arranged a racing schedule there will be more opportunities for a man owning a racing yacht to race this year, because each club has certain dates exclusively for its own use.

LONDON, April 6. -- [Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.] -- Such sober people as kept their heads during the abominable distractions of the week have been much graver over the question of relations with France than I have known Englishmen to be over anything else for these past eleven years.

Within a fortnight Richard Mansfield will be established as a theatre manager in this city, and will have entered upon a new stage of his career. It has long been Mr. Mansfield's ambition to control a New-York theatre, where he could properly produce good plays and afford occasionally to make those experiments in his art which are too costly for the peripatetic star.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., April 6. -- The Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference at Bethel Church opened to-day with another discussion of the case of Samuel O. Rusby, a candidate for full admission as a member of the conference whom the Qualifications Committee would not pass because, it is alleged, he is neither fair of face or form.

PETERSBURG, Va., April 6. -- Gen. William Mahone, ex-United States Senator, Chairman of the Republican State Committee of Virginia, and all-around politician of national fame, to-day made an assignment here for the benefit of certain creditors. These preferences amount to about $81,000.

A few days ago placards were posted on the advertising stations of Berlin, on which was an invitation to all the cripples in the German capital to communicate with a certain gentleman and state their circumstances. It was added that the advertiser proposed to give assistance in deserving cases.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 6. -- The Rev. M. L. Gates, the retiring pastor of Grace Methodist Church, started for Boston this morning, carrying in a satchel $300, which he had collected for a religious enterprise in that city in which he is interested.
LONDON, April 6. -- According to the latest foreign advices, Belgium, both diplomatically and practically, will support France in her claims in the Upper Nile Valley.
If it is not too late, I would like to add a few words in regard to a training school for help, which has been discussed for the past few weeks through the columns of your paper.

BOSTON, April 6. -- The recent gift by Judge Mellen Chamberlain to the Boston Public Library of a collection of autographs which he has been engaged in collecting since he was eighteen years of age, and which has been his pastime for more than fifty years, is one of the largest and most important benefactions which this institution has received.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 6. -- A magnificent rain fell throughout Kansas and Missouri to-day, assuring the planting of a huge crop of corn.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- For months there have been three vacancies in the Quartermaster's Department of the army, and the candidates, of whom there are several hundred from among the junior army officers, are restless and impatient over the delay in filling these positions. Within a month there will be another vacancy, the fourth in the list, caused by the retirement of Col. J.D. Bingham, stationed at Chicago, Ill.

The twenty-seventh annual games of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association were held in the armory, Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue, last night. The big armory was, of course, crowded, as it always is, when the athletes of the Seventh gave a public exhibition. Lieut. Schuyler, who is the President of the association, says that there were 6,000 persons in the armory.

Lieut. Gov. Saxton, in his address before the Logan Club, in Brooklyn, Friday night, said he would not consent to "wear a collar" of a boss, whether it fitted him or not. As reported in The Brooklyn Eagle, the Lieutenant Governor said:

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The ordnance experts of the navy are giving attention to the specifications for armor plates and appurtenances. These specifications are to form the basis for the proposals which will be asked some time hence from the Carnegie Steel Company and the Bethlehem Iron Works, the only two firms in this country which car furnish armor plate.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The publication by a Chicago newspaper this morning of what purports to be the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the income tax case is but an amplification of reports which have been current in Washington for more than a week.

In a case before a Paris court, in which a popular actress has had to appear as a witness, the Judge seems to have shown considerable diffidence about asking the lady, as he was in duty bound to do, what was her age. Evidently he considered that such a question, put to a witness, would be a direct incitement to perjury, so he asked her her age before she had been sworn.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- In regard to the press dispatches from San Francisco, stating that it had been found that the gold coins of the Carson Mint for several years past were below the standard of fineness, as provided by law, Mr. Preston, the Director of the Mint, stated to-day that this was not true.

I have been much interested in your articles upon domestic service and have hoped that some of your correspondents would have described what seem to me the difficulties and mistakes we struggle with in this country.

A somewhat impressive illustration of how a "double standard" can be trusted to work is given in a report made by Mr. George Horton, the United States Consul at Athens, and recently published by the State Department.

The new building that is to be erected by the Bar Association will not be a clubhouse, in the general acceptance of the term. It is to be equipped with all the adjuncts of the best clubhouses, but is to be constructed first with the object of giving to the members of the Bar Association an appropriate place for thought and study.
Having read with great interest the discussion in your paper about the servant question, I cannot resist the temptation to send you a few lines.

The reconstruction of the Tammany Society, of Columbian Order, which many prophesied after the defeat of the Tammany political organization of last November, will probably be not very much of a reconstruction after all. The thirteen Sachems of the society control it absolutely.

Three years ago, says The London Spectator, the obituary of the last giraffe in England was printed. There was then good reason to believe that with the extinction of the herd of English-bred giraffes, which had been maintained successfully since 1836, the animal would remain for some time unknown by sight to the London public, whose pets they had been for half a century.
May I be permitted to call attention in your columns to a charity which deserves to be brought prominently to the notice of philanthropic people in New-York?
HAVANA, April 6. -- The Autonomist Party has issued a manifesto directed to the Cuban public strongly condemning the uresent revolt. The manifesto says:

Harriet Beecher Stowe was one of the very first American women to pay tribute to humor. Her offering was Topsy, that wooly-headed classic, who has been translated into more languages than any other character of fiction. It was Topsy who said: "I wasn't born. I growed." Topsy will never die.
TRENTON, N.J., April -- Industrial stagnation, hard times in fact, may accomplish more in closing saloons than did the Citizens' Moral Crusade.
The College of the City of New-York and the New-York University teams played a game of baseball on University Heights yesterday, the University, winning easily. The score:

For the first time in several weeks the Saturday market was not buoyant. Traders were inclined to take profits where in sight, and there was a general indisposition to do anything pending the decision of the United States Supreme Court on the income tax. London prices were almost on parity with New-York, and there was little or no arbitrage trading.

RED BANK, N.J., April 6. -- One of the oldest religious societies in Monmouth County is the First Methodist Epsicopal Church of Red Bank. The society was born at Little Silver in 1786, and it was several years later before the organization had its headquarters at Red Bank. The first Methodist sermon was preached by a Mr. Van Dyke, who lived here.
There was a sensational episode on Beacon Street last night, or, to be accurate, at about 1 A. M.

The official reports indicate that cholera will prevail in Europe during the coming warm season as it did last year. The threatening sources of infection are Russia, Galicia, and Turkey, where the disease has been present throughout the Winter. There has been no cholera in Belgium since the last week of November; three cases were reported in Germany in the last three weeks of December, and seven in Holland on Dec. 8.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6. -- The franchise which was granted to the New-York and Philadelphia Traction Company was secured as part of a system that will cover about 600 miles of road, which is fairly under way. It is estimated that the building necessary to comply with the franchise will cost almost $10,000,000. The electric railway is to span the State, with its terminal points at New-York and Philadelphia.

The young baseball men of Yale crossed bats with New-York's lusty Giants, at the Polo Ground yesterday, and took some of the wird out of the Leaguers' sails. So far as the actual score goes, the sons of Old Eli were beaten, but during the major part of the game the students played fully as well as their professional brethren, despite the fact that they have had no Southern training.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- A season of systematic practical instruction for the army will shortly be announced. The period will probably extend from April or May until November, during which military exercises will be held. Special attention will be given to tactical drill, attendance upon which will be exacted of all physically competent soldiers.

The author of this novel has the gift of contrivance and the skill to sustain the interest of a plot through all its development. "The Mermaid" is an odd and interesting story. The scene is laid partly on the northeastern point of Prince Edward Island and partly still further northward among the rocks and quicksands of the wind-swept Magdalens.

Some of the wiseacres were nonplused early during the past week by the announcement that the southwest corner of Nassau and Liberty Streets, covered with old five-story brick buildings, had been sold to a syndicate, represented by Messrs. Lamb Rich, the architects, for $1,250,000. The price paid seemed so large to some, that they straightway said there must be a mistake about it.
The lives of several hundred passengers were placed in jeopardy last night between 7 and 8 o'clock by a collision between the ferryboats Whitehall and Montauk, both of the Hamilton Avenue line.

Although it comes after the works of Guizot, Carlyle, and Ranke on the same subject, Gardiner's History of the Commonwealth and Protectorate is indispensable to students. While full of extended details, it is never uninteresting; and, although as impartial as the sun, does not make one eclectic enough to praise and blame Cromwell and Charles II. alternately.

Dr. Charles A. Eastman, the full-blooded Sioux Indian who startled the country a few years ago by taking unto himself a wife from among the prominent whites, Miss Elain Goodale, and of whom it was subsequently rumored that he ran away from her to return to his own people, is an intelligent and agreeable young man of some thirty-odd years.

The magniture of cycling as a pastime is hard to grasp in these end-of-the-century days, when one is told that "everybody" is now a wheelman. Within the last five years the popular craze has extended to all civilized countries on the face of the globe, and it has yet to reach the pinnacle of its prosperity.

James Pyle Sons are the owners of the handsome and towering warehouse now approaching completion on the northwest corner of Washington and Charlton Streets. Designed by Architect Thomas R. Jackson, it has been erected in the most substantial manner by Builder Hugh Getty of No. 274 Ninth Avenue, who is well known in connection with construction work of the first class.
LONDON, April 6. -- The Central News correspondent in Shanghai states the conditions of peace proposed by Japan.

Mr. Balfour, the Conservative leader in the House of Commons, has recently published a very interesting and able book on "The Foundations of Belief." It would be unfair to characterize a work of such importance in a brief statement, but it is not unfair to say that he seeks to demonstrate that sentiment has much more to do in determining the ideas which we call beliefs than has the reason.

It rather looks as if the market had had its rise, and that it will be dull and lower for a while. There is nothing to cause a serious break in prices, and very much to prevent it; but for all that, appearances indicate that the bulls will have to wait a little, and start their next rise from a lower than the present level.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 6. -- Under the auspices of the King's Daughters Charles F. Underhill is giving a series of recitals in the Casino. The first was given Thursday evening. It was Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream." The others will be as follows: April 22, Charles Dickens's "David Copperfield"; May 2. Sheridan's great comedy, "The Rivals."

It is satisfactory to observe that the French Government is dealing with the questions between England and France in Africa in a much more dignified as well as in a much more amicable spirit than the French press. We have already commented upon the extraordinary effusion of Anglophobia that was permitted to itself by a journal of so high standing as the Temps.
WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The old Lancaster is again to be placed in commission.

The present and ever-increasing interest in national and local history makes especially timely the publication of the appended correspondence between Washington's headquarters at Harlem Heights in 1776 and the new State Government, or "convention," as it was called, then sitting at Fishkill.
Here is the account given by an English weekly of the terrible embarrassment caused by the United States Government to the unfortunate European powers:

Dr. Chauncey M. Depew, during his recent visit to Chicago, followed his usual custom of taking close note of the drift of matters in the political and business world. On his way home he stopped in Albany and took further observations.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 6. -- The announcement that Robert P. Porter has acquired a controlling interest in The World has caused little surprise in Ohio political circles, though it is regarded as extremely significant.

Bridget Williamson was brought before Justice Taintor, in the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday charged with having passed a fifty-dollar Confederate bill on John Hughes, a bartender in the saloon 305 Spring Street. Mrs. Williamson was arrested by Court Officer Hunt on a warrant.

Please permit me to express my admiration for the masterly setting forth of the domestic servant girl question in The Sunday Times, and, among the many important facts and thoughts evolved, to especially commend those of Mrs. Spencer Trask. It seems to me that she has gone more completely to the root of the whole matter, and that it would be well if her letter could be read by every well-meaning housewife in our land.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 6. -- Now that Easter is but one week away, the hotel managers look back over a Lenten season marked by almost unprecedented success, and, following the old-time rule of judging the Spring months by the days preceding Easter, compare their booking lists for the days to come with those of the time just past with the utmost satisfaction.

Ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower and J.K. Terry have brought suit against the Long Island City and its Commissioners of Improvement to enjoin further proceedings with a contract to pave and grade Borden Avenue, on the ground that the action of the Commissioners was illegal.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Sir George Baden-Powell's intended inquiry as to whether the British Government will refuse to join in the conference suggested by the United States in regard to the seal fisheries question, bears reference to a dispatch which Secretary Gresham addressed to Sir Julian Pauncefote on Jan 23.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 6. -- Lehigh opened the baseball season by defeating Columbia 21 to 12. Stewart, the crack pitcher of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, was in the box for Columbia, and Lehigh hit him at will, getting 19 safe hits. Nevins pitched for Lehigh during the first five innings, old had Columbia at his mercy.
Anthony McHugh Cannon, a leading citizen of Spokane, Washington, was found dead in his room at the Sturtevant House shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Death was due to heart disease.

Awarding prizes is a thankless task and one involving no little trouble. So many considerations of which the public is not aware enter into the matter to influence judgment. Then, too, after some years, no small proportion of the artists become ineligible, either passing the age limit or from having already obtained the distinction.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Notwithstanding the expressed opinion of State Department and British officials that nothing but peace may come from the Venezuelan boundary dispute, those familiar with the temper of the Venezuelan Government and people declare that Venezuela will go to war if Great Britain retains its present attitude and refuses to submit to arbitration the right to the territory which Venezuela claims has been usurped by British Guiana.
TRENTON, April 6. -- The State Fish and Game Commissioners will hold weekly meetings to put the fish and game laws into effect.

The revolution in Europe in 1848 drove so many poor Jewish refugees to this country that several organizations were formed here to aid them. Most of them were in destitute condition, and strangers to the language and usages of the country whose protection they sought.

PARIS, March 15. -- It is really very hard to please these people. M. Felix Faure and his family have been working from early morn till after the evening dinner with receptions and balls in the service of the republic; or perhaps, I had better say, to make the Government seem nearer and dearer to the people.

The eight persons against whom indictments were handed up by the Extraordinary Grand Jury on Friday surrendered themselves to the police yesterday morning and were taken to the District Attorney's office, where bail was entered for their appearance to plead to the indictments.

When the sun came out after that short shower yesterday afternoon the cyclists flocked to the popular paths by the hundreds. A small party of both lady and gentlemen members of the Michaux Cycle Club was in the parade, setting toward Grant's tomb, going up the Boulevard. The Michauxs extended the usual run to the West End Hotel, at which they tarried for a short time before making the return run.

SPA SPRINGS, N.J., April 6. -- The strikers at the terra cotta works resorted to no violence to-day. Sheriff Servian notified Gov. Werts early in the morning that he thought he would be able to prevent lawlessness by the dissatisfied workmen. The report that troops were to be called out spread among the workmen, and had a very perceptible effect.

A bill has passed one branch of the Connecticut Legislature prohibiting the placing of advertisements on trees, rocks, and structures without the owner's consent. Persons of taste and sensibility who have occasion to ride through the State of Connecticut on railroad trains, and to have the atrocious disfigurement of what ought to be pleasing landscapes constantly thrust upon their vision, will fervently desire that the Legislature go further than this mild prohibition.

NEWPORT, April 6. -- The Navy Small-Arm-Board will reconvene at the torpedo station Monday, April 15. It will be the third time the board has met for the examination of inventors' patterns in the hope of selecting a worthy small arm for the navy. Each time some new guns have been shown, and old ones once examined have been presented again, improved.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., April 6. -- Regardless of a cold and penetrating southeasterly wind that swept across the Wheatley and Jericho hills with great velocity to-day, the Meadow Brook Hunt Club participated in a ten-mile run across country. The hunt party met at Wheatley Pond, opposite the country seat of E.D. Morgan, ex-Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club.

WASHINTON, April 6. -- Consul General Ramon Williams of Havana has sent to the State Department a remarkable argument against the continuance of Spanish rule in Cuba and in favor of tariff independence.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6. -- The Massachusetts mill committee closed its week of inspecting Southern cotton mills by visiting the mill districts at Columbia, S.C., and Augusta, Ga. The committee continues to find very much that is interesting and instructive. Each day the Eastern mill owners appreciate better the conditions in the South, and there is perfect freedom among them in admitting the businesslike appearance of the mills in the Southern territory.

The indictment of Messrs. Clausen, Straus, and Tappen for their participation in the spending of a special appropriation of $1,000,000 raises several serious questions. Of course, they are not indicted for being in the wrong about the speedway, but they are indicted for an offense which does not seem to be much more properly within the purview of the Penal Code.

The Assembly Committee appointed to investigate the sweating system and the employment of women and children in factories and stores, had its fourth session yesterday in Part II. of the Superior Court. The committee consists of P.W. Reinhard, Jr., Chairman; Seth Wilkes, Harvey T. Andrews, Charles Steinberg, and Jacob Kunzeman.

The United States Consul at Chemnitz has been much impressed with the important place which drawing holds in the schools of Germany, and has summarized the results of his observations in a report which has just been published by the State Department.
Shad have begun to run up the North River, and within a few days they will be plentiful in the markets.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Secretary Herbert has an interesting question before him. A recent act of Congress for the reimbursement of officers who have suffered loss by shipwreck, provides that the reimbursement shall be confined to articles regarded by the naval regulations as necessary and proper for an officer to carry at sea.

At a children's party where the guests and hostess were of very tender age low tables were spread at which the small chairs of kindergarten height were comfortable seats. The bouillon was served in small cups and slim Vienna fingers were handed around with it; delicate chicken sandwiches followed, with some clear fruit jelly.
The signs of Spring are growing daily more pronounced in the City of Churches.

ORANGE, N.J., April 6. -- The hopes of the Greater Orange advocates are becoming stronger daily, and they are now looking forward with confidence to a consolidation of the Oranges into one large city. They declare that the discussion of the subject, largely through the columns of The New-York Times, has resulted very much in their favor, and that the more it is agitated the more converts they make.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 6. -- Mrs. Benjamin Carter and the Misses Carter gave a tea at their home, in Park Street, Wednesday. Those who assisted in receiving were Miss Alice Carter, Miss Grace Miller, Miss Walker, and the Misses Howell.

After reading a chapter or two in this book, one cannot resist an impulse to turn back to the title page for another look at the date it bears. The figures are there, plain enough -- 1895 -- but for all that Mr. Gibbs has chosen to write his "history" as though it were for publication forty or fifty years ago.

CAIRO, Feb. 22. -- A low-lying coast, marked here and there by a solitary tower or a group of palm trees; a sea of turquois blue, shading off to sapphire in the distance or suddenly dashing into white as it charges against the long breakwater, and, finally, a tall pharos rising against the sky and Pompey's Pillar challenging the eye from afar.

Jack Winthrop and Bessie, his wife, are two nice and highly sentimental people, who live in a Paradise, not in Mesopotamia, but California. Bessie has a cousin Helen, a rather enthusiastic young woman, who has made a wretched marriage. Her husband was that young Spaniard Jose de Santa Yberri.

Mr. Frederic Villiers, in his letter printed in your issue of April 3, courteously offers to me the last word. If this is the last word in the controversy, it seems proper that I should sum up as briefly as possible the matters at issue and the points made.

In compiling a life of John Addington Symonds from the letters, journals, and papers that he left behind him, his literary executor, Mr. Horatio Brown, has had every possible chance afforded him of carrying out the scheme, evidently dear to his heart, of reconstructing for the wide public the brilliant, attractive, and noble personality of his friend.

BOSTON, April 6. -- Like the movement to remodel and refit the Jubilee, a movement to form a syndicate for a new cup defender has come to grief. Just who was in the syndicate does not appear, but Sidney Burgess, brother of the late Edward Burgess, was to furnish the design. The matter progressed so far as the asking for estimates from a leading builder, but it has now apparently been dropped.

OGUNQUIT, Me., April 6. -- "Hearn 'em talkin' over to Kennebunk yist'day abaout a reverlution here in Ameriky. They was a feller from Bosting over there, an' he said they wan't no daoubt on't. 'Comin' sure's taxes,' says he. 'The people's gittin' madder'n madder every day,' says he; 'fust thing you know they'll tip things t'other side up an' start a Gover'munt of their own.'
ALBANY, April 6. -- A charity edition of The Argus will be published April 18 by the women of Albany, the proprietors of that paper having generously offered it to them for one issue.

The endowing of churches and institutions is not such an uncommon occurrence as to cause surprise or comment, unless the sum be a large one. But it is out of the ordinary to have a large sum of money settled upon a man for the purpose of enabling him to devote his life to study unembarrassed by the necessity of supporting his family.

William Markham, retired capitalist, lived at North Point, on the Sound, in as comfortable an antique castle as could be simulated out of good modern wood and brick and stone. An antique castle it was to its owner and to the neighboring folk, none the less so for its materials or because electricity, steam, and running water were substitutes for rushlights, peat, and dirt.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn filed, in the City Clerk's office, yesterday, among others, a veto of a resolution adopted by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen in regard to electric lighting specifications. The resolution adopted by the Aldermen made possible the charging of different rates for different locations.
" Ein fur Alle und Alle fur Einen" is the motto of the local league of German warriors who have organized under the title of "Deutscher Krieger-Bund, New-York."

Col. Andrew Hannibal Humboldt Dawson, whose aviary was attended with such touching fidelity while Mrs. Letitia Kreizer was unmarried, as set forth by the Colonel in The New-York Times of yesterday, appeared before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Superior Court at the morning session yesterday, in connection with the Kreizer separation case.

The Sportsman's Association announces that the first exhibition will be held in Madison Square Garden May 13 to 18, inclusive. The officers of the association are President -- Charles Tatham; Vice Presidents -- Jacob H. Studer and Charles Daly; Treasurer -- J.A.H. Dressel; Secretary -- Frederic S. Webster; Assistant Secretary -- Harry Palmer; Frank W. Sanger, Manager Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The cause of irrigation in this country is being rapidly advanced, and it is believed that thousands of acres of the arid regions of the West will be reclaimed in the present year.

GLASGOW, March 26. -- The racing in the Mediterranean has done wonderful service for the ports where the racing took place, into which tides of visitors have carried more money than the inhabitants have ever before fingered. But yacht racing has not benefited much, and until the two French yacht clubs sink their differences in the matters of measurement and time allowance, no very satisfactory results are likely to be reached.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 6. -- The Village Trustees last night directed the local bill poster to tear down bills of a New-York museum representing a dozen stout women, attired in tights, engaged in a bicycle race, and it was done to-day.

HOT SPRINGS, N.C., April 6. -- High up among the pine-clad mountain peaks of the Blue Ridge in the "Land of the Sky" is Hot Springs fast becoming known as one of the most delightful all-the-year-round resorts in the United States. It is only within the last half-dozen years that the reputation of these springs has been much more than Southern and local.

At his home, in Greenville, Penn., in a shop to which is attached a testing gallery sixty feet in length, the Rev. John Peate, D.D., is preparing to fashion the speculum of the great telescope for the American University -- an institution of the Methodist Episcopal Church, now taking to itself a local habitation on the heights near the national capital.

It is the ambition of every Brooklyn girl after graduating from the public schools to enter the Girls' High School, where she may enjoy the advantages of advanced education, and be prepared for college or for more immediate concerns of life.

The English version of "Mme. Sans Gene," as presented by Kathryn Kidder and Augustus Pitou's company at the Broadway Theatre, has proved one of the greatest successes of the present theatrical season in New-York. The engagement came to an end last night, and Manager T. Henry French had a pleasant surprise in store for the players.

Morningside Heights and Washington Heights together form the most attractive part of the city to anybody who is seeking a home that is somewhat suburban in its characteristics. The possibilities of the region are greater, perhaps, than of any other part of the city, but its development depends almost entirely upon the solution of the rapid-transit question.
Jesse N. Gregory, the longshoreman who shot and killed his wife, Clara, Thursday evening in the tenement house 423 Eighth Avenue, almost succeeded in taking his own life before he was arrested.

Miss Edith M. Thomas has in one of the April magazines a poem entitled "The Compass." It is a work of much literary merit, but people who have really seen the instrument in question are likely to wonder whence the talented singer drew her information about its construction and idiosyncrasies.

Perhaps in "Sport Royal" may be found the germ of that clever romance of Mr. Anthony Hope's, "The Prisoner of Zenda." With maturer powers, in the latter story the author has expanded incidents and accentuated characters. What Mr. Hope has is a Dumas way of conceiving things, given clearly with action, and a snap with a click to his dialogue.

Fire was discovered early yesterday morning in the rear of the residence of J. Harry Adams, in Bay Thirty-second Street, near Bath Avenue, Bensonhurst. Liberty Hose Company of Bath was the first to respond to an alarm. It secured the only hydrant in the vicinity, and, after attaching its hose, ascertained that it was short about one length.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 6. -- Prof. Edward W. Scripture of the Yale University Psychological Department, in describing the new apparatus called the pendulum chronoscope, otherwise known as the pendulum timer, said yesterday to a New-York Times representative: "We have often heard the phrase, 'quick as thought.'

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Gen. John G. Farnsworth of Albany, N.Y., died at his rooms at the Arlington Hotel, this city, tonight at 9:20 o'clock, from the effects of a stroke of paralysis, superinduced by heart disease.

A resumption of the argument in the Noyes-Dana libel case, in which Judge Addison Brown of the United States District Court is asked to grant a warrant for the removal of the editor of The New-York Sun to Washington, D.C., for the purpose of trial, took place yesterday.

With the coming of April the horse racers end their long vacation, and it is only a question of a few days when the sulkies will be whirling as merrily as ever. The tracks at Lexington, Baltimore, and even Philadelphia, are in shape for fast work before the courses in this vicinity can be made ready.

There is probably not going to be much trouble with Venezuela over the ultimatum. President Crespo will write a check just before the clock strikes, even as his predecessor, Senor Don Guzman Blanco, had to do when a British war ship looked into La Guayra and wanted 10,000 and the crew of the English trader whom Guzman had speculatively locked up in his rotunda.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Cushing is likely to have a new commanding officer. Lieut. F.R. Fletcher, who has been in command of the torpedo boat since December, 1892, will probably be detailed to a larger ship.

TACOMA, Washington, April 6. -- News has just reached here that Great Britain, not content with raising a boundary dispute by which it hopes to acquire a portion of the most valuable part of Alaska, including Juneau, the chief city, has begun active steps looking to the opening of a highway from the coast toward the rich and almost undeveloped gold field of the Yukon.

Central Office detectives are said to be looking for a person named Charles B. Bennett, alias "Skinny" Bennett, alias Marks. They say they know him well, and that his picture is in the Rogues' Gallery. He has been arrested, they state, for picking pockets in this and other cities.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 6. -- In the southern suburbs of this city stands a large brick mansion which many years ago was the home of the Patti family. There Adelina Patti spent her earlier years.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 7. -- With a total registration of 5,335 in this city, the indications are that strenuous efforts will be made to poll an unusually heavy vote at the charter election Tuesday. While the race for Mayor between three candidates is important, candidates for Councilmen are doing the most real work.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 7. -- Thomas S. Shaw, alias Ralph F. St. John, stepped into the Wyoming National Bank on Friday last and asked the cashier if he could open an account with them. On being informed that the bank was open for business, he went on to say that he had $2,500 on deposit in the Central National Bank of New-York, and would like to make a draft for that amount.

PETERSBURG, April 7. -- It is believed here that one effect of Gen. Mahone's financial embarrassment will be to complete his downfall as a politician in this State and the South. He had the ambition to lead next year the Southern delegates to the Republican National Convention and control them for his favorite Presidential candidate.

The roll-off for second place in the Harlem Republican Club tournament between Lotus, Winsor I., and New-York I., took place at the Harlem Republic Club Alleys, West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, Saturday night. Lotus team defeated Winsor I. by the score of 912 to 837 in the first game. The second game resulted in a victory for Winsor I., over New-York I. by 17 pins. New-York II. team captured first prize,

Aside from the depravity that it has been necessary to make public in the downfall of Oscar Wilde, people who met him here, and accepted his letters of introduction as an accredited English gentleman, are curious to know something of his family, his mother, his wife, his children, and almost everybody else upon whom he has brought absolute ruin.

Anthony M. Cannon of Spokane, who died suddenly at the Sturtevant House Saturday, figured in an incident in St. Paul which was a part of a series of mysteries which have never been solved. The story was told yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times.

The Trustees of Scenic and Historic Places and Objects, as told in The New-York Times, effected an organization Saturday at the office of Andrew H. Green, under the incorporating law, which is Chapter 166 of the Laws of 1893.

Easter examinations being over, the absorbing subject among the students of Stevens is the lacrosse situation of 1895, and the chances of their team retaining the championship. On April 15, one week before college opens, the candidates will return to Hoboken for the beginning of the regular training, which will continue every day that week at the

ITHACA, N.Y., April 7. -- On their return from the brief Spring recess, the students were saddened by news of the death of Prof. James Edward Oliver, head of the department of mathematics, who had been ill at his home here since January. Prof. Oliver was one of the oldest and most beloved teachers in the university, and was generally recognized as the foremost American scholar in the field of pure mathematics.

WICHITA, Kan., April. -- Walter Scott shot and killed his wife in the entrance of the Christian Church at noon to-day, and then placed the pistol in his mouth and fired a blast into his brain. Both died instantly. Scott was twenty-one years old and his wife nineteen.

There is still the most urgent call for assistance by the people of drought-stricken Nebraska. Attention has repeatedly been called in The New-York Times to the necessity of providing these sufferers with food, clothing, and seed for several months. They will be helpless until new crops are gathered, and new crops cannot be had unless seed is furnished.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Following is an abstract of the reports made to the Controller of the Currency, showing the condition of the national banks of the United States at the close of business on March 5:

Curiously varied and extremely uneven, the exhibition of the Academy of Design this Spring presents, nevertheless, many interesting pictures. Some of these are hung skyward, and others are not infrequently passed by because of the company they are obliged perforce to keep. A greater number, too, than usual are of large proportions.

Braunschweig, capital of the Duchy of Braunschweig, possesses an institution with a long name. It is a society called Zwangversittlichungverein, and the object of this society is to make men and women modest and moral whether they will or won't. At present it is concerning itself with children.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 7. -- Brit Glenn, commonly known as "Kid Charlie," a negro gambler and desperado, killed two men this morning and wounded three, one of them probably fatally.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 7. -- The prospectus of elective courses in the academic department in Yale University was given out yesterday. The "preliminary choice" of former years is done away with, and students will make their final choice of studies for next year by April 27. The requirements in junior and senior years remain unchanged, seniors selecting one of four philosophical courses.

The vote that was taken recently in the House of Commons in favor of paying salaries to members of that body is not conclusive, but it comes much nearer to being so than the House has ever come before. The payment of individual members already takes place in a limited number of cases where the member claims it on the ground that he cannot afford to give his whole time to his public duties.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 7. -- The decision rendered by the Supreme Court yesterday, sustaining the ruling of the Cowley County District Court, which convicted Anderson Gray of the murder of Thomas Patton, although Thomas McDonald acknowledged to having committed the deed, closes one of the most extraordinary cases ever brought before a court of justice, and for the first time admits that hypnotism is a defense for murder.

It has been erroneously assumed by many people that the late M. Worth was the first man milliner of European reputation. This is a mistake, as has been pointed out by a learned writer in The Eclair. The first man milliner of whom history takes notice was Rhomberg, who became famous in Paris in the reign of Louis XV. He was the son of a Bavarian peasant.
GLASGOW, April 7. -- The United Press correspondent had an interview to-day with a Clyde boatbuilder who stands very near Mr. Watson, the yacht designer.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.

A bridge policeman last night picked up a calico dress which was tied in a bundle and lying on the New-York extension of the bridge. He unfolded the garment and found in one of the pockets a note that read:

CAMBRIDGE, April 7. -- The annual junior dinner at Harvard is the only class gathering of a social nature in undergraduate life. In fact, it is often said that there is no class spirit at Harvard. The class of '96, however, rather dispelled this illusion by the spirit and success of its dinner on Thursday. Over 200 men were present, and three large dining rooms at the Vendome were thrown into one to hold them.

-- The Brooklyn Chess Club held its monthly reception on Saturday night. Edward Hymes, the intercollegiate champion, was billed to give a simultaneous exhibition against all-comers, but not enough club members were on hand or willing to encounter the visitor. Two consultation games were then arranged, Messrs. Ruth, Broughton, and Morphy taking one board and Messrs. Sauweine and Breckinridge taking the other against Hymes. In the latter game, a

BAYONNE, N.J., April 7. -- Diedrich H. Garbs, a saloon keeper at East Twenty-second Street and Van Buskirk Road, Constable Hook, Bayonne, was severely stabbed with a jack-knife in the hands of Patrick Sheehan, a next-door neighbor, this morning. Garbs will die.

RICHMOND, Va., April 7. -- Judge Edmund Waddill, the trustee named in the assignment deed, says that Gen. Mahone intended to secure certain debts he owed in preference to others he considered he did not owe, and for which he was being sued. Judge Waddill says he does not consider Gen. Mahone insolvent by any means.

Police Justice Deuel, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday had an opportunity to test the operation of a measure that was drafted by him, and that became a law and went into effect last Friday. This enactment gives to Police Justices the power to dispose of simple violations of corporation ordinances on the first arraignment of the prisoner.

The Engineering and Mining Journal has received an important communication from Prof. Charles Olszewski concerning his experiments in the liquefaction of gases. It would seem that Prof. Dewar, who has been so frequently quoted in connection with the liquefaction of gases, has merely followed the experiments made by Prof. Olszewski and the credit which has been given to the former is not due him.

There is an ailment to which politicians in the United States, above a certain grade, are peculiarly liable. It is developed particularly among those who have attained a sufficient prominence to be "mentioned" by their friends or by themselves as Presidential candidates. We do not know that it has ever been classified scientifically, but in the world of workers and office seekers it is known as "the big head."

Three counties in Pennsylvania are up in arms against a mutilation of their fair proportions, as proposed in a measure before the State Legislature called the Monongahela County bill. Some persons, whom the indignant citizens call "county-seat boomers," propose, by taking parts of Westmoreland, Washington, and Fayette Counties, to form a new county of the name given in the bill.

NEWPORT, N.J., April 7. -- A grand raid on the riparian oyster beds is thought to be contemplated by the Captains of the piratical oyster boats, as arrangements are quietly going on aboard the boats for a concerted move. The fighting riparian have laid in 1,600 rounds of ammunition, and are doing duty night and day on Fortescue Beach.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 7. -- Steps were taken here yesterday toward the organization of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union Point o' Woods Building Association, for the purpose of constructing a women's building at the Point o' Woods.

LONDON, April 7. -- The Central News correspondent in Tokio says that the stories about the killing of the wounded at the battle of Tien-Chwang emanated exclusively from Chinese sources. The Japanese maintain that the wounded were treated by them with the customary humanity. A dispatch was sent from Hiroshima to Lieut. Gen. Nodzu, Commander of the Japanese troops in Manchuna, briefly stating the accusations and requesting an explanation.

Elaborate services were held in the Protestant Episcopal and Roman Catholic Churches of the city yesterday, the day being Palm Sunday, commemorative of the entry of the Saviour into Jerusalem. In all the churches at the close of the services pieces of palm were distributed to the congregations.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Senor Joaquin Bernardo Calvo, Charqe d'Affaires of Costa Rica, requests the United Press to state in the most emphatic manner that the expedition of the Cuban revolutionist. Gen. Maceo, who is stated to have effected a landing in Cuba, did not start from Costa Rica, as that Government is energetic and vigilant in preventing any abuse of its territory by the organization of hostile expeditions against friendly powers.
The Academy of Music, Montague Street, Brooklyn, was crowded last night when the Rev. Cortland Myer delivered a sermon on "Workingwomen."

CAMBRIDGE, April 7. -- Another radical change in the order of the 'Varsity crew has been sprung by Mr. Watson. This new order is said to be permanent, but the same rumor has accompanied every shaking up of the crew.

The latest great strike, or, more properly, lock-out, that of the boot and shoe makers, is fortunately lacking in most of the sentimental attributes which go to confuse judgment in such matters. The shoe trade has been brought to a standstill, and many thousands of workmen thrown into idleness, in order that a strictly technical dispute may be fought out between masters and men.

The police of Denbighshire are a graceless and irreverent lot. One of their number at Wrexham lately spied a chimney on fire at the residence of Mr. W. Wynn Evans, and straightway took out a summons for the offense. If Mr. Evans had been an ordinary citizen this would have been a proper proceeding.

Although the weather yesterday was not propitious for the popular pastime, the devotees of cycling turned out by the thousands and were seen a-wheel from early morning until long after sunset. Longer runs than have before been taken by club parties this season were enjoyed, the destinations of the pedalers covering almost every point of the compass within a radius of thirty miles of City Hall.
