SALT LAKE, Utah, April 18. -- A bitter and prolonged struggle took place in the Constitutional Convention yesterday on the subject of taxing the outputs of mines and improvements thereon. Members from the mineral and agricultural districts discussed the question with a great deal of heat, but it was finally decided that the provision allowing such a tax should stand.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Gov. Morton's pacificatory dinner at the Executive Mansion last night, to the Republican Senators, was not an overflowing success. Senator Reynolds, whose presence was absolutely essential to the success of the entertainment, failed to accept the invitation.

Col. David C. Austen, who sent in his resignation as Colonel of the Thirteenth Regiment a few days ago, has, according to a statement made yesterday, commanded the regiment for the last time. The Colonel said that after some thirty-five years of service in the National Guard, he thought he was warranted in taking a rest.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Prof. Otto Lugger of the University of Minnesota is in Washington consulting with the authorities at the Agricultural Department with regard to an extensive line of work he has just begun in Minnesota, in accordance with the provisions of an appropriation made by the Legislature of that State.

THURSDAY -- P.M. The course of the stock market to-day leaves no room for doubt that bullish sentiment is steadily growing. The stock market not only broadened materially, but the business in bonds was large and well distributed. There was a slight recession shortly after the opening, but for the remainder of the day trading was done at advancing prices, and as a rule the final sales were at the highest figures of the day.
Gen. Anson G. McCook made good his right to be designated as "one of the fighting McCooks" at the meeting of the Republican County Committee last night.
Perhaps never prior to this Winter have New-Yorkers had so many exhibitions of ancient pictures of the various schools, nor has the demand for the earlier men's work ever before been so great.

CHOCAGO, April 18. -- A Special from Columbus, Ohio, says: "Judge Stevenson Burke yesterday filed his answer in the suit against him and his associates to recover $8,000,000 on Columbus, Hocking Valley, and Toledo Railroad bonds, claimed to have been appropriated to the defendants own use.

The successive phases of the boycott of the Seaboard Air Line by the railroads comprising the Southern Railway and Steamship Company is exciting much interest in Southern territory. The fight has become exceedingly bitter, and it affects both freight and passenger business.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19. -- The second 1,000 horse-power engine of the Consolidated Traction Company was set in motion at the River Street power house yesterday afternoon. An additional 1,575 amperes of electricity was thus placed at the command of the managers to distribute where they chose in operating cars either in Newark or Jersey City.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, April 19. -- The New-Jersey chapters of the Daughters of the American Revolution held a social meeting at the Mansion House, this city, to-day, the anniversary of the battle of Lexington.
CHICAGO, April 19. -- The organization which it is believed will quiet the free-coinage movement in Illinois will be formed to-morrow at the Palmer House. It will be styled the Honest-Money League.

The author of that clever romance, "A Superfluous Woman," in "Transition" shows again somewhat the same melancholic tendency. Those mental distinctions existing between the sexes the writer of "Transition" clearly depicts. "There are two things women must conquer," says Honora.
The special meeting of the Dock Board, which was announced Thursday and which was held yesterday, resulted in the dismissal of 378 employes of the department.

Yesterday was "Primrose Day" in England, being the anniversary of the death of Lord Beaconsfield in 1881. The celebration of it would naturally direct attention to the nature and value of the public services which have induced more than a million Britons, of both sexes, to embody themselves in a "Primrose League."

LONDON, April 19. -- The Times has the English text of the Pope's recent apostolic letter to the English people. The letter fills three columns. In it the Pope said he greatly desired to address to the English people a special letter and thus give them a token of his sincere affection. He wished keenly that some effort of his might tend to further the great work of bringing about the reunion of Christendom.
Police Captain Rhodes of the Manhattan Avenue Precinct, Brooklyn, is mystified over a trolley accident which the police have not reported to him.
PANAMA, via Galveston, April 19. -- Jorge Isaacs, a celebrated author of the Republic of Colombia, and in poliitcs an eminent Liberal, died at Ibague, in the Department of Cauca, yesterday.

FRIDAY -- P.M. Local traders worked for a reaction today, but London was such a persistent buyer that their efforts were only successful to a very limited extent. The volume of business was somewhat smaller than yesterday, both in stocks and bonds, and the demand for investment issues was still remarkably good. There was some irregularity during the day, but the market closed steady, with many of the active specialties higher than on Thursday.

The announcement by Justice Jackson that his health is improving and that if the income tax law is to be reargued he will resume his place on the bench and take part in the proceeding goes far toward making the reargument a certainty. It secures a full court, and that is practically the only condition to taking up the matter again.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Secretary Morton, when asked in regard to the press dispatches from Chicago to the effect that his agitation on the subject of high prices has led to reduced consumption of beef, and a consequent break in the markets for live stock, said that, so far as had been learned, there had been no break in the price of beef.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Two workmen were instantly killed, three others were fatally injured, one of whom is dead, and one seriously hurt by the fall of a great derrick to-day in the yards of the South Chicago Shipbuilding Company. Three others were hurt about the head and arms, but were able to walk to their homes.

The row in the Republican camp is becoming grotesque. Not only are the factions in this city growing more bitter against each other every day, but the G.O.P. in the State is likewise showing a tendency to split in two, even as it did in the days of Half Breeds and Stalwarts.
The Beard of Officers of the Seventy-first Regiment is still after Frederick B. Carey, who is charged with having pocketed certain sums of money that should have gone to the regiment.
No audit was made yesterday in the Finance Department of the disputed livery bill presented by Col. Waring of the Street-Cleaning Department.

LONDON, April 19. -- A Central News dispatch from Seoul, under to-day's date, says that a plot has been discovered to dethrone the King of Corea in favor of his nephew, Li Shun Yon. The conspirators, including Li Shun Yon, were promptly arrested.
ROME, April 19. -- The Cabinet is discussing a proposal to hold the Parliamentary elections on May 19.

The author of this volume dedicates his book to the boy who wants to become a bloodthirsty pirate, to every man who "still believes in buried treasure," and to a general public, which thirsts for "tall fights and reckless adventure." With this dedicatory preface, at once Owen Rhoscomyl pitches in, and you have a succession of combats, where the fighting takes place either between single individuals or between packs of assorted assailants.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 19. -- The Spanish Club gave a banquet in Armas Square last evening to the 750 troops that recently arrived from Spain. The soldiers were served at table by local volunteers. An enormous crowd gathered in the square and cheered throughout the meal.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 19. -- It is not yet six months since the Democratic Party in the Empire State met with a defeat so overwhelming and complete that its immediate effect was to impress even the most hopeful members of the party with the fear that the reverse could not be retrieved in years.

The Veteran Association of the Seventh Regiment gave its annual dinner at Delmonico's last night, in celebration of the seventy-first anniversary of the formation of the regiment and the thirty-fourth anniversary of the departure of the regiment to the war, in 1861. In the absence of Col. Henry W.T. Mall, the commandant of the veterans, who was unable to be present, owing to illness, Major W.B. Coughtry presided.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 19. - Capt. Blish and Dr. Iredell of this city have laid out the course for The New-York Times tri-State relay bicycle race between New-York and Philadelphia on this relay. It commences at a point about two miles from Franklin Park, at a place called Woodlawn, and ends at the first telegraph pole this side of Wheatsheaf, on St. George's Road from Rahway to Elizabeth.

The popular Riverside Wheelmen did themselves proud last evening at a large gathering of their friends at Jaeger's, in Madison Avenue, near Fifty-ninth Street. The occasion was the club's inaugural entertainment and reception, and in every detail the affair was a flattering success. It began with the stage entertainment and wound up with a dance and collation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 19. -- The Westchester County Republican Committee held a meeting this morning in the parlors of the Orawaupum Hotel here for the purpose of discussing the action, or inaction, of the Senator and Assemblymen representing this county in the Legislature at Albany.
ALBANY, April 19. -- Gov. Morton has approved:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 19. -- An extensive series of robberies, by which the Erie Railroad has suffered for nearly a year, was unearthed in this city to-day. It is estimated that the losses will exceed $15,000, and very probably go as high as $25,000.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 19. -- Oyster pirates are causing much trouble on the grounds off Malinecock Point, in Long Island Sound, and trouble is anticipated.

The case of Oliver Curtis Perry, the recaptured train robber, came up before Judge Lippincott at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, in the Jersey City Court House. Perry hobbled into court, hand-cuffed to a policeman. His feet are still sore from the effects of his journeying from the Matteawan Criminal Insane Asylum without shoes.

BOSTON, April 19. -- The League season was opened at the South End Grounds this afternoon with a larger attendance than has ushered in the season for a number of years. Fully 15,000 people crowded the grounds. Several thousand stood up in the outfields, making a ground rule of two bases on a hit into the crowd necessary. The game was delayed thirty-five minutes in consequence of the rush on the field.

If the Mikado of Japan should decide to visit Pekin for the purpose of discussing with the Emperor of China the project of an alliance between the two countries, this journey would prove, even more conclusively than anything that has yet happened, the dawn of a new era in the East.

" Stare decisis et non quieta movere" is a maxim of great age, and in its time has been used to defend more abuses and to prevent more reforms than any other illogical argument ever invented by gods or men. Its ingenuity is truly infernal, and by confounding conclusions with premises, it gives pig-headed obstinacy numberless opportunities to pose as wise conversatism.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Patriots' Day, the anniversary of the battle of Lexington, was generally observed in the State to-day, although not in so elaborate a manner as it was last year, when the holiday was legally commemorated for the first time.

Much indignation was expressed yesterday by those who have been prominently identified with the movement to secure cheaper telephone service in this city because of the summary killing of the measure recently introduced in the Legislature to bring about a reduction in the rates now charged.

The twenty-rater Isolde, built by the Herreshoffs for Prince Leopold of Germany, arrived at the Hamburg- American Steamship Company's docks at Hoboken yesterday morning in tow of the steamer Archer. Everything was ready for her reception at the docks, and it was not long before she was hoisted out of the water and set in the cradle built for her on the deck of the steamship Russia.

The Fire Commissioners were in secret session for nearly three hours yesterday afternoon, and during the meeting the charges that members of the department had been asked to contribute to a corruption fund of $45,000 to promote the passage of bills for increasing their pay were discussed. These charges are what an investigating committee of the Senate will begin to consider this morning.

Mr. Moore passes in review all the fads of the day -- musical, artistic, scientific, historic, and social -- and has a sharp word to say about them all. The romance is essentially a clever one, for the author is full of resources. There are bits of "They call it love" to be found in many pages of the romance which would be worthy of quotation.

" Please, I have my mother with me, and I don't know what to do with her." said a small voice at the entrance to the general assembly room on the upper floor of Grammar School No. 77, at First Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The Associate Alumnae of Barnard College held a well-attended meeting in its interest last night, at the college rooms, 343 Madison Avenue. The purpose of the meeting was to arouse wider interest in the project of securing $100,000 to complete the purchase of a site adjacent to the new grounds of Columbia College, on Morningside Heights.
BORDENTOWN, N.J., April 19. -- Mrs. Delia T.S. Parnell, mother of the late Charles Stewart Parnell, was assaulted last night by highwaymen, and robbed of a small sum of money.
Mr. James A. Hayden has bought the four-story and basement Ohio stone dwelling 5 East Forty-seventh Street, 23 by 65 by 100, at about $75,000.

The Government of the Russian Empire has taken another step toward the legal recognition of the gold standard and the resumption of specie payments at such time as may be found practicable. A decree has been unanimously approved by the Council of the empire authorizing commercial transactions of every kind to be concluded on a gold basis.

ALBANY, April 19. -- When the House met a question arose on concurring in the Senate amendment to the Tobin dressed-stone law. This amendment exempts crushed stone from the kinds of stone that must be dressed in this State. Mr. Cutler said the Hudson River Counties between Poughkeepsie and New-York were much interested in having the crushed stone industry included within the provisions of the bill.

" First catch your hare!" is falsely attributed, as we know to-day, to the compiler of a famous cook book. In Mr. Tom Brand's case it is "First catch your Prince," and then marry him to your daughter. Tom Brand is an intensely coarse and vulgar millionaire, and wants a position in society.

ALBANY, April 19. -- If the Senate follows to the end the plan adoptey to-day, a dragnet investigation will be instituted that will certainly expose the methods by which certain bills have been passed and other bills held up, ventilate the workings of the lobby, and blacken the reputations of many persons.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- After the quietest Lent that the Capital City has known in years, the Spring season started off this week with a round of weddings, dances, and teas that kept people busy.

The following letter in the original is in the possession of Mr. George N. Steinman and is of historic interest, in that it gives about the best short account of the famous battle of New-Orleans we have ever seen, and so we publish it for the benefit of all who are interested in historical subjects: CAMP 5 MILES BELOW NEW-ORLEANS.

And so Rorke could find no satisfactory solution of the ever-vexing question. Twice or thrice he accosted Graice and strove to draw him into talk, but the newcomer seemed to shut up like an oyster in the presence of the Irish Corporal, and was surly and defiant in manner, a great contrast to the joviality he displayed when soliciting comrades to take a hand at cards.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Gov. Morton to-day listened to an appeal for a respite for Dr. Robert W. Buchanan. George W. Gibbons and Theodore M. Roche appeared in behalf of the doomed man, and made a brief plea.
ORANGE, N.J., April 20 -- There was a successful cake sale at the home of Mrs. Francis A. Gill, in Main Street, East Orange, to-day, for the benefit of the Orphan Home.

ALBANY, April 20. -- The pilgrimage of the Old Guard of New-York to this city on Monday next, to attend divine services in All Saints Cathedral, on the anniversary of its organization, will serve a twofold purpose.

HAVERHILL, Mass., April 20. -- The five-year old daughter of E.L. Hall, residing at Riverside, whily playing "Indians" with companions to-day, was horribly burned about the head, and it is feared she will die. She was selected as the victim to be burned at the stake, and was tied hand and foot to a pole; her playmates piled a lot of combustible material about her feet and set it on fire.
Assistant Fire Marshal Demalignon is making a searching investigation in connection with two mysterious fires which occurred yesterday afternoon in the cellar of 225 West Forty-second Street.

The Columbia College sophomores completely overwhelmed the freshmen in the interclass competitions at Columbia Oval, William's Brodge, yesterday morning. S.H. Bijur, '97, covered himself with glory by scoring 25 points. Summaries:

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The officers in charge of the National Museum have in view a system of exhibits which has, to a limited extent, been adopted. An effort is making to preserve, as far as possible, the identity of many animals which are rapidly becoming extinct. Among these are the buffalo, the walrus, the fur seal, and several smaller animals of this and other countries.

The contentions in the ranks of the local Republicans are becoming more bitter every day. With increasing chagrin the followers of the Platt faction are claiming that the local administration is using its position to build up the anti-Platt faction.

Those public school teachers who joined in the protest against the passage of the bill for reorganizing the educational system of this city have unfortunately placed themselves in an unfavorable light before the public. To any one familiar with the schools and their administration, the protest itself bore on its face evidence of the need of the proposed reform, and the reply of the subcommittee of the Committee of Seventy very easily exposes its flimsiness.

The deadly Brooklyn trolley system added another victim to its list yesterday, and 107 is now the record. The latest victim is Charles G. Evans, a young and enthusiastic bicyclist, who lived with his parents at 640 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn.

Giacomo Zizzo awaits the coming of a Guillaume de Loris to sing the story of his heart's woe. None but a poet whose pen could indite the tale as de Loris told that of unhappy Heloise and miserable Abelard could do Giacomo's suffering justice.

Brick manufacturers and dealers in building materials look with hope to a revival of the building industry in this city this year. There are several large buildings already in process of construction, and considerable rebuilding and the conversion of residences into fiats are expected. And this notwithstanding the fact that a good many old buildings are said to be in the market for less than it would cost to erect new edifices.

DOVER, Del., April 20. -- Addicks was the gainer in to-day's Senatorial ballot, and his followers were highly elated. Once more six votes are placed in his column, and his claims are that the total will be still further increased when the final breakup of the Higgins forces occurs. To-day he corraled Representative Money, a hitherto Higgins man.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Receiver McNulta expects to get a large sum of money for the Whisky Trust on account of the recent rise in the price of beef. According to the contract with Nelson Morris for feeding cattle, Morris says he will equally divide the net profits resulting from the cattle fed, which exceeds $8 per head.
ORANGE, N.J., April 20. -- The eleventh annual exhibition of the Orange Art Association was opened in the studio in Cleveland Street, to-day. The exhibits are well arranged and grouped.

TRENTON, N.J., April 20. -- Lewis Parker prominent in Masonic circles, and Secretary of the Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows, was one of the many Freemasons who visited the Holy Land and held a special session of the Masonic Lodge in the King Solomon quarries. There were thirty-four Master Masons in the party, and they have just returned home.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 20. -- The close of Lent was marked in this city by the giving of a charming reception Monday afternoon by Mrs. E.B. Clark of Crescent Avenue, to introduce her two daughters, Miss Clark and Miss Bertha McCullough Clark. The house was elaborately decorated with beautiful Easter lilies, white roses, and smilax.

A certain honest farmer, one R. Lane, of Wilmcote, near Stratford-on-Avon, asks me to notify as many Shakespeare enthusiasts as possible, that the old Mary Arden house, at Wilmcote, is now open to the public. As he is offering a convenience that will be much appreciated by Shakespeare pilgrims, I think you might run him a line in The Times.

SING SING, April 20. -- Warden Sage of Sing Sing Prison received word from Albany this afternoon that the Governor had refused to grant a respite to Dr. R.W. Buchanan, and that the sentence of the court must be carried out.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 20. -- Among the cottagers in town this week were Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. W.S. Wells, Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. White, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Burden, Mrs. Shepard Homans, Mrs. John G. Heckscher, John R. Caswell, and John H. Glover.

United States Commissioner John A. Shields completed his fortieth year in the service of the Federal Government yesterday. He entered the service as an office boy on April 20, 1855, and rose by successive stages to his present important position.

According to information yielded with more or less reluctance by certain men who attended the meeting of bar-iron manufacturers in the Weddell House on Friday an organization for mutual protection was formed which will be known as the Merchant Bar-Iron Association, and will embrace nearly all bar-iron mills west of the Alleghanies.

PATERSON, N.J., April 20. -- A daring robbery was perpetrated yesterday at the home of Thomas Smith, at Singac, by which two thieves secured nearly $2,000. Smith is a section boss on the Lackawanna Railroad, and lives with his age wife on the Preakness Road

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- About 4,000 persons attended the opening of Franklin Field, the new athletic grounds of the University of Pennsylvania, to-day, and witnessed the best day's track sport ever held in Philadelphia. Much to the disappointment of the Red and Blue followers, the relay race between Harvard and Pennsylvania resulted in an easy victory for the Crimson lads.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The news from Honolulu received to-day relative to Minister Thurston has served to intensify curiosity regarding the outcome of the alleged difficulty between that gentleman and Secretary Gresham which led to Mr. Thurston's hurried departure from Washington.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 20. -- Superintendent H.E. Allison of the Matteawan Asylum for Insane Criminals says that he cannot understand why the convicts who recently escaped from that institution should receive so much sympathy from the public.

BERLIN, April 20. -- The Chinese Government has concluded a loan for 30,000,000 marks at 6 per cent. interest with a syndicate composed of the National Bank fuer Deutschland, Heydt Co., and Behrens Sons of Hamburg.
The investigation by the Senate Judiciary Committee of what is known as the Goff bill came to an abrupt conclusion yesterday.

The trouble with American health seems to be that the stock transplanted from Europe is doing twice as much work here in climate half as favorable. The lung food of the two continents comes from opposite extremes. The air of Western Europe has floated thousands of miles from exuberant tropics and over the soft, tonic waters of the Gulf Stream.

HONOLULU, April 13, via San Francisco, April 20. -- Minister L.A. Thurston arrived this morning, in company with Finance Minister Damon. Mr. Thurston said that no change whatever had taken place in his official relations with Secretary Gresham, and that he knew of no foundation for newspaper statements on that subject.

The two Collectors of Internal Revenue for the City of New-York seem to adopt rather different attitudes toward the question of what the law may require of them in regard to the assessment of the income tax. Collector Sullivan of the Second District carefully refrains thus far from committing himself to any particular course of action toward those who withheld their returns beyond the 15th of April, following the advice of their lawyers.

Cyclists who ride on the Grand Boulevard and other busy city thoroughfares should take warning through the death of Robert Center. This gentleman's untimely end was the direct result of speeding with the body low over the handlebars. In this position his head was necessarily low, making it impossible to see far in front without an extra effort in throwing back the head.

The Trustees of the Lenox Library have issued their twenty-fifth annual report, which shows the condition of the library, of the funds and other property of the corporation, and its receipts and expenditures during the year 1894.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Officers' Lyceum, as a means of keeping army officers informed on professional matters, will be continued another season. The opposition which it has met at some of the posts has received no consideration at the War Department.

During the last few years the proportion of families who own their own homes has been increased, owing to the multiplication of building and loan associations. It is no longer necessary that a man should be possessed of a snug capital before he can transform himself from a tenant into a householder.
The eighth weekly session of the Assembly committee which is investigating the sweating system of New-York was held yesterday in Part II. of the Superior Court.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 20. -- An interesting meeting of the Women's Town Improvement Association was held in the High School Hall yesterday afternoon.

Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald, President of the State Lunacy Commission, is very strongly of the opinion that Oliver Curtis Perry is a lunatic of the most troublesome variety Incidentally Dr. MacDonald disapproves of the criticisms that have been made concerning the management of the criminal asylum at Matteawan.
" I certainly expect," said a Brooklyn woman, "that if ever I go to heaven I shall find my dog standing at the gates wagging his golden tail to welcome me."

The semi-annual meeting of the Mount Holyoke Alumnae Association was held yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The morning session began at 11 o'clock, when the following officers for the ensuing year were elected:

Comparatively few cyclists of the metropolis are aware of the amount of ferriage to which a man with a wheel is taxed upon leaving Manhattan Island. Questions on this subject crop up every day, and not one wheelman in five hundred can tell the fee for a person and a bicycle by this or that route.

SATURDAY -- P.M. Prices continued to improve in to-day's stock market. There was some weakness shortly after the opening, owing to realizing on profits, but the market took all offerings so readily that the traders became active purchasers about 11 o'clock, and from that time on the general list was quite buoyant.

It has been settled that the new Board of Sachems of the Tammany Society or Columbian Order will ask ex-Recorder Frederick Smyth to be Grand Sachem, and, from an excellent authority, it was learned yesterday that he would accept:

The new volume of Mr. McMaster's history covers the period from 1812 to 1820. It deals with the war of 1812, recounts the naval victories, describes the negotiations for peace, the commercial distresses and progress of that period, treats of the Seminole war, and of the settlement of the West. Emigration westward then depended upon the general condition of the people.

The dimensions of the spars for the new cup defender that are being made in Boston, and of the sails that have been ordered of Wilson Silsbe of Boston, as printed exclusively in The New-York Times on Friday, have been the chief topic of conversation among yachtsmen since then. The length of the spars show that the new boat is to have an enormous sail spread, and consequently great driving power.

TRENTON April 20. -- The Mercer County Wheelmen held a successful reception on Wednesday night in the large Masonic Hall. A few weeks ago they gave a pink tea that continued for a week and brought the young people of the town together, and since they have occupied their elegant new clubhouse on East State Street they have given a number of ladies' nights that were society affairs.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- The control of The Times-Herald and Evening Post passed into the hands of Herman H. Kohlsaat, formerly publisher of The Inter-Ocean, this afternoon, and he assumed charge of the consolidated journal to-night.

It is easy to be seen why Russia resents the terms of peace arrived at between China and Japan. Her disappointment is freely expressed in the Russian journals. Some of these journals suggest that Russia shall seize Manchuria, as far as the mountains, and part of Corea with Port Lazareff, "as compensation for the gains of Japan." Others suggest a European conference to compel the moderation of the Japanese terms.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 20. -- Pennsylvania outplayed and outfielded Lehigh here this afternoon, and won, 23 to 4. Lehigh men played like schoolboys, and seemed to have no idea of what they were doing. Both sides batted well. The score:
WILLET'S POINT, L.I., April 20. -- "Halt! Advance and give the countersign!"
Opposition to the so-called Compromise Educational bill is being actively waged by the school teachers of this city, who are working energetically to secure its defeat in the State Senate.

The trade in the large markets was somewhat brisker yesterday than it was Friday. A number of dealers, however, complained of the lightness of the demand for beef and other meats. Some of the fish dealers also admitted that trade was rather duller than it should be at this time of the year.

Last Thursday morning an editorial in The Times directed attention to the fact that within ten days there had been a rise in the prices of wheat, cotton, and petroleum, that is, "in our chief article of food product, our chief raw material exported, and one of our chief manufactured exports." It was further pointed out that the advance in each had extended to the European markets.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The American Minister to Chile has informed the State Department that the Chilean Congress, before adjourning in February, enacted legislation guaranteeing the capital of the Transandine Railway Company for twenty years, at 4 1/2 per cent., which insures the completion of the road between the two oceans from Valparaiso to Buenos Ayres.

The silver jubilee of the New-York Maennerchor will be celebrated at the society's hall, 207 East Fifty-sixth Street, to-night and to-morrow. Preparations for elaborate festivities have been in the hands of various committees for some weeks, and the outlook is that the event will be a memorable one.

Unusually interesting, the exhibition of the American Art Association at its galleries, in Twenty-third Street, offers peculiar opportunities for the study of the latest movement in France of the men of the impressionistic school, for one entire floor is devoted to their canvases.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt were here this week inspecting their new villa, which has taken the place of The Breakers, which, with all its contents, was destroyed by fire three years ago. The new house is a veritable palace, and in the matter of cost and general appointment is said to outrank any private Summer residence in the world.

Chauncey M. Depew was the guest last evening of the Montauk Club in Brooklyn, the occasion being the annual celebration by the club of his birthday. Mr. Depew will be sixty-one years old on Tuesday. This is the fourth year the Montauk Club has celebrated Mr. Depew's natal day.

" I think it was quite a triumph," said Mrs. Russell Sage, when asked by a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, what she thought of the passage by the State Senate of the Assembly concurrent resolution submitting to the people a constitutional amendment providing for woman suffrage.

Duse, the great Italian actress, is to come to this country again, next season, after all. Many American managers have been trying to secure her since her artistic success on her former visit and it has been accepted as pretty certain that the Rosenfeld Brothers, her former managers here, would be the winners in the race.

No doubt "Puddin'head Wilson" is the play of last week that will have the longest life and, in the end, the greatest fame. It is not a particularly good play, speaking according to rule, for it is absurdly ill made, and full of superfluous stuff. Who are the twins, anyway, and why did they go to Dawson?
ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 20. -- The Rev. Howard T. Widdemer, the supply of the First Presbyterian Church, preached his last sermon last Sunday morning, and the church is now without a pastor.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 20. -- The farce-comedy entitled "I Have Written to Brown" was produced in the Summit Casino on Thursday evening by amateurs, for the benefit of the Fresh-Air and Convalescent Home. The characters were assumed by Miss Elizabeth Smith, Miss Flagg, Walker Marcus Dennett, E.P. Hicks, B. Vivien White, and W.F. Callender, Tableaus preceded the farce.

If it were possible, without causing discomfort or perturbation, to penetrate the cranium of a newly-hatched chick, expose its brain and clearly read thereon its emotions and impressions at the moment it steps out of its shell into a sunlit world, we might find paralleled the emotions and impressions of those dear, miserable sinners who, on Sunday last, stepped out of the shell of forty days' retirement.

ORANGE, N.J., April 20. -- Chief Consul Robert Gentle of Elizabeth and Secretary J.C. Tattersall of Trenton, of the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, have just sent out a new lot of application and renewal membership blanks. At the top of the renewal blank it reads: "Renew your membership and then secure one new member with the attached application blank."

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Reliable advices from Tokio, Japan, received to-day, say that the attempted assassination of Li Hung Chang was not the act of a madman, as published in Japanese newspapers, but the result of a widespread and premeditated conspiracy, the publication of which was suppressed by the Government.

As the time for the closing of the Spring renting season approaches, the results appear to be less satisfactory than were hoped for. This condition was foreshadowed in the columns of The New-York Times several weeks ago. It applies especially to offices, dwellings, and the more expensive flats. Stores have in general been well rented Concessions have been made to good tenants of dwellings and offices, to prevent their moving.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 20. -- A number of women here interested in the success of a "people's room" searched among the old residents of the town for curious and quaint things, and held an exhibition of them last evening in the upper rooms of the People's Building, on Main Street.

With the first leaves of Spring begins the annual renovation of the local tennis courts. This year the players in New-York and Brooklyn have lost no time in getting to work, and play has already begun on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, which of late has been coming to the front, and is now recognized as the leader, even in the matter of fixing the date for beginning outdoor play.

It was early in the year 1861 that Jerry Oakley, a boy only nine years old, was tied hard and fast to the bedpost all day to keep him from volunteering his services to the Confederate Army. But Jerry was a determined little man, and when the Dixie Guards reached Richmond, Va., Jerry was one of the number.

Appraiser Bunn received yesterday from Louis H. Todd, who brought charges of undervaluation against Sypher Co., dealers in antiques and curios, papers purporting to be private invoices on imports of silverware by the firm. At the time of these imports the bullion price of silver in England was 4s. 6d. an ounce.

The Senate committee appointed to investigate the charges made in The Press concerning the raising of a corruption fund, said to have amounted to $45,000, to promote the passage of the bill for increasing the pay of New-York firemen, and connecting the names of Senators Raines, Coggeshall, and Robertson with the charges of bribery, held a session yesterday in the courtroom of Part III. of the Court of General Sessions.

A terrific explosion occurred on the steam yacht Reva, at Morris Dock, Harlem River, at 10:45 o'clock yesterday morning, and the entire upper works and cabins of the vessel were blown to pieces, the fragments being scattered around to a distance of 100 feet in all directions.

In the issues of April 7 and 14 The Times published the first and second installments of the remarkable correspondence between Washington's Headquarters at the Roger Morris Mansion, on Harlem Heights, in 1776, and the Revolutionary Government of the new State of New-York, or "Convention,'' then sitting at Fishkill-on-the-Hudson.

The officers of the National Shoe and Leather Bank, at Broadway and Chambers Street, for robbing which of more than $350,000 Samuel C. Seely is serving a term in prison, stated yesterday that under the old management of the institution Seely's brother-in-law, Samuel E. Aymar, robbed it of $20,000.

By a vigorous use of their bats in three innings yesterday, the New-Yorks, won a game from their rivals, the Brooklyns. For a time the boys from across the bridge looked like winners, and their followers were shouting themselves hoarse, hopeful of a second victory over the Temple Cup winners, but they were doomed to disappointment.

BOSTON, Mass., April 20. -- The liabilities and assets of the Baldwin Brothers Company, brokers, who assigned yesterday have not yet been ascertained. The collapse of this company, however, will be felt over all New-England. Its business, amounting to millions of dollars every year, was larger than that of any other similar firm, with one exception.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 20. -- One of the familiar figures about West Point this last Winter has been an elderly, gentleman, with soldierly bearing, seen most frequently in his walks to and from the library. Col. T.C. Tupper, a veteran of the civil war, now on the retired list, comes from old colonial stock.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 20. -- There are two entertainments given annually at the Military Academy by the cadets. One takes place in August, and is known as the "Color Line"; the other is held in Grant Hall 100 days before June, and is called the "Hundredth Night." The color line entertainment always attracts hosts of visitors.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 20. -- Every interest now is centered upon outdoor life. Nature has done her share in sending good weather and an abundance of fragrant arbutus. The pink and white wild flowers, with the starlike pixie blossoms, are thought ample reward for many a long walk and careful search among the brown leaves.
Two charges were made yesterday against the official honesty of Col. George E. Waring, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, by Gen. Egbert L. Viele.

The public prints have been full for the past three years of accounts of the developments in the study of tuberculosis, and, in particular, of the demonstration beyond a doubt of its contagious character, and papers have been read before many audiences on the same subject, yet with startling distinctness there come constantly evidences of how little the leaven has really worked.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The President has reason to be gratified with the response to his recent letter urging action in the interest of an honest currency. Already the South is interested, and the sound money convention, to be held in Nashville May 23, will undoubtedly mark the beginning of a campaign against the free coinage heresy, which will continue until the close of the Presidential campaign of 1896.

Our London cable letter informs us of an innovation in the settlement of strikes which has its suggestions for us as well as for the English. By the agreement adopted, "labor troubles" in the trade concerned are henceforth to be submitted to the arbitration of an impartial and official body, and each side is to make a deposit of money, to be forfeited if it fails to abide by the decision of the arbitrators.

Most admirable in both letter and spirit is the circular issued by the Treasury Department to Customs Inspectors in connection with the new rule authorizing the landing after sunset of steamship passengers. It defines with exactness the object of baggage inspection, and at the same time gives these officials some thoroughly good advice on the proper way to perform their annoying but necessary duties.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Further proof has been elicited here that the charges made against Mrs. Francis Spranger of this city and her husband, a physician of Detroit, have no foundation in fact.

Those who look upon opera as an art and not as a mere pastime must have felt a shock on the night of Tuesday last, when so much splendid talent was wasted on the heartless music of Meyerbeer in "Les Huguenots." The change from a time of good opera and bad singing to one of good singing and bad opera was too abrupt.

LONDON, April 20. -- [Copyright, 1895, by The New-York Times.] -- There is still a complete and baffling uncertainty as to what is to come out of the situation in the far East. The London Foreign Office never gossips, and now it is more severely buttoned up than ever. On the Continent there is much more fluent expression of opinions, but these are all obviously speculation.
The cornerstone of the new Montauk Theatre, on Fulton Street, near Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, was laid with appropriate exercises at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

At the hundredth anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, yesterday, the Rev. Dr. J.H. Rylance, the rector, preached an interesting historical sermon, taking for his text Genesis, xxviii, 1S-19: "And Jacob took the stone that he had put for his pillow and poured oil upon the top of it.
ALBANY, April 21. -- The following has been given out from the office of the Secretary of State:

A woman, familiarly known in certain localities in Thompson and Sullivan Streets as Alice Welsh, was fatally stabbed early yesterday morning. She was found unconscious just before 6 o'clock in the hallway of 143 Thompson Street, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where she died five hours later.
GREENVILLE, Ala., April 21. -- Five negroes were lynched here last night.

If the Japan-China treaty be correctly reported -- and of this we can judge in a short time now, when it shall have been formally ratified -- its commercial provisions will be of great and increasing importance to the Western world. They are of a very enlightened character, and are calculated to put to shame nearly all the Occidental nations who have heretofore regarded themselves as incomparably superior to the Japanese.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 21. -- Paul Fenimore Cooper, son of the novelist, died here tonight of paralysis, aged seventy years.

MONDAY -- A.M. The stock market continued to improve, both in the volume of business done and in prices. The activity and buoyancy extended to the bond market, where the business for the week was heavier than in any other week for more than a year. Over $14,000,000 in par value changed hands.

HOBOKEN, N.J., April 21. -- College opens again on Monday, April 22, and the Hoboken merchants will once more have cause to rejoice. Easter being late this year, the third term will be necessarily short, and the students severely taxed to satisfactorily fulfil the requirements. The new engine presented to the electrical laboratory by the class of '95 has arrived, and will be ready for use within another week.

Some months since we called the attention of our readers to an open letter addressed by Mr. Wharton Barker to Gov. McKinley. The writer addressed the Governor, "because," he said, "you stand in the front rank among those who should lead in times of public peril, (and these are times of great public peril,) and you should therefore tell your countrymen what you believe they should do at such times.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 21. -- There is considerable stir in this State to-day, occasioned by the announcement that Dr. Sampson Pope and J.F.J. Caldwell, appearing before Judge Goff of the United States Circuit Court, at Clarksburg, West Va., had secured a temporary injunction in the case of Dunbar vs. the State Board of Control and F.M. Mixson, Commissioner, which, if made permanent, practically destroys the effect of the dispensary law.
Prof. Felix Adler delivered a lecture on "The Ten Commandments" before the Society for Ethical Culture, at Carnegie Music Hall, yesterday morning.

One week ago we published a list of the manufacturing companies which had increased the wages of their employes in the two or three weeks immediately preceding. We are able this morning to make some interesting additions to this list. In order that the extent of this significant movement may be clearly seen, we republish below the names of the companies or firms which have made the increases mentioned heretofore:
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 21. -- Senator Isham G. Harris gave out to-day for publication the following:

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 21. -- The mills will resume operations to-morrow morning under the scale of wages in operation previous to Aug. 20, 1894. Twenty-four thousand workers will be benefited. There is every prospect of a fair trade during the coming Summer, as the mills are now fairly well sold ahead.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 21. -- It has been suggested by some of the leaders of the Connecticut Democracy that the Connecticut Democrats should take some stand on the financial question as outlined in President Cleveland's letter to the Chicago business men. In discussing the matter to-day, ex-Gov. Luzon B. Morris said:

BERLIN, April 21. -- Trustworthy dispatches from St. Petersburg say that the Standard Oil Company and the Russian oil producers have perfected their agreement, which now awaits the Finance Minister's sanction before becoming operative. The public shares largely the excitement of speculators in oil. Every scrap of news regarding the Russo-American negotiations has been snapped up eagerly and spread conspicuously on the front pages of newspapers throughout the empire.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21. -- The Essex County Wheelmen held their annual run to New-Brunswick to-day. The start was made from Military Park at 8 o'clock this morning. A large contingent of the Harlem Wheelmen of New-York came over on the 7 o'clock train, and were escorted from the station to the park by a committee from the club.

PORT LIMON, Costa Rica, March 28. -- Owing to the strict censorship exercised by Colombia, but very little news is received here regarding the revolution in the neighboring republic. Any news unfavorable to the Caro or Government party is suppressed, while all cable and telegraph lines are under constant Government control, and all messages are vised by Government officials.

BERLIN, April 21. -- Inquiries at the Imperial Yacht Club in Kiel have elicited the statement that the list of entries for the Kiel regatta next June is still incomplete. The list will be held open until June 8. Among the yachts already entered are the Emperor's Meteor, the Prince of Schaumburg-Lippe's Varuna, Prince Henry's Irene, and the Lais, Mucke, and Carina.

The Sultan has probably made up his mind that there has been a massacre. Also that it will not do to have the massacre repeated. Similar conclusions have also been reached apparently by the representatives of the European powers charged with the duty of keeping the Sultan and his Ministry within bounds.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- A report received at the Department of State from D.W. Maratta, United States Consul at Melbourne, Australia, shows that during the year 1894 there were produced in Australia, Tasmania, and New-Zealand 2,195,848 ounces of gold and 1,115,318 ounces of silver. During the same year silver lead and silver ore was raised valued at $10,683,617.

The announcement from Richmond, Va., that entries for the Spring meeting there close Tuesday, and that the sulkies will be lined up in battle array just a week later, is a reminder that the campaign for the harness racers is very close at hand. To the trainers in this section and throughout the New-England States the invitation to the capital of the Old Dominion possesses no attractions.

Cycle racing enthusiasts in this State, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania are wide awake to the fact that The New-York Times's 150-mile team relay contest to Philadelphia gives promise of being one of the greatest road events of the year. During the last eight days the larger part of the course has been remeasured, and by this evening the entire distance will have been covered by experts appointed to attend to this important work.

TRENTON, N.J., April 21. -- The Senate investigating committee was obliged last week to damage greatly the reputation of the Republican Party by forcing Head Clerk Joseph D. Hulme of the State Treasurer's office on the stand and getting from him a confession of evildoing. The committee did not wish to take up the charges, made against Hulme, because it meant Republican disgrace.

The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the New-York Maennerchor was begun last night with a superb concert and a few agreeable surprises. The musical programme which Musical Director Heinrich Bauer arranged contained an unusual amount of novelties, interspersed with some standard compositions.

In selecting the New-York and the Columbia to join temporarily the San Francisco and the Marblehead, our regular vessels on the European station, in the coming pageant at Kiel, Secretary Herbert supplies an ample and more than ample representation of our navy for that display.

The Rev. Dr. Louis Albert Banks delivered the first of a series of discourses on "The Saloon Keeper's Ledger" in the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, on Sunday evening, the special theme being "The Saloon Debtor to Disease."

I saw in your paper to-day an account of a lecture delivered at Columbia College by Mr. Sever, Instructor of Electricity at that college, in which it was stated that all attempts at storage battery traction hitherto made were failures.

An Irish correspondent of The London Spectator writes to inform the readers of that paper that the English papers seem to have missed the real point of that horrible chapter in the history of superstition -- the murder of Mrs. Cleary in the County of Tipperary. She did not fall a victim to the belief in witchcraft or in demoniacal possession -- neither has any real hold in Ireland.

Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt was "at home" to his usual Sunday callers at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday. One or two who have not called regularly this session were among the number, and, while one or two of the regular coterie were absent, the new-corners were of sufficient importance to lead to the comment that "the usual talent" was there.

OIL CITY, Penn., April 21. -- Forest fires have been raging in this neighborhood for two days, and considerable valuable timber has been destroyed. In may cases the fires have started by accident, but in one case the fire was started by an incendiary.

Far up among the hills of Westchester County, where stone walls and oak trees abound, away from the railroad, almost as far from the world as if it lay in one the Territories, there is the little hamlet of Bedford Village.
Two men probably fatally injured, a girl severely injured, and nine men under arrest is the result of an Italian shooting affray in the Eastern District of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

The worsted yarn trade is interested just now in the enterprise of Alpin J. Cameron Co., yarn manufacturers, of New-York, Philadelphia, and Chicago, who in a few weeks will start in this city a factory which will employ from 250 to 300 hands, which means food and shelter for from 1,000 to 1,200 men, women, and children.

ALBANY, April 21. -- It would not be surprising if before the end of the session several amendments were proposed to the new Constitution, the most important of which will consist of measures to repeal and nullify that section which requires bills to lie on the desks of members for three legislative days before final action can be taken upon them.

On a charge of disorderly conduct preferred by William E.D. Stokes, James McAlister, a trim-looking young Englishman, was sentenced yesterday to the Island for three months by Police Justice Ryan, in the Yorkville Police Court.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 21. -- The Faculty of the Princeton Theological Seminary has announced the schedule of the annual final examinations. These examinations begin April 25 and close May 2, and are the only examinations held during the year. The eighty-third annual commencement of the seminary takes place immediately after the close of the examinations, from May 4 to May 7.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 21. -- The Rev. Father Phelan, pastor of a Roman Catholic church in North St. Louis, and editor of The Western Watchman, printed in his paper yesterday a criticism on Protestants that has set the city in an uproar. The following are extracts from the article:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 21. -- The last college session of the year began April 10. During the vacation the main building was improved by a new system of electric fire alarms.

Some members of the Grand Army of the Republic said yesterday that the various posts in this city would probably follow the example of one of the Brooklyn posts, and pass resolutions condemning Commissioner Waring for his utterances made concerning the Grand Army of the Republic to Dr. Gibbs the other day.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 21. -- The Spring term opened last Tuesday. Nearly all of the students have returned, and there are a few new ones. The vacation was prolonged a week on account of Easter. This term will be very short, but the usual amount of work will be done.

Bookkeeper Samuel E. Aymar of the National Shoe and Leather Bank, who was arrested in Brooklyn Saturday night for having robbed the bank of $20,000, was arraigned before Justice Voorhis, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday morning, and remanded back to Police Headquarters for examination this afternoon.

A cloudless day, a warm sun, and a gentle breeze made yesterday a welcome day for all who love to watch the growth of Spring in the shrubs, trees, and flowers. Although the temperature was only moderate, being 62 in the shade throughout the afternoon, the day was excellently adapted to the use of those pedestrians who had discarded their Winter wraps and overcoats, while retaining their Winter flannels.

The Right Rev. Thomas F. Gallor, D.D., Assistant Bishop of Tennessee, yesterday afternoon delivered the introductory lecture of a series of discourses which will be given under the auspices of the Church Club of New-York during April and May, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. These lectures will be on "Christian Unity and the Bishop's Declaration."

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- The steamer Southwark, which arrived here to-day from Liverpool, brought Capt. Edwin Moore and the crew of six men of the Nova Scotian schooner Glenola, from which they were taken on Friday last in latitude 40 degrees 3 minutes, longitude 64 degrees. When abandoned the Glenola was in a waterlogged and sinking condition.

The work toward the organization of a co-operative employment bureau which was begun by a number of well-known New- York women some weeks ago has prospered beyond their most sanguine hopes. Decision in regard to the possibility of starting the bureau was to be given about the first of May, but it has been decided already that the work will be taken up.

Perhaps it was because that at the Saturday conference with commanders of precincts Superintendent Byrnes was unusually insistent in regard to the enforcement of the excise law and specific in detailing what would happen if a district were found "wet" yesterday that, while perseverance by thirsty folk with foot gear that did not excite suspicion was rewarded, New-York went more "dry" than might be expected with a police force short about 400 of its quota.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 21. -- The principal topic of discussion among the friends of the university of late has been the controversy aroused by the passage of resolutions by the local Baptist ministers deploring any effort to make the university less Baptist in its teaching force and governing officers, and especially demanding "that the influence of every class room shall be unequivocally Christian in the sense which Baptists put upon that term."

-- William P. Kirk, the famous yacht builder of Toms River, N.J., has launched the schooner yacht Helene, which he constructed for Commodore Francis Shunk Brown of the Philadelphia Yacht Club. The schooner was designed by A. Cary Smith. She is luxuriously fitted up as a cruising vessel, and will be used upon yachting trips along the North Atlantic coast.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 22. -- The special correspondent of The United Press returned here to-day from an extended trip into the interior.

The attempt to get a jury to try Police Inspector William W. McLaughlin, who is accused of bribe-taking, was resumed yesterday before Justice Barrett in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. A fresh panel of 150 talesmen had been summoned for yesterday, and the time of the court was taken up for nearly an hour listening to the legal excuses of the talesmen.

The contest over the Governorship of Tennessee is likely to be decided this week. The Legislature has resumed its session, and the Committee of Twelve, appointed under the contest law, is ready to report.

" The Saloons and the Law" was the subject discussed at a largely attended meeting of the City Vigilance League of the Eighth Assembly District, held last night in the Spring Street Presbyterian Church, Spring Street, near Varick, at which the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst and Joseph Murray, President of the Board of Excise, were the principal speakers.
The County Medical Society, at its meeting at the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street last night, considered the question of advertisements in medical journals.

The public-school teachers of this city have issued the following reply to the criticisms of the sub-committee of the Committee of Seventy on their protest against Assembly Bill 2,230 reorganizing the school system here:

Our columns have borne witness that certain members and officers of the Grand Army of the Republic have been very much excited by Col. Waring's disrespectful characterization of that organization as "a lot of pension bummers." There can be little doubt that, if Col. Waring belonged to the G.A.R., he would be ignominiously expelled for holding such language about it.

The eleventh installment of games in the Brooklyn team bowling championship tournament was commenced at the Elephant Club alleys, Fulton Street, Brooklyn, last night. The Brooklyn Bicycle Club, representing the Wheelmen's League; the Park Bowling Club, representing Cody's tournament, and the Bergen Hill Bowling Club, representing the Niagara tournament, were the contesting teams.

TAMPA, Fla., April 22. -- The revenue cutter McLane, Capt. Willey commanding, which arrived in this port on the 10th inst., and was before reported to be leaking, has completed her temporary repairs and sailed for Mobile, Ala., where she will be docked and thoroughly repaired. Her officers say she is not the type of vessel for this station.

When Col. Orsello discovered that Major Sessa was the author of the posters reflecting upon Mrs. Orsello and Miss Orsello, it was clear that the way was open to a "difficulty." No high-spirited Southern gentleman could be expected to endure such reflections as these upon the ladies of his family, even though they were circulated only by word of mouth.

A special meeting of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club was held at the clubhouse, 7 East Thirty-second Street, last night, to frame resolutions upon the death of Mr. Robert Center. In the absence of Commodore E.C. Benedict, Vice Commodore Henry C. Rouse and Rear Commodore Van Renssalaer Cruger, Gerard Beekman presided.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 22. -- George H. Riecker, aged twenty-six years, editor of The Bristol Herald, attempted suicide this morning at the home of his brother-in-law, John Whitmore, in New-Britain, by cutting his throat. The attempt was the result of despondency resulting from drinking. His wife, to whom he was married last June, was present with his sister when Riecker cut his throat.

At the election held on Nov. 6 last, 64,830 legal voters of the City of Brooklyn voted in favor of consolidation with the City of New-York, and 61,926 voted against the proposition. The majority for consolidation was 2,904.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 22. -- Mrs. Sarah J. Parmenter and Charles Kelloway were married by the Rev. D.B.F. Randolph, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church, yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Parmenter is the widow of Isaac J. Parmenter. She is fifty-nine years old, and wealthy. The bridegroom is twenty-four years old. For over four years he has been Mrs. Parmenter's coachman.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen at the weekly meeting yesterday had a lively fight for patronage. It resulted in two Republican Aldermen being ignored in the distribution of the fourteen Trolley Speed Inspectorships, and one Democratic Alderman getting one of the places for one of his Democratic constituents.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The reports from St. Petersburg and London, that Russia is dissatisfied with the terms of peace between China and Japan, and intends forcibly interfering to prevent Japan's occupying any of China's soil, are directly in conflict with information received here from highest sources.

It is not surprising that members of the Legislature chafe under the restrictions of the Constitution which stand in the way of their rushing measures through at the end of the session, but if they imagine they can get rid of them by new amendments, undoing the deliberate action of last year's convention, they will probably be disappointed.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 22. -- The cornerstone of the Woman's Building of the Cotton States and International Exposition was laid this afternoon with imposing ceremonies. A great crowd, composed largely of ladies, assembled on the exposition grounds about the stone foundations of the proposed building.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The Board of Engineers selected by President Cleveland in accordance with an act of Congress to visit Nicaragua and investigate the feasibility and expense of constructing the inter-oceanic ship canal will probably organize to-morrow, Major William Ludlow, the army member, having arrived in New-York to-day from London, where he has been military attache to the American Embassy.

The family of Frederick Baker, after suffering for several months in silence the obloquy thrown on the dead man's name and reputation through the robbery of the National Shoe and Leather Bank by Samuel C. Seely, have come forward to claim a hearing for their side of the story.

The closest whist contest this year for the possession of the American Whist League trophy was played last Saturday night in this city between the Continental Club, whose headquarters are at 111 and 113 West Thirty-eighth Street, and the famous Hamilton Whist Club of Philadelphia. The result was a tie, something which has never happened before in the contests for this much-coveted trophy.

-- For an Exhibition Room. -- A concert in behalf of the New-York Room to be established in the Woman's Building of the Cotton States and International Exposition at Atlanta, Ga., will be given at the Hotel Waldorf to-morrow evening. The soloists will be Francis Fischer Powers, Ben Davies, Miss Marguerite Hall, Mrs. Ella M. Powell, Victor Harris, and P.J. Wurts.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.
CHICAGO, April 22. -- The advance in wheat which began last week, the price going higher at the rate of 7 cents in seven days, continued in a sensational manner to-day in the Board of Trade.
LONDON, April 22. -- The Central News correspondent in Tokio says that Ito Miyoji has been appointed special envoy to China for the purpose of exchanging the ratifications.

Members of the Janes Methodist Episcopal Church, Reid Avenue and Monroe Street, Brooklyn, are congratulating themselves over the fact that the tact displayed by their pastor, the Rev. J.A. Adams, has prevented a threatened serious breach in the congregation.

The publication of the defalcation of Aymar, the bookkeeper of the Shoe and Leather Bank, interested no person in New-York more profoundly than Mrs. Baker, widow of Frederick Baker, who was charged by Seely with being his confederate in his self-confessed crime.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., April 22. -- Mrs. Delia T.S. Parnell's condition was somewhat improved this morning. She had a changeable day yesterday, being considerably better in the morning, but grew worse during the afternoon, and was delirious at times during the night.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The President does not indorse all that Secretary Morton said on the money question in his interview published yesterday, and he has deemed it proper to make public the following statement:

BERLIN, April 22. -- The Cologne Gazette says that the Chinese loan of 30,000,000 marks, at 6 per cent., which has been concluded with a syndicate of German bankers, is merely a provincial transaction which was arranged some time ago by the Viceroy of Nankin.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Secretary Gresham has directed Mr. Eustis, the United States Ambassador to France, to ascertain from the French Government the reasons for the arrest and detention of Waller, ex-United States Consul at Tamatave, who arrived in confinement at Marseilles on a French warship Saturday.

-- The New-Jersey Athletic Club has a novelty added to its programme for Decoration Day, and many are wondering just what a barrel race is like. That there will be fun during the race is an assured fact, and as this is the first time such an event has been given in America, the winner, whoever he may be, will be known as the champion.

I do not know what our people are to do, as up to the present time our county has failed to dispose of its share of the State warrant provided by the two-hundred-thousand-dollar appropriation. The season came and passed for planting small grain, and no seed was sent nor money enough to purchase any with.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Some of the regular dry dock builders of the country are finding fault with the Navy Department for the liberal way in which it has sought bids for the completion of the timber dry dock in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The contract for this work with James Gillies, a Brooklyn man, was annulled on account of the failure of the contractor to perform his work within the time specified.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., April 22. -- The horsewhipping case between Mrs. Alfred Chelberg and Mrs. Thomas W. Lister of this place came to a trial before Police Justice Bisgood this morning, and Mrs. Lister was found guilty and fined $30. The courtroom was packed.

The friends of public education will be greatly gratified to learn that the lectures which will be delivered at the Museum of Natural History, in Central Park, by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, are to be repeated in all the cities and villages of the State that have a population of 5,000 and upward.

-- John H. Shults has of late years purchased more mares with fast records for breeding purposes than any other stock-farm proprietor in the country. Several of these have dropped foals during this month at Shultshurst, near Portchester. Gold Leaf, whose pacing record of 2:11 1/4 was a championship performance from 1889 till Robert J. appeared in 1892, has a bay filly by Stranger.

The arrival of Mr. John L. Waller at Marseilles, on Sunday, aboard the steamer Djemnah, from Madagascar, is the best thing, probably, that could happen for throwing light on what until now has been a rather obscure affair.

The authorities at Ellis Island have in custody Diss Champe, a Belgian, thirty four years old, who hoarded the Berlin al Southampton and came to this city. He was in the steerage, and while on the voyage relieved many of his fellow-passengers of such small articles as he took a fancy to and could pick up unobserved. He put them in his old carpet bag and stowed it away under his straw mattress.

The Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton, in a sermon which he preached last Sunday morning in All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, in Madison Avenue, expressed his disbelief in the physical resurrection of Christ's body. He acknowledged that this view was opposed not only to the teaching and doctrines of the Protestant Episcopal Church, but also to the direct testimony of his disciples.

There was but scant progress made by the police yesterday in the search for the person who so brutally murdered Alice Welsh, the woman who was found bleeding to death in the hallway of the tenement house at 143 Thompson Street early on Sunday morning.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- The Greenhut-Morris faction received another setback in the United States court this morning when Judge Showalter refused to grant an order referring the case of Receiver McNulta and others against Nelson Morris, Joseph B. Greenhut, Samuel Wolner, and P.J. Hennessey as far as Nelson Morris is concerned, to a Master in Chancery for immediate hearing.
The Reinhard Assembly committee met yesterday morning in Part II, of the Superior Court to continue its investigation into the "sweating" system in this city.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 22. -- Prisoner Perry, held here for extradition, was taken to the Court House this morning, in order that he might be more fully identified by the Matteawan authorities. Supreme Court Commissioner John T. Nugent heard the evidence, by direction of Judge Lippincott.

GREENPORT, L.I., April 22. -- Miss Belle Brooks, twenty years old, daughter of Capt. Sidney Brooks of East Marion, was seriously injured through the collision of two carriages in front of the Episcopal Church, in this village, last evening.

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers, with J.N. Kalley Son, have sold 267 and 269 Washington Street, extending through to 103 and 105 Warren Street, at $200,000. The property measures 52 feet on Washington Street and 40 feet on Warren. The same brokers have sold, at $100,000, the corner of Clinton and De Kalb Avenues, Brooklyn, 130 by 200.
BOSTON, Mass., April 22. -- Frank Howard Poor, formerly of Haverhill and now an inmate of the Masachusetts Reformatory at Concord, it is said has recently been left an estate worth $15,000,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 22. -- An Indiana Republican, who was in Washington during President Harrison's Administration, and who takes a hand in national politics, said to-day that Benjamin Harrison will be the compromise candidate of the currency factions next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 22. -- The preliminary examination of Theodore Durrant, charged with the murder of Minnie Williams, was begun to-day. The testimony of the witnesses did not differ materially from that given at the inquest.

For some time past in almost every weekly issue of the American and the English trade journals of the iron and steel industry reference has been made to sales of American iron or steel products in England or in neutral markets which were formerly supplied by English manufacturers.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 22. -- The Park Club of Plainfield won the State whist championship by one trick Saturday night from the Montclair Club in probably the most exciting contest of the season. The clubs met to play off the tie in the tournament of the New-Jersey Whist Association. Rodgers and Howell of Plainfield lost to Kloman and Mulford of Montclair by five tricks.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 22. -- The oyster war is now practically at a standstill, pending developments. Judge Barnard to-day, after listening to the arguments of William J. Young and Counselor Stoddard, issued an injunction restraining all parties from dredging or taking oysters from the grounds now claimed by the Matinecock Oyster Company.

Frederic W. Hinrichs, Registrar of Arrears in Brooklyn, addressed the members of the Young Men's Democratic Club, at 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, last night, on the Municipal Ownership of Street Railroads." Among other things, he said:
Dr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Carpenter do not seem to have had a particularly cheerful time of it since they were married, two years ago last November.

ALBANY, April 22. -- By the personal influence and power of Speaker Fish, the Troy Police bill passed the House this evening after one of the most exciting sessions of the year. The bill came up on the order of third reading.

SING SING, N.Y., April 22. -- The execution of Dr. Robert W. Buchanan in Sing Sing Prison has been set for Wednesday, April 24, at 11 o'clock in the morning. He will then expiate his crime of killing his second wife, although he still maintains his innocence.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- It was expected that the Supreme Court would to-day hand down a decision on the motion for a rehearing in the income tax cases, and the chamber was filled with persons interested in the question, but nothing was said on the subject.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22. -- It is a peliar fact that the recent rise in oil, which is now generally attributed to mere speculation, began in the Orient. Japanese papers just received throw a curious light on the matter. They seem to show that the whole movement was simply a speculative deal engineered by the Standard managers after they had made a compact with the Russian Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A general order was issued at the War Department today announcing the retirement of Major Gen. Alexander D. McCook, in which the services of the retiring officer are thus spoken of:

A new enterprise, in which many prominent women are interested, is to be started in New-York May 1, to be called "The Woman's Headquarters," and it will be a great convenience to New-York women during the Summer months, or at any time during their temporary absence from the city, and to other women living out of town, but frequently visiting the city.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Old Guard of New-York are the honored and distinguished guests of the City of Albany and the Burgesses Corps to-day. Elaborate preparations for the entertainment of the visitors had been made and the arrival of the Old Guard was heralded by the firing of a salute.

" The Importance of Being Earnest," a three-act comic play, presented for the first time in this country at the Empire Theatre last evening, is not, properly speaking, a farce, but rather a burlesque comedy in the manner of W.S. Gilbert's "Engaged" and "Tom Cobb" and "Fogarty's Fairy," or Sydney Rosenfeld's "A Possible Case."
ALBANY, April 22. -- As soon as the Assembly met to-night, Assemblyman Finn (Dem., New-York) tried to get before the House the following resolution:

An exhibition of the work of an artistic, serious wood engraver, a man well equipped by nature, by experience, and by education to produce on wood with the two or three simple instruments of his craft excellent pictures, recalls the changes that have been made in recent years toward the simplifying of the process work, the cheapening of the cost of reproduction, and the opening up of a new field of illustration by half-tone.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Waring's utterance that the Grand Army was an aggregation of "pension bummers" has caused many Republicans and Grand Army men to ask Mayor Strong to remove the Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The contention of the Kansas City Live Stock Exchange that the talk of a "proposed investigation" by the Secretary of Agriculture has caused "the market for live stock to be unwarrantably agitated," has occasioned surprise here, where stories of a scarcity of cattle have been put forward in explanation of the heavy increase in the price of beef.

BOSTON, April 22. -- Capt. Paine of the British steamer Barnstable, which arrived here to-day from Port Antonio, Jamaica, says the published report that his steamer had been fired upon by a British gunboat on the outward passage to Jamaica was erroneous.

LONDON, April 22. -- The House of Commons, which stood adjourned over the Easter recess, resumed its sittings to-day. Speaker Gully took the chair, but immediately afterward the Usher of the Black Rod appeared in the House and summoned him to appear before the House of Lords.

A number of actors and managers from this city will make a pilgrimage to-day to the Edwin retreat Home, at Holmesburg, near Philadelphia, where the celebration of the anniversary of the birth of Shakespeare will be held, in accordance with the terms of the will of the great actor who endowed the home and gave it his name.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., April 22. -- Capt. Smith of the Revenue Cutter Commodore Perry, which arrived here yesterday from New-York said to-day in relation to affairs in Peru:

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- This morning at St John's Episcopal Church, one of the historic churches of Washington, the Hon. George Nathaniel Curzon, M.P., of England and Miss Mary Victoria Leiter, eldest daughter of the Chicago millionaire, L.Z. Leiter, were married, in the presence of the British Ambassador and Mrs. Cleveland and a large and distinguished company, including guests from England and from leading cities in this country.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The United States Patent Office was for the third time visited by fire this afternoon. The location of the fire was in the southwest corner of the basement, in the photographic blueprint room, close to a crowded public thoroughfare.
LONDON, April 23. -- The Times correspondent in Hong Kong says:
