ST. PETERSBURG, May 29.--A law was promulgated to-day permitting commercial dealings ill Russia to be conducted upon a gold basis.

ALBANY, May 29. -- Gov. Morton to-day signed many bills which are of general interest and importance to the entire State. Several of the more important measures passed at the session were to-day made laws. The list signed includes:
George W. Smalley, who for many years was the foreign correspondent of The New York Tribune in London, arrived here yesterday on the Teutonic.
The murder of Underbutler Ferdinand Harris at Matthew C.D. Borden's house, 25 West Fifty-sixth Street, Monday, was still a mystery last evening to the police.

FLUSHING, L.I., May 29. -- The Quakers, to the number of more than 1,000, took possession of the village this morning and retained it until the close of their services this afternoon. New-York City contributed a large contingent.
Mayor Strong has declined to accept in behalf of the city Senator T.D. Sullivan's Truck bill, over which there was so exhaustive a hearing at the City Hall last Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 29. -- H.H. Holmes, or Herman Mudgett, who pleaded guilty yesterday to the charge of conspiracy to defraud the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Association, is now in prison awaiting sentence.

Acting Chief Conlin was present at the 9 o'clock roll call in the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters yesterday morning, and lectured the members of the force upon what was expected of them under the existing circumstances.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Agricultural Department has made an important improvement in its system of securing crop returns, and while it is not expected that the new system will be in full operation before twelve months, still, it is expected, its benefits will be felt much earlier, as the new scheme will be put into operation as fast as agents can be secured to do the work.
PANAMA, via Galveston, May 29. -- No official details concerning the loss of the Colima have been received here.

The Grand Jury yesterday indicted the proprietors of a number of department stores in this city for selling inferior silverware for "sterling," and in the afternoon they were arraigned before Recorder Goff, who paroled them.

In a very thoughtful article in the Economiste Francais M. Paul Leroy Beaulieu discusses the relations of the Orient, as developed by the recent war, with the powers of Europe. The sober economist and student does not share the panic which has fallen upon some of his contemporaries as to either the military or commercial invasion of the West by the East.

RED BANK, N.J., May 29. -- The Red Bank Wheelmen have made big preparations for the road races to be held here on Decoration Day. Although in its infancy, the club is a strong organization, and bids fair to become one of the leading cycling organizations in the State. It was formed on April 12, with nine members. The membership at present is ninety, and there are new applications at every meeting.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 29. -- Fine racing is assured for the first National Circuit meet at the Crescent Oval to-morrow afternoon. Some of the fastest riders in the country are here, and the entry list contains several hundred entries. The track is reported to-night to be in better condition than ever before.

The joint committee of Aldermen and Supervisors which is making the reapportionment of Assembly districts in Kings County has a very difficult task before it to accomplish the purpose which the Republicans desire.

The "revised" Constitution of this State seems to give rise to a tremendous brood of "questions." The village politicians and poolsellers who oppose the annexation of a part of Westchester County to this city, through their learned counsel, have raised the objection that the Senate apportionment is in the way.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Wheat started to go higher soon after the opening of the market to-day, reaching 82 4/8 cents, the top notch of the session, in quick time. Then came as quick a reaction of nearly 2 cents, the cereal selling to 80 1/2 cents, which was three-eights of a cent lower than the close yesterday.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May 29. -- The Legislature adjourned to-day, for the third time, owing to lack of a quorum.

The McLaughlin jury was complete yesterday for a short while. Hardly had the twelfth seat been filled, however, when the prosecution began to use its peremptory challenges, and the list was again depleted.

CLEVELAND, May 29. -- The opening session of the third of the national conferences for good municipal government, it being also the first annual conference of the National Municipal League, was held in the Chamber of Commerce rooms this afternoon. It was, perhaps, the most notable gathering of men ever held in this country for the sale purpose of devising ways and means for the better government of municipal corporations.

Water Purveyor Edward P. North yesterday submitted to Commissioner of Public Works Brookfield his estimates of expenditures for asphalt pavements in city streets for the current year. The amount of new asphalt pavement proposed is 195,025 square yards, and the estimated cost is $780,100.

Ex-Secretary William C. Whitney arrived here yesterday from Europe on the steamship Teutonic. With him were his daughter, Miss Whitney; his son, H.P. Whitney; Miss Davidge, Miss H.T. Barney, and Alexander Gunn.

The splendid new American Line steamship St. Louis -- the third largest ship afloat and the biggest and finest vessel ever built in the United States -- reached New-York on her maiden voyage yesterday. The St. Louis was built by the Cramps, in Philadelphia, and was launched Nov. 12, 1894. She started last week on her trial trip down the Delaware from the yard of the builders.

CREEDMOOR, May 29. -- A detachment of the Twelfth Regiment, National Guard State of New-York, under command of Capt. Washington Content, and composed of Companies E.G. and H. practiced here to-day, with the following results:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 29. -- Fair weather favored the tennis players here to-day, at the New-England championship tournament, which was continued on the courts of the New-Haven Lawn Club, before a large gathering of spectators. The feature of the day's play was the meeting between Howland and Larned in the semi-final round of the singles this afternoon.

A novel scheme for rapid transit in this city, which differs in almost every important particular from the many plans which have been at various times submitted to the Rapid-Transit Commissioners, has been prepared by Alfred H. Thorp.

If Charles E. Courtney and his Cornell crew thought they were going to get out of this country quietly yesterday, they must have been wonderfully surprised when they beheld the crowd on the American Line pier before the steamship Paris sailed. It looked as though the Cornell campus was transferred from Ithaca to West Street, in the vicinity of Barclay and Fulton Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The contention of the naval ordnance officers that the armor belt on the new battle ships should be raised one foot higher than designed is warmly combated by Chief Constructor Hichborn in a memorandum which has been filed with Secretary Herbert.
JERSEY CITY, May 29. -- It is expected that the parade to-morrow will surpass anything of the kind ever before held here. Six thousand men and boys will probably be in line.

Garden and Forest makes the admirable and timely suggestion that Central Park should contain some appropriate memorial of A.J. Downing. Indeed, the suggestion would have been timely on the score of its merits any time these thirty-five years, since the Park was begun; but it is especially timely now on the score of its present practicability.

A big piece of good news for tennis lovers was given out yesterday afternoon. It appears that after the Essex County Country Club's scheme of inviting two English cracks to take part in their tournament was spoiled by overlooking the fact that the propposed tournament was to be held on the opening day of the English championships, the idea was taken up and vigorously pushed by the Neighborhood Club of West Newton.

RIVAS, Nicaragua, May 29. -- The Commission of Engineers appointed by President Cleveland to examine the plans and route of the Nicaragua Canal has arrived here safely. All members of the party are well.

Gold to the amount of $105,000 was transferred yesterday from the Assay Office to the Sub-Treasury, to be credited to the Treasury reserve on account of foreign purchases of the new Government bonds. This was the remainder of last Saturday's receipt from the Campania. It had been withheld from credit until it could be accurately weighed. With yesterday's credit the shipment amounted to $955,000.

Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, the recently elected President of the Grand Trunk Railroad, is coming to this country to make a thorough examination of that property. He will be here in about two weeks, and it is expected that he will remain in Canada for a year or more. The entire Grand Trunk system will probably be reorganized.

PANAMA, via Galveston, May 29. -- The Pacific Steam Navigation Company's steamer Santiago, which arrived this morning, brought information that Gov. Drouet of Guayaquil has been deprived of his office.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, May 29. -- A lamp exploded in the hold of the steamer H.E. Runnels this morning while she was thirty miles off this port. The crew were unable to keep the fire under control. At 7 A.M. the steamer New-Orleans answered her signals of distress, and soon had two streams playing on the fire.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- After a meeting, which practically lasted all day to-day, the members of the Western Freight Pool, who convened yesterday, finally entered into an agreement which is virtually the same as the old one. It is for one year and can only be broken by giving 60 days notice from March 31, 1896.

BANGOR, Me., May 29. -- Congressman Boutelle has sent a telegram to Chicago protesting against the dedication of the Confederate monument. The telegram, which is addressed to Mayor Swift, is as follows

In the Ohio Convention Gov. McKinley was badly beaten. He was not a candidate for any office, but he is the head of a machine, and the traditions of Ohio require the head of a machine to control everything within reach, to give battle to every challenger. So when Mr. McKinley's candidate for Governor was beaten, the Governor was beaten.

The Jewish Feast of Shabuoth, or Pentecost, a feast at which the ancient Israelites presented their first offerings of fruit for the year, was celebrated yesterday in the Hebrew synagogues in this city according to the Jewish ritual.

Twelve innings were necessary yesterday to decide the game between the New-York and the Philadelphia Clubs at the Polo Grounds. The visitors won by a run. Five thousand spectators saw the contest, which was most interesting.

It will seem to most non-sporting readers that Lord Rosebery has "made a record'' in winning two successive Derbys. This is not quite the case. Lord Falmouth won two, but they were seven years apart. The precedent for the Prime Minister was set by the Duke of Portland, who won the Derby of 1888 with Ayrshire and of 1889 with Donovan.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29. -- There is every prospect to-night that the great Irvington-Millburn road race will be favored tomorrow with fair weather, and the largest crowd that ever saw the cyclists' Derby lost and won. This city is full of strangers awaiting the big event, and at the many little road-houses, which fringe the course, there are hundreds of wheelmen, who, in one way or another, will take part in the race.

An amusing experiment to prevent a donkey from braying led to a rather savage conflict on the Place Moncey this morning. The owner of the quadruped, a chair-stuffer, was in the habit of beginning his rounds at an early hour, and usually took a brief morning meal in a tavern, outside which his donkey remained to bray.

ALBANY, May 29. -- The interest in the Park Bank defalcation increases, but the facts regarding the whole affair are guarded with the utmost secrecy. Nearly every avenue of news has been stopped, and bankers, as well as business men, are unable to learn anything further than what has been published.
The principal events in the memorial celebration to-day will be a parade in the morning, ceremonies at Grant's tomb in the afternoon, and exercises at Carnegie Music Hall in the evening.

NEW-HAVEN, May 29. -- The "Insane" was the subject of the morning session of the conference on Charities and Corrections, Dr. J.W. Babcock, Columbia, S.C., read a paper on "Provision for the Insane," and F.B. Sanborn of Concord, Mass., a paper on "Increase of Insanity." Mr. Sanborn said:

The latest action of Mr. Cope Whitehouse, says The Egyptian Gazette, is the formation of a company called "The Cope Whitehouse Drainage Canal and Reservoir Company,'' which is stated to be incorporated under the laws of Illinois, U.S.A., 1895. The capital is $5,000,000, divided into 50,000 shares of $100 each.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- The decision of the United States Supreme Court on the income tax is very gratifying to Pennsylvania people, and there is a feeling of satisfaction, often expressed, that a Pennsylvania jurist -- Justice Shiras -- should have been the one upon whose views depended the final result.

SARATOGA, N.J., May 29. -- Post McKean will, to-morrow morning, proceed to Mount McGregor, and decorate the General U.S. Grant cottage. In the afternoon Post Wheeler will conduct Memorial Day services at Greenridge Cemetery. Several prominent clergymen connected with the Baptist May anniversaries, in annual gathering here, will take part in the exercises.

MADISON. Wis. May 29.--It is understood here that Senator Vilas would like to be Secretary of State, and a report is in circulation that he proposes to make an effort to secure the place. The Senator left home today for Westpoint N. Y. He is a member of the Board of Visitors to the Military Academy.

It was on a 30th of May, after the close of the civil war, that President Andrew Johnson approved a joint resolution of Congress expressing "the gratitude of the Nation to the officers, soldiers, and seamen of the United States, by whose valor and endurance, on land and on sea, the rebellion has been crushed."

LONDON, May 29. -- Lord Rosebery's lucky star was dominant again to-day, when his colt Sir Visto, trained by Matt Dawson and ridden by "Sammy" Loates, won the Epsom Derby, the greatest of all English races. It was the second successive win of the Blue Ribbon event for the Premier, his colt Ladas having won last year.

I was walking up the village, when I saw, to my dismay, that the entire gable end of one of the cottages had fallen bodily out, of course exposing the rooms, both up stairs and down. My first thought was naturally for the safety of the family, a young agricultural laborer and his wife. But there were my friends just returning from an errand, and this was the conversation which followed:

English visitors, when admiring Delacroix's famous "Shipwreck of Don Juan," in the Louvre, frequently have been much exercised in mind at the apparent absence of that hero. M. Henri Rochefort, fresh from his sojourn among us -- if not from the study of Byron -- has been explaining the mystery to the Parisians.

The outgoing Grand Jury and District Attorney Fellows combined their forces yesterday to call attention to the urgent necessity for improved methods to facilitate the disposal of the criminal business of the county. The Grand Jury handed up two presentments.

HAVANA, May 18. -- The return of Martinez Campos has strengthened public opinion in favor of the mother country. Here everybody has unlimited confidence in him, not only as a military man, but as one better able than any other to re-establist order, liberty, and morality.

Judge Gildersleeve of the Superior Court yesterday fined the New-York and Manhattan Elevated Railroad Companies $14,750, declared them in contempt of court, and, incidentally, rapped the Supreme Court rather sharply for interfering with and undoing the work of the Superior Court.

The most patriotic gathering that has ever filled Assembly Hall, in the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, cheered, waved flags, and sang national airs yesterday afternoon with a fervency that left nothing to be desired.

Much interest has been shown of late over the probable outcome of the long cycle race on June 8 between F.M. Dampman of Philadelphia and A.W. Fuller of Brooklyn. They will start in advance of the first relay riders in The New-York Times one-hundred-and-fifty-mile tri-State team race, and following The Times route, endeavor to reach the grounds of the Riverton (N.J.) Athletic Association as soon as possible.
The Coe Brass Company, at Torrington, Conn., has raised the wages of 600 men 10 per cent.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 29. -- Between 2 and 4 o'clock this morning fires were discovered in eight different places in the business portion of this city. The fires gained no headway in either ease, being fortunately discovered by night watchmen and police.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- The South sent its most distinguished living representatives of the "lost cause" to Chicago to-day to witness the unveiling to-morrow of the monument in Oakwood Cemetery to the Confederate dead -- those who died while prisoners of war at Camp Douglas in this city.

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, May 29. -- The Republican State Convention has adjourned, after a two days' session. It accomplished three things: It nominated a State ticket; it wrecked the McKinley-Sherman machine, and it established "Fire Alarm" Foraker's authority as dictator of the Republican Party in Ohio.

Dr. Chauncey M. Depew gathered around his dinner table last night, at 43 West Fifty-fourth Street, about all the visible supply of Republican Presidential candidates and nearly all of the leaders of the warring Republican factions in this State and city.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29. -- The Pacific Mail Steamer Colima was wrecked between Manzanillo and Acapulco off the west coast of Mexico last Monday. She was bound for Panama, and left here with 191 persons on board -- 39 cabin passengers, 37 steerage, 43 Chinese, 11 officers, and a crew of 61 men.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--Escorted by military bands playing dirges and marching troops of different branches of the national military service, and With the Stars and Stripes covering the casket, the body of the late Secretary Gresham was borne along the historic Pennsylvania Avenue to-day on its way to Its last resting place, in Chicago.

On the bronze pence, halfpence, and farthings now being coined, the Queen's titles, including that of Empress of India, are set forth in the same manner as on the new gold and silver coins. A formal proclamation, notifying the Queen's orders to this effect, and dated May, 11, appears in last night's London Gazette.

Many persons are expected to take advantage of the holiday to-day to visit the Ward property, extending from One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street to One Hundred and Seventy-second Street and King's Bridge Road, to the Hudson River, which is to be sold in lots by Mr. D. Phoenix Ingraham on June 11. Book maps will be distributed on the premises to-day.

George F. Elliott, President of the Brooklyn Law Enforcement Society, sent a letter to Police Commissioner Welles yesterday calling his attention to a prize fight at the Seaside Athletic Club at Coney Island Monday night. He also notified Mr. Welles that, there is, to be another fight at the island to-night, and says:

WEST POINT, May 30. -- Decoration Day was not kept as a holiday at the Military Academy. Drills and recitations were held as usual. The regular soldiers had field-day sports on the flats north of seacoast battery.

Dr. Chauncey M. Depew's dinner to a distinguished company of Republicans on Wednesday night was generally talked about by the politicians yesterday, and they all agreed that it had not cleared up the political situation in any way.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 30. -- An excellent programme was provided at the New-Jersey Athletic Club carnival of sports this afternoon. President James E. Sullivan and the Athletic Committee, composed of Chairman James D. Boyd, H.A.E. Jachne, E.W. Hjertberg, S.S. Schuyler, and E.E. Barnes, made up a list of attractions which proved interesting to all the spectators.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30. -- The Pacific Mail Steamship Company gave out the following dispatches, received to-night from Manzanillo:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 30. -- The New-England Championship Tennis Tournament was continued here this afternoon on the courts of the New-Haven Lawn Club. A tennis reception and lawn party was held on the ground during the afternoon, and many of New-Haven's society people turned out to see the play and meet the players. The chief match of the day was in the semi-final round of the doubles between Howland and Larned and Budlong and Talmage.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The law officers of the Navy Department are still engaged on the record of the court-martial trial of Dr. Kershner, the naval Surgeon charged with violation of regulations and perjury. It is said that the court found Dr. Kershner guilty of part of the charges, and that he has been sentenced to dismissal, a result which the Secretary or the President is likely to modify.

CONEY ISLAND, May 30. -- The attractions presented at the Seaside Athletic Club to-night drew a fairly good crowd. The bout of the evening was that between "Kid" Lavigne of Saginaw, Mich., and "Jack" Everhardt of New-Orleans, who were on the card to fight twenty rounds at 134 pounds.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 30. -- The popularity of golf was shown to-day in an unmistakable manner on the links of the Morristown Golf Club. When it is considered that this club was organized barely a year ago, and that there were then practically no golf players worthy of the name in this vicinity, the score to-day was one of the strongest evidences that golf has come to America to stay.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., May 30. -- In nearly every village and hamlet of Long Island there was some sort of recognition of Memorial Day. In the larger towns there were parades of Grand Army posts and firemen, while in the smaller towns the school children turned out to honor the Nation's soldier dead.
The twelfth annual regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club was sailed from City Island to Ma-tuncock Point and return, yesterday. The race was the best in the history of the club.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 30. -The American Baptist Home Mission Society began a two-days' session at the Baptist Church this afternoon, to observe the sixty-third anniversary. Following the devotional services, Stephen Greene of Newton, Mass., Second Vice President, presided, and delivered the annual address, in which he gave an interesting statistical account of the growth of the society.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 30. -- The annual meet of the Asbury Park Wheelmen was held this afternoon on the grounds of the Asbury Park Athletic Association, on the banks of Deal Lake. There were over 3,000 spectators present. The races were all Class A events. The number of entries was unusually large, and three of the seven races were run in heats.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- The funeral train bearing the body of Waitei Q. Gresham from the National capital reached here shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon, and, with civic and military honors, the body was entombed in a vault at Oakwood Cemetery, there to remain until a final burial place is chosen.
The great feature of the celebration of Memorial Day in this city was a monster parade of war veterans and public-school children.

RED BANK, N.J., May 30. -- That bicycling racing here is popular was proved to-day when not less than 2,000 people turned out to see the road races held under the auspices of the Red Bank Wheelmen. The roads were in fairly good shape, having been scraped for the races. Good order was maintained along the line, and there was not a single accident.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Decoration Day in all the great national cemeteries of the capital, and in which so many thousands of the Union dead are buried, was commemorated by appropriate exercises. For the first time in several years the weather was clear and beautiful. The absence of the President and his Cabinet deprived the day of some of its expected features.

It is reported that the incipient epidemic of cholera at Mecca has been stamped out. If this be true, Europe will breathe more freely, but the insanitary condition of Mecca, especially during the pilgrimage season, makes it almost impossible to check a cholera epidemic there after the disease has once appeared.

Grandfather's Hat has been in high luck this week. The insatiable Foraker transferred Major William McKinley to the list of unavailables on Tuesday, and yesterday Gov. Morton had a -- well, Mr. Blaine had one in '76, and it put him back eight years.

LONDON, May 30. -- A dispatch to The Westminster Gazette from Tokio says that the Emperor, after a stay of many months at Hiroshima, made a triumphal return to the capital to-day. The streets and houses were gaily decorated, and the populace were intensely enthusiastic.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and their son were here to-day looking over their new villa. Some sub-contractors have been placed under a penalty to have their work accomplished at a given date, which, it is expected, will hasten matters.

So surely as John Chinaman drifts into India, "on the make," so surely does the empire have trouble with him. Accordingly the Empire has had trouble lately with Ah Sin. He lived in the Burra Bazaar; he grew fat, and seemed prosperous; but the sources of his plumpness and prosperity were not visible to the naked eye of the Inspector of Police.

A little fellow who had no trainer and no kindly hands to groom him started in a field of 126 cyclists in the great Irvington-Millburn handicap yesterday, and, displaying the generalship of a veteran of many contests, won a race pretty to look upon. His name is Frederick W. Richt. He is a member of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club, and a Young Men's Christian Association young man.

LAWRENCE, Mass., May 30. -- The Washington Mills have adopted a new system in the payment of their employes in the form of premiums. The weavers are to get a premium of 5 and 10 per cent., according to their ability and faithfulness. Hereafter their pay will be made up each four weeks, and the premiums will be added according to the amount earned at the regular price list.

One of the features of Memorial Day in Brooklyn was the decorating of the graves of the trolley victims. The committee in charge, who represented the anti-trust organization, had made preparations, and whenever they located a grave of a trolley victim it was decorated. Among these were the following:

At the Lenox Tennis Club's courts yesterday the finals went on in spite of the heat. The women's singles were not played, and the women's doubles were played in two parts, morning and afternoon. The games will be resumed to-day, as the finals in the women's singles, the mixed doubles, and some consolation matches are yet to be played. The summaries follow:
YONKERS, N.Y., May 30. -- Memorial Day was observed in a patriotic and impressive manner here to-day. Kitching and Fremont Posts, G.A.R., visited the cemeteries and decorated the graves of comrades.

Not since the Weather Bureau was established, twenty-five years ago, has the temperature in New-York City been so high on Memorial Day as it was yesterday, when it was just above 84 at 11 o'clock in the morning.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- Decoration Day at Belmont Park was marked by a good-sized attendance, a fine track, and some fast racing. The unfinished 2:25 pace and three well-filled contests were on the programme for decision. Mascot Jr., fulfilled expectations by winning the eighth and ninth heats of yesterday's postponed event, and placed first money to his credit.
New blood is being put into the Detective Bureau, which was established in the New-York Stock Exchange by ex-Chief Byrnes for the protection of Wall Street.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 30. -- "Kut-kut, kut-kut, kut-kut-da-da-kut."

TRENTON, N.J., May 30. -- The James Page Library Association of Philadelphia to-day decorated the grave of Gen. George B. McClellan. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Hanlon and Senator W.H. Daly of Hoboken were the orators. Robert Sterling, Marshal of the parade, was overcome by the heat and fell from his horse.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30. -- Before adjourning over Memorial Day to next week Tuesday the lower branch of the Connecticut General Assembly decided to postpone taking a vote on the proposed amendment to the State Constitution providing for plurality elections in the matter of State officers until Wednesday, June 5.

Brooklyn had to furnish the light-harness sport for the metropolitan district yesterday. The Parkway Driving Club prepared a promising card for the holiday, and the result was quite up to the most sanguine expectation. About 1,200 spectators enjoyed the sport with the sulkies, varied with one event to road carts, and eleven heats to decide the three events.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 30. -- The finest monument in the State was this afternoon unveiled by the Grand Army of this city. It was erected in honor of the members of the Second Kansas Regiment who fell in the battle of the Big Blue, just below Kansas City, Oct. 22, 1864, where Gen. Price and his 30,000 rebels were held in check all day by a handful of raw Kansas militia.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Col. Edwin C. Mason, commanding the Third Infantry Regiment of United States Regulars, with headquarters at Fort Snelling, Minn., will be placed on the retired list of the army to-morrow on reaching the age limit.
Gov. Morton fainted yesterday mornig while he was reviewing the Memorial Day parade, as it passed the Worth Monument, in Madison Square.

The public reigned in Central Park yesterday. The invading army of men, women, and children numbered more than 100,000, and to control them a force of 5,000 Park Policemen would have been inadequate, but, all circumstances well considered, the behavior of the immense throng was as decorous as could be expected.

That there is new blood in the Atlantic Yacht Club was very evident by the way the opening day of the season was celebrated yesterday. The flag was hoisted and saluted by a fleet of more than fifty yachts, and then twenty-nine took part in a race down to the Southwest Spit and back.
The Memorial Day celebration in Brooklyn yesterday was more extensive than in former years, and the parade was all that could be desired.

The open regatta of the Audubon Yacht Club was held yesterday over a triangular course on the Hudson River off One Hundred and Fiftyfifth Street. A light breeze was blowing from the south. The summary:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 30. -- The first race meet of the Crescent Wheelmen of Plainfield this season was held on their new third of a mile oval track this afternoon, in the presence of fully 8,000 persons.

BOSTON, May 30. -- Ex-Congressman John F. Andrew died of apoplexy, at his home on Hereford Street, early this morning, aged forty-four years. He was about the city yesterday, and, as far as his friends knew, as well as ever. He retired early last evening, and when a servant went to call him at 8 o'clock this morning, it being past his usual time for rising, he was found dead in bed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 30. -- Alonzo C. Mather of Chicago was in this city yesterday in connection with the power bridge which is to be constructed across the Niagara River here, and which is to be used to furnish electric power by means of immense two-hundred-foot wheels to be driven by the river current.

Under fair skies and over a good course, the twenty-ninth regatta of the Harlem River Association was held on the historic old river yesterday. It did not seem as if a particle of the enthusiasm of former years was lacking, and the events in nearly every instance were creditably contested. The bridges and the river banks were filled with lookers-on all day long.

-- Every Issue of The Monthly Illustrator finds it improved in many ways. The June number of the admirable publication opens with an article on Henry Mosler. There are several illustrations from his pictures and of pen sketches, Mr. Trumble writing the letter press. The faithful studies of Breton life with which Mr. Mosler is so familiar cannot fail to be of great interest to the many readers of this magazine.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., May 30. -Charles White was killed at a picnic in Elm Park to-night, and Orlando Robinson, a young colored man, is locked in the West Brighton Police Station, awaiting the result of the Coroner's inquest, on a charge of murder. The police say they are certain that he is responsible for White's death.
ORANGE, N.J., May 30. -- The Orange Athletic Club baseball players beat the nine of the University of Pennsylvania at the Orange Oval this afternoon in the presence of some 3,000 persons.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 30. --Brown made up for her previous defeats at the hands of Yale by a score of 12 to 3, this afternoon. Thirty-five hundred people saw an exciting game, in which Thompson, Yale's Freshman pitcher, was knocked out of the box, and Trudeau hit hard. Brown played a magnificent fielding game. Yale's 3 runs came hard.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- Fully 3,000 persons witnessed the trotting events of the Mutual Driving Club at the Waverley Fair Grounds this afternoon. The track was very fast. Interest centered in the match race between George C. Smith's black gelding Bert Sheldon and Edward Radel's bay gelding Conway. Bert Sheldon won in three straight heats.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 30. -- The first session of the conference of the delegates from the affiliated societies to the National Municipal League Convention was held in the Chamber of Commerce rooms this morning. President J.C. Carter of New-York was in the chair. A number of delegates arrived during the night, and there were about 125 representatives of the various civic and good government societies in their seats when the conference was called to order.
BERLIN, May 30. -- Two Russian military officers, in civilian attire, were arrested in Mogilno, West Prussia, to-day, upon suspicion of espionage.

It seems that for the first time in a whole generation the American peopie are entitled to congratulate themselves upon the production in an American shipyard of an ocean steamer of the very first class. This should mean that we are approaching the condition, which we have not attained since the war, but which we enjoyed before the war, of being able to compete on equal terms for the carrying trade of the world.

Senator Blackburn is very indignant because the Administration is "interfering" in his re-election to the Senate from Kentucky. The interference consists of the speeches of the Secretary of the Treasury in behalf of sound money. He does not complain of Mr. Carlisle personally, and concedes his right as an old Kentuckian and a Democrat to take part in the discussion.

BOSTON, May 30. -- In Western Massachusetts and Connecticut high temperatures are reported, the mercury reaching 87 at Springfield -- the highest of the year -- and ranging from 78 to 85 at Worcester, Hartford, New-Haven, and Norwich.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., May 30. -- Miss Mary Eveline Benedict, daughter of Read Benedict, was married yesterday evening to J. Garnet Basinger of Georgia, at Ravenhurst, the home of Mr. Benedict, at this place. The Rev. J.G. Johnston, pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church of Port Richmond, officiated.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- The twenty-first annual regatta of the Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association was rowed to-day on the Passaic River course and proved a big success. Five thousand persons lined the banks and occupied seats in the clubhouses. To sundown the interest did not flag.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 30. -- The largest crowd that ever visited the Waltham Bicycle Park was present this afternoon at the opening tournament under the auspices of the Associated Cycle Clubs of Boston and vicinity, the attendance being estimated at between 12,000 and 15,000. Two new world's records were made during the afternoon. In the one-mile open, Class B, an attempt was made to lower the world's competition record, now held by Bald.

It is not apparent, so far, that this is going to be an especially sickly Summer. The Job's comforters who are fond of predicting cholera and deadly fevers have been silent. Yet it cannot be denied that the Summer heat always brings out more or less malaria, particularly in districts where the earth is torn up or drainage is imperfect.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- The monument erected in Oakwood Cemetery to the Confederates who died in Chicago prisons during the war was dedicated to-day. The funds for the monument were chiefly subscribed by Union soldiers, and in to-day's exercises Grand Army men and Confederate veterans participated.

An enjoyable event on Staten Island yesterday was the formal opening of the Richmond County Country Club. The club's grounds delightfully situated in the interior of the island never presented a more picturesque appearance than yesterday. A gay throng of insular fashionables drove to the clubhouse in stylish traps, ranging in style from a runabout to a four-in-hand.

Cissy Fitzgerald seemed to be the star at the Brooklyn Jockey Club races yesterday. Though there were seven races to be run, with a fair lot of horses in each, the blonde young woman who has as a stock in trade a wink and a kick attracted more attention than all the horses put together. That was, perhaps, because there was a typical holiday crowd at the track, in addition to the horsemen and bettors.

Gov. William McKinley of Ohio visited Brooklyn and was the guest of the Montauk Club, on Eighth Avenue, that city, last evening. It was plainly evident that the little Major had left his Presidential boom at home.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 30. -- The opening of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bay this afternoon was a very successful affair, and taxed the hospitality of the well-known organization to its utmost. Lunch was served at 1 o'clock, and the Hungarian Band of eight pieces furnished music. The club flag was raised and saluted.

Mayor Strong created a little ripple of excitement during the memorial exercises of the Grand Army of the Republic in Carnegie Hall last evening by declaring that the Confederate soldiers shed as good blood as the Federals, and did so in what, to them, was as noble a cause as that of the North's -- the defense of their firesides.

Two games of baseball were played between the Brooklyn and Cleveland clubs yesterday, at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, and each club won a game by a one-sided score. The morning game was played in the presence of about 6,000 spectators and resulted in the Brooklyn's fairly trouncing the Clevelands, defeating them by the score of 10 to 1.

The Chicago ball club made its first appearance at the Polo Grounds yesterday, playing two games in the championship series. The local team defeated the visitors in a well-played game of eleven innings in the morning, and were beaten after a hard fight in the afternoon, in which the visitors hat a bit the best of it.

ALBANY, May 30. -- For alleged violations of the State civil-service law, rules, and regulations, and possibly the Constitution. Public Works Commissioner George W. Aldridge is to be investigated by the Civil Service Commission. The investigation has been ordered by Gov. Morton, and will begin next Tuesday morning.

Three days have elapsed since Ferdinand Harris, the colored under butler in the employ of Matthew C.D. Borden, was murdered in the basement hallway of his employer's house, 25 West Fifty-sixth Street, and the police, despite industrious work, have not been able to clear up the mystery.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- The big road race will probably be awarded to Homer Fairmon, who finished third in to-day's event. J.M. Dworak crossed the line first at just half a minute past 11 o'clock, and E.W. Fry of Milwaukee was about 200 yards behind him. Close to Fry came Fairmon, and George Emerson was not far off. Neither Dworak nor Fry rode the full course, and they were disqualified.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 30. -- James C. Os~ I borne, a bicyclist living-at 377 Vgest One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, NewYork City, this evening, vhile coasting down -shburton Avenue. lost control of his wheel, and was thrown with such force as to render him unconscious. HIs right eye was torn out, his nose broken, and his face badly lacerated.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 30. -- Charles Ricker, thirty-eight years old, of 282 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, New-York, was found unconscious at the foot of the hill on Broadway, near St. Paul's Church, early this morning. His wrecked bicycle was on the other side of the road.

BOSTON, May 30. -- In the Canadian Senate, at Ottawa, Monday night, Senator Poirier made a long speech concerning the proposed monument to commemorate the seige and capture of Louisburg, and denounced the contemplated action of the Massachusetts Historical Society as offensive and an impertinence to a large number of loyal Canadians.

Mayor Strong has very properly refused to accept for the city a bill permitting the Police Commissioners to raise the salary of doormen from $1,000 to $1,200. Commissioner Parker said that he was not prepared to approve the bill, because the doormen, who, it was claimed, have to expend $100 a year, would still ask to be reimbursed for this expenditure.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- One of the most important tributes to Secretary Gresham among the messages received from all the foreign legations at Washington was that from Minister Romero, who, in acknowledging the official announcement of the death of the Secretary of State, wrote as follows:

Recent advances in the wheat market, reaching 20 cents a bushel in four months, have recalled to operators the market of 1891, which ran a course somewhat similar to that of the present one, and made that year one of the best on record for all concerned in the trade in that staple.

Fire Marshal James Mitchel arraigned Mark Schoenholz, thirty-five years old, of 142 Lewis Street, before Police Justice Ryan, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday. He believes Schoenholz to be one of the worst firebugs in the country.

The governing boards of racing in this section of the country, the Stewards of The Jockey Club, and of the National Steeplechase Association, both held meetings at the office of August Belmont, 23 Nassau Street, yesterday. Mr. Belmont presided at both meetings.

It is made clear in Mr. Winsor's book (an interesting successor to his recent "From Cartier to Frontenac") that one thing which contributed largely to the French failure in civilization in North America was their great desire to find something rather than to build up something. They were like the Spanish in this respect.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Hugh Gough, who succeeded W.E. Goschen as First Secretary of the British Embassy some few months ago, to-day received a cable message announcing the death of his father, near Dublin, Ireland.

ST. LOUIS, May 31. -- The mercury at 2 P.M. marked 95, showing this to be the hottest day of the year. Four cases of sunstroke, one of them resulting fatally, were reported. John Foster, a negro, aged twenty-eight, was overcome by the heat and fell under the wheels of his wagon and was crushed to death.

The Aldermanic Committee on Parks and Bridges met in the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday to consider Aldermen Gullfoyle and Clark's resolutions requesting Park Commissioner Squier to have inserted in his budget money to construct a return bicycle path along the Ocean Boulevard, and also a bicycle path on the Eastern Parkway to Howard Avenue.

Some years ago the public mind in England was strongly stirred by the account of diseases in the matchmaking trade, and beneficial results have followed the revelation. "What the eye doesn't see, the heart doesn't rue," and it is a far cry from the scene of the everyday life of most of us to the manufactories in the North of England.

William and Robert A. Osborn, dealing in wine as John Osborn, Son Co. at 45 Beaver Street, made an assignment yesterday to Ferdinand Hirsch and Norman T. Melliss, Preferences were given to Robert and Mary C. Osborn of Nyack, minor children of John Q. Osborn, deceased, for $9,608 each, for money loaned to the business. Robert A. Osborn has also made an individual assignment to the same assignees.

The opponents of the unlimited coinage of silver in the South make a strong case against its advocates when they show that any such measure would inevitably result in silver monometallism, and that it would tend indefinitely to postpone the only bimetallism possible -- that secured by general international agreement.

Sunday will take Place at Clermont the grand historical cavalcade in celebration of the eighth centenary of the First Crusade. Great preparations have been made for the event, and in order that the costumes and accessories in the procession may be historically correct, M. Ambroise Tardieu, the official historiographer of Auvergne, has been engaged as a sort of stage manager.

ALBANY, May 31. -- Gov. Morton reached this city this morning, feeling none the worse for his visit to New-York and the uncomfortable incident on the reviewing stand during the Memorial Day parade. He had not suffered at all from the fainting fit, which was brought on by the heat. He went at once to the Executive Mansion and began work.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31. -- This morning, in view of the discouraging dispatches that had been received concerning the loss of life by the Colima disaster, there was little hope held out for the safety of the missing passengers. Those whose spirits were made buoyant yesterday upon the receipt of Mr. Brewer's dispatch, reluctantly concluded that they would hear nothing further from relatives and friends.
BALTIMORE, May 31. -- The Manufacturers' Record reports the last week to have produced a greater number of industrial enterprises in the South than in any one week for years.

Real estate interests will be largely represented before the Aldermen this afternoon at 2 o'clock, when the hearing takes place in the matter of granting a franchise for the railway along the King's Bridge Road. The West End Association will have a committee in attendance to urge that the franchise be given to the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- No news has been received at the State Department of the serious Bedouin outbreak in Arabia and the possibilities thus opened of active European intervention in that portion of the Turkish dominions. This is not surprising, inasmuch as the United States has no Consular representatives within several hundred miles of the locality of the outrage.

There is news from France -- very important news to those whom it may concern, and rather unexpected to all, though rumors have indeed been flying about. Rouge has gone out. There is to be no more florid complexions, and pallor is to be the rage. Of course, as a corollary, golden hair is to disappear -- which is rather a relief, on the whole -- and the taste will be for brunettes.

COLIMA, Mexico, May 31. -- Six more survivors of the steamer Colima have reached here. They are John Thornton and J.F. Childbred of Seattle, Lewis Peters and Vindor, and the Seamen Gonzales and Fred Johnson. They got ashore on a raft, from which three seamen were lost.

HONOLULU, Hawaiian Islands, April 25. -- Disinterested people are protesting against the continuance here of the present state of anarchy -- for the acts of the alleged "republic" are not to be classed with those of a well-organized, stable, and righteous Government.

Another important Republican dinner was given last night. Gen. Horace Porter was the host and Gov. McKinley of Ohio the guest of honor. It was not a harmony dinner. It will attract more attention from the politicians than did Dr. Depew's famous harmony dinner, because they will attach more political importance to it.

Fighting Bob's valor had finally oozed out of the palms of his hands. He had felt it going. After it had gone he felt better. He didn't mind the word "coward," and, that rascal Beverley not appearing, he wouldn't fight with his dear friend Jack Absolute, no, not for the world.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 31. -- The morning session of the American Home Mission Society was devoted to addresses by the Rev. George E. Horr, Jr., of Massachusetts on "Formative Influences," the Rev. E.R. Pope of Minnesota on "Study in Comparative Religion," and the Rev. A.H. Lyons of Idaho on "What Becomes of the Money.''

Albert H. Dollard, the brother-in-law of Daniel F. Lewis, President of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company, was indicted by the Kings County Grand Jury yesterday on the charge of having signed a declaration of a dividend when there was no surplus money from which to pay it.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- This week's bulletin of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen contains the following:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 31. -- Two women, one young and well dressed, the other elderly and plainly attired in black, called at the Court House here Wednesday. The young woman asked Constable Joseph Locke to look after her companion. She said she would return in a few minutes, as she was only going to see Judge Hudspeth to ask him to commit the old lady to the insane asylum.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 31. -- Two deeds, conveying 5,500 acres at Montauk to Austin Corbin and Charles M. Pratt, were recorded in the Suffolk County Clerk's office here today. The deeds are from Frank Sherman Benson, Mary Benson, and Jane Ann Benson, who for some years have been in possession of the Peninsular, subject to the rights of the Montauk tribe of Indians.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Citations were served this afternoon on Joseph B. Greenhut, Peter J. Hennessy, and Nelson blorrts to appear before Master in Chancery Booth to-morrow morning and submit to an examination in regard to rhisky Trust affairs. Ex-Presldnt Grenhut returned to this city from New-York this morning.

NEWARK, N.J., May 31. -- James J. Brown, a salesman of New-York, and Miss Mamie McTague, stepdaughter of Market Policeman James Kehoe, and a niece of James F. Connelly, the new Consul to Osaka, Japan, were to have been married next Tuesday.
Michael Dady, the Brooklyn politician and intimate friend of John Y. McKane, at present in Sing Sing Prison, acted as a man of mystery yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., May 31. -- The annual State Division race meet will be held here to-morrow, and if the weather remains favorable it will be the most auspicious that the Mercer County Wheelmen have ever managed. Many entries have been made, and the cyclists of Mercer County are on the tiptoe of expectancy regarding the sport promised.

BOSTON, May 31. -- Miss Sara Cone Bryant of Melrose of the senior class of the College of Boston has been honored with an appointment to a Fellowship by the Collegiate Alumnae Association of America. This fellowship will give the appointee a year's study in the great German universities, commencing next Fall.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The State Department has some interesting information from Hawaii which sustains the Administration in its denial of annexation to Hawaii. It has not been officially announced, and it is not generally known, that ex-Minister Thurston maintained that annexation should not disturb existing social and political relations in Hawaii, so far as the suffrage of certain inhabitants of the Pacific Republic was concerned.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Promotions in the army, following the retirement to-day of Col. E.C. Mason, are as follows: Lieut. Col. J.H. Page, Twenty-second Infantry, stationed in Montana, becomes a Colonel. He was early in the war a private in an Illinois regiment of artillery, and later was commissioned a Second Lieutenant in the regular army.

English and American sympathizers with the unhappy Armenian subjects of Turkey are securing signatures to a petition, addressed to Mr. Gladstone, and asking him to secure, through pressure exerted by England upon the Porte, permission for the erection of Armenia into a semi-independent province, paying tribute to the Sultan, but administered by a Christian Governor, selected by the great powers and guaranteed from the interference of Turkey.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- There has been considerable speculation to-day about the Secretary of State, without anything authoritative. The President and the members of his Cabinet, except Secretaries Carlisle and Morton, reached Washington at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

WILKESBARRE, May 31. -- A fire of a most serious nature started in north shaft of the Wyoming Colliery of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company, at Port Bowkley, to-day, and at 11 o'clock to-night was burning fiercely. Fully 500 feet of the gangway were ablaze. A terrific explosion was caused by the fire at 6 o'clock this evening and Patrick J. Duddy, a mine boss, and Morgan Bevan, a timber man, were badly burned.

Very few among the hundreds of thousands of persons who daily pass the New-York end of the Brooklyn Bridge probably appreciate the wonderful piece of engineering work that is being carried out before their eyes. The men in charge have undertaken the task of tearing out the entire New-York terminal and building a new one, with four tracks, instead of with two, the tracks to be about ten feet above their present level.
ALBANY, May 31. -- Gov. Morton this morning named the two members of the Capitol Commission authorized by the new law. They are Archimedes Russell of Syracuse and Gen. Ira M. Hedges of Haverstraw.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31. -- A local paper prints the following: "A few days ago Reuben N. Lloyd, leading counsel for the contesting heirs of the Fair estate, left for New-York. His departure was announced to but few, and they understood that he had gone to consult with Herman Oelrichs upon the coming contest of the will presented by Attorney Goodfellow and his fellow-executors.

Mayors of cities in this State should make a careful study of the provisions of Article XII. of the Constitution, in so far as these relate to bills for special city laws. Some of them are still giving hearings on these bills, and the Mayor of Buffalo has announced a hearing upon one to be held next week.

WOODSBURG, L.I., May 31. -- The opening regatta of the Keystone Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon over the regular club course in Hempstead bay. There was over 200 guests present to watch the yachts skim over the course. The three classes were sent off within a few minutes of each other, and all the boats got away pretty well bunched.

The members of the Woman's Board of New-York City, which was organized to prepare an exhibit for the New-York City room in the Woman's Building at the Cotton States and International Exposition that opens in Atlanta, Ga., next September, met yesterday at the home of Mrs. Joseph Bradley Read, 40 East Fifty-first Street. Mrs. Read is Chairman of the board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- A cablegram from Havana was received here to-day reporting the loss of the bulk oil-carrying bark Carrie E. Long, from Philadelphia for Havana, by being struck by lightning near the Bahama Islands, and the death of the Captain, mate, and two sailors.

The Manhattan Railway Company of this city is preparing to substitute electric motive power on its several lines, in place of steam, and the General Electric Company has submitted plans and estimates for the change.

ALBANY, May 31. -- It is possible that the last has not been heard of the bill creating the Manhattan State Hospital and putting the insane poor of New-York City under the State Care act. When Mayor Strong sent it back to the Governor without either his approval or disapproval, Gov. Morton, acting under legal advice, let it be understood that he regarded it as dead.
There was a brisk verbal battle yesterday at the public hearing before Mayor Strong on the bill granting the New-York and Brooklyn Tunnel Company the right to construct a tunnel under the East River.

An important conference of authors and literary men generally was held in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, yesterday afternoon to discuss the irregularities of English orthography, which, as stated in the call for the meeting, "are an inconvenience to all who read and write our language, a burden upon education, and an abstacle to the spread of Anglo-Saxon thought.

From the moment the American traveling into Mexico gets in exchange for one American dollar two Mexican dollars, until, when, on returning, he gives two Mexican dollars to get one American dollar back, his life is full of surprises. The order of horse racing here is a fair sample of how entirely and completely the civilization of the United States is reversed in Mexico.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 31. -- On the road leading to Lyons, just outside of Clyde, about midnight last night, Lon Lake was shot by James Kerby. The two men have been good friends for years. They went to Clyde to observe Memorial Day and became intoxicated. They started home with Kerby's horse about 11 o'clock.

ALPENA, Mich., May 31. -- The steamers Norman and Jack were in collision in a dense fog near Middle Island, Lake Huron, last night. The Norman sank, carrying down with her Mrs. Reynolds, the steward's wife; Watchman Nelsbernstine, and a deckhand named Toney. The Jack is badly damaged.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 31. -- The National Municipal League to-day called on Congress, by resolution, to revise the naturalization laws, so that undesirable foreigners cannot become citizens.

Those persons who felt uncomfortably hot yesterday were surprised to learn that the temperature reached only 93 at its highest point, and that the humidity was greatest at 8 o'clock in the morning, when it was 56 per cent., afterward falling to 50 per cent. in the afternoon.

We published yesterday morning a report as to the investigation of certain evasions and violations of the civil service law by the Commissioner of Public Works, Mr. George W. Aldridge. The report was specific as to fifty-six places filled by that officer since the 16th of April by appointees not taken from the eligible list resulting from legal examinations.
Police Commissioner Grant sat in judgment at the trials of accused policemen at headquarters yesterday. There were fifty-seven cases on the calendar.

ALBANY, May 31. -- Commissioner Dowling of the Bureau of Statistics of Labor has been making an investigation in regard to the condition of business in 1895, as compared with the depression of 1893 and 1894. This investigation covers the erection of new buildings and the alterations and improvements of old ones, as taken from the records of New-York City and Buffalo.

HAVANA, May 21. -- The news of the death of Jose Marti, the so-called President of the Cuban Republic, has caused a real sensation. Marti was the soul of the revolution. He had initiated and prepared it, in spite of the little aid which he could find in Cuba every time he had attempted to create a revolutionary movement.

Charles A. Baldwin Co., broker at 40 Wall Street, filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday a bill of sale of the fixtures and other portable property in their offices for $800, to J.B. Coutant, an employe of the firm.

President Freedman did not have the slightest idea that his club was going to defeat the Chicagos yesterday, owing to the odds and ends of a team that he was obliged to put in against Anson's colts. Mr. Hutchinson, however, proved an easy mark, and they defeated the Chicagos readily.
Dr. Joaquin Saldanha Marinho, who was recently buried at Rio de Janeiro with public honors, was for many years one of the most prominent figures in public affairs in Brazil.

The numerous local option elections which have been held within the last six months have attracted much attention, largely because of the success of prohibition in a majority of the elections. When the cause of prohibition went down in August, 1887, many felt that this vexed question was settled for many years to come, but the movement seems to have been marching on in a very lively way.

ALBANY, May 31. -- "I have carefully perused Senator Sherman's Zanesville speech on silver," said Senator Hill to-day. "If an Ohio Democrat had made the speech, there would have been condemnation all along the Republican line.

Energetic efforts are making by the National Union for Practical Progress, an organization whose headquarters are in Boston, and which has fifty branches in thirty-nine cities, to secure from Americans an expression of opinion as to the most practical and effective way to put an end to Turkish misrule in Armenia.

Frederick, alias "Mike," Lochmeyer, aged twenty years, whose address is said to be 421 Fifth Street, was arrested yesterday by Central Office Detective Sergeant Titus and lodged in the Tombs prison, charged with being a "suspicious character.'' In reality Lochmeyer was arrested for supposed complicity in the murder of Walter F. Harris, second butler in the house of M.C.D. Borden, 25 West Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Army Ordnance Office is about to purchase another quantity of smokeless powder. It will be of domestic manufacture, and must meet the requirements which have lately been adopted in behalf of a satisfactory composition. These requirements are interesting as illustrating the advances made in the preparation of smokeless powder, which a few years ago was hardly subject to stipulation of any kind.

TRENTON, N.J., May 31. -- The Executive Committee of the New-Jersey League of Republican Clubs held a meeting at the Trenton House to-day. It was decided to hold a State convention for the election of officers and the transaction of business pertaining to the coming campaign June 26. The convention will be held in Taylor's Opera House, this city. A ratification meeting for the day after the Republican Gubernatorial nomination will also be arranged for.

The men of Brooklyn feel that they have suffered a great indignity through the passing of the Sunday shaving act, which compels them either to shave themselves on that day or to come to New-York to have it done.

Justice Barrett was overcome by the heat at 9:30 o'clock last night, and fell fainting from his chair, while presiding at the trial of Police Inspector William McLaughlin, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The army ordnance officers have been testing the hollow bullet, the invention of two foreigners, Kruka and Hebler. Prof. Hebler sent several of these bullets to the War Department, and they have been the subject of a test at Frankfort Arsenal, near Philadelphia.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., May 31. -- Miss Elsie Colman committed suicide last night. She was twenty-one years old and in possession of wealth inherited from her father, who was a successful banker. Since the death of her parents. Miss Colman has lived with her aunt, Mrs. S.J. Gifford.

The history of such epidemics of typhoid fever as the one now prevailing in Stamford, Conn., where there are now 337 cases, caused by the distribution of infected milk by one dealer, shows that even persons who have been enlightened by education and experience as to the danger of infection through the agency of an unguarded milk supply become victims of the ignorance or criminal carelessness of the dairy farmer or distributor.

The appeal from the decision of Judge Goff in the South Carolina registration case has been brought before the United States Circuit Court of Appeal at Richmond, Va., which has taken jurisdiction and will fix an early date for hearing argument. This court consists of Chief Justice Fuller of the Supreme Court presiding, Judge Hughes of the Eastern District of Virginia, and District Judge Simonton of South Carolina.

IVing as Corporal Gregory Brewster..

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 1. -- No village in Westchester County has grown so rapidly or so prettily in the last decade as this, the county seat of one of the most important counties in the State, adjoining, as it does, the great metropolis.

The Paris Figaro publishes an account of an interview which its London correspondent has had with Mr. H.M. Stanley on the subject of African colonization. Mr. Stanley is represented to have said in the course of the interview:

ORANGE, N.J., June 1. -- A large audience witnessed the dramatic and musical entertainment given in the village hall, South Orange, to-night for the benefit of the South Orange Free Library. The travesty on Shakespeare, "Place aux Dames," was presented by this cast: Lady Macbeth, Mrs. Walter I. McCoy; Ophelia, Miss Guilliard; Portia, Miss Benjamin; Juliet, Miss Walker.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1. -- The annual examinations and graduation exercises began at the Military Academy to-day.

The splendid performance of "The Rivals" in the Fifth Avenue Theatre last Friday afternoon was such an example of dramatic art as the playgoers of this generation have rarely seen. It was something more than an aggregation of actors whom the public accepts as "stars." It was an almost perfect rendering of a good play.

The present flourishing Hebrew Technical Institute is an evidence of the forethought and wisdom of some of the most prominent Israelites of New-York. When Hebrew immigration into this country began to increase at a rapid rate, the men at the helm of existing Hebrew philanthropic institutions realized that the younger element of the new-comers must be taught trades in order to be able to provide for themselves.

Sir: In regard to the prosecution of certain Dry Goods and Department stores in this city on the charge of violating the New-York State Sterling Law, there should be no misunderstanding on the part of the public.
It is believed that the arrest of Mark Schoenholz, the alleged incendiary, on Friday, will lead to the capture of all the chief incendiaries in this city.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- The second annual regatta of the Yale Corinthian Yacht Club took place to-day. The course was a triangular one from Morris Cove, the headquarters of the Yale Yacht Club, to Charles Island and return to the cove, a distance of twelve miles. The time made was slow because there was no breeze to speak of.

The law over which the barbers of Brooklyn and the citizens of that suburb who neither shave themselves nor go unshaven will to-day rage together is a very characteristic piece of Sabbatarian legislation. The author of the statute, whose portrait The Times presented yesterday, does not look like a Sabbatarian. On the contrary, he looks like a legislator.

PARIS, May 9. -- The political pulse was throbbing with apprehension this week. For a few hours it seemed as if Japan was growing too near, and satisfaction was enthusiastic when news came that compromise was rendered possible by the diplomatic modesty of the conqueror. The French felt the sympathetic foolishness of their generosity.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1. -- The Pacific Mail Company has furnished the following list of the lost and saved in the Colima wreck. It is as nearly complete as possible:

LENOX, June 1. -- The wedding of Miss Adele Sloane, eldest daughter of William Douglas Sloane, to James Abercrombie Burden, Jr., will take place Thursday, June 6, at Trinity Church, in Lenox. It will call together more society people than have ever been seen in Lenox at one time, although there have been many weddings of note here before.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Yesterday's debate in the French Senate on the question of the presence of France in a formal and official capacity at the ceremonies at Kiel upon the occasion of the opening of the Baltic-North Sea Canal has produced a bad impression in official circles here.

The most progressive country in Europe just now is undoubtedly Hungary. For centuries this proud and wealthy land has been the apple about whose acquisition nations have engaged in bitter war. The Romans, the Huns, the Tartars, and the Turks alternately have held sway in the Marianic States, by the beautiful blue Danube.
SARATOGA, June 1. -- After the address of its President, the seventy-first annual report of the Board of Managers of the American Baptist Publication Society was presented this morning.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Judge Baker this morning handed down his decision in the case of Attorney General Moloney against the Pullman Palace Car Company, in which the former claimed that the defendant company had violated its charter by conducting a number of enterprises other than those for which the State granted it a charter, and that the charter should, therefore, be forfeited.

The work of reindexing the records in the office of the County Clerk, Brooklyn, has been condemned by lawyers of that city, and County Clerk Saffen and Register Harmon have dismissed Michael Finnegan. He has taken the matter to court, on the ground that his removal is unwarranted and illegal.
This is the last month in which Mayor Strong can exercise the power of removal and appointment under the Power of Removal law.
SING SING, N.Y., June 1. -- The County of Westchester will very soon be effectually gridironed with trolley roads.
When the elevated trains come to be propelled by electricity, perhaps incandescent bulbs will replace the so-called lamps that now adumbrate the cars.

Yesterday afternoon, Gen. Thomas Wilson, United States Army; Col. Frederick D. Grant, Edward Hagaman Hall, Ira Bliss Stewart, and Stephen M. Wright, officially representing the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, visited Stoney Point, on the Hudson, as a preliminary step to some action by the society looking to the conversion of that historic site into a State or national park.

All the hotels in the world are said to be eclipsed in point of size and slendon by the fifteen-story structure which Col. John Jacob Astor has begun to build adjoining the Waldorf at Fifth Avenue and Thirty- fourth Street. It will also be one of the most novel hotels in the world in its arrangements.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1. -- The annual race meet of the State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, held here to-day, was easily the best from every standpoint ever promoted in Mercer County. The racing was very interesting, the music was good, there were present hundreds of pretty women in bright new Summer gowns, and The New-York Times team contest was exciting and interesting.

The cotton field in Ambrose Park, South Brooklyn, has been thriving for the past few days. A Southern State could not have produced a more glorious condition of heat than the earth and air and all intermediate objects have seemed to give forth the last few days. Nature has combined with art to give Black America a proper setting.

PARIS, June 1. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Rouanet made his promised Interpellation in regard to the alleged scandalg connected with the Southern France lailway. It was necessary for the dignity of Parliament and the country, he said, that the judicial comedy of the Panama Canal inquiry should not be repeated. .

Frank Mauer of 9 Mulberry Street, supposed to be a professional beggar, was overcome by the heat at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon at Barclay and Greenwich Streets, and taken to Hudson Street Hospital.

The new American Line steamship St. LOUIS, which is to sail next Wednesday on her maiden trip to Southampton, England, was inspected yesterday at her Fulton Street pier by a few favored persons, to whom invitations had been sent.

For many years there has been a bug-bear brought out from time to time to frighten timid investors in real estate. This has been in the form of a proposed legislative enactment giving to savings banks the right to invest their funds in securities other than those of the few varieties so long specifically designated on the statute book.

Thomas C. Platt has been busily engaged' for the last few days in telling his political friealds tl]at Gov. qrton will h,ve f:O. h nomination for President the votes o the New-York State de!ega_ti_on to the Republican National Convention next year.

The first house ever built in Missoula, Mon., has an interesting and peculiar history, thoroughly in keeping with the wild conditions of life prevalent in that part of the country when it was erected, thirty-five years ago. As seen in the picture, this house is really nothing more nor less than an ordinary log cabin, the typical domicile of the first settler in the uninhabited districts of the West.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 1. -- The Plainfield Choral Society held its annual meeting Monday evening in Vincent Chapel. The business session was preceded by a delightful programme, those taking part being Mr. Fitzhugh, Mrs. Asa Collier, Mrs. Collins, L.S. Bond, Miss Jessie M. Utter, and G.H. Simmonds.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Mayor Strong of New-York City has returned to 't. h e q0yernor, with his approval, four bills which Were in.,.. troduced by Senator RaiSes, designed to remodel the methods of procedure 'in making and oe'tiiyin election _retur. ua iu the aetroDolis.

Let us choose a typical house and go inside. Call it the Blue Boar, and say the hour is 9 P.M. The house has a long frontage toward the main road and extends round the corner into a by-street. It is entered by several doors, and each opens into a separate compartment of the barroom, which but for the dividing partitions would be an extensive saloon fully 70 feet in length.

The members of the Brooklyn Police Department paraded yesterday and presented a magnificent sight, in spite of the heat and rain. Mayor Schieren was loud in his praise of the excellent showing made by the force as it passed him in review in front of the City Hall.
The building occupied by Barnard College at 343 Madison Avenue was well filled with the students and their friends yesterday morning, when commencement exercises were held.

Though several trotters and pacers went some fast miles at Baltimore last month, the first part of the season for the harness racers has so far been somewhat of a disappointment. The weather was chiefly responsible for the interruptions in Maryland, but the elements are not to blame for what happened at Philadelphia.

BUFFALO, June 1. -- Ex-Gov. Flower was in Buffalo to-day for a few hours, leaving here to-night on the steamer Northwest for a trip up the lakes. When asked what he thought about the outlook of 1896, he replied:...

" A happy New Year to you," said the conductor of the "Limited," as Jack Ormsby was whisked away eastward from Chicago, after sixty hours of incessant railway riding from Fort Frayne. Happy New Year, indeed! It sounded like mockery.
The sixth annual meeting of the Seidl Society was held at the clubrooms on Friday afternoon, and the following officers ,were elected for the ensuing year:

ORANGE, N.J., June 1. -- The Princeton College baseball team easily beat the Orange Athletic players at the Orange Oval this afternoon. Westervelt, the Orange pitcher, was in poor form, and all the Orange men played a ragged game in the field, and made a total of thirteen errors. The hard catches of Cumng for Orange and Easton for Princeton were the features of the game.

Elaborate preparations are making in the charming little town of Chapel Hill, N.C., for a befitting celebration on the 5th of June by the University of North Carolina of the centennial of its existence. It is the oldest university in the South next to William and Mary, and its roll of alumni eminent in public life is equaled by few American colleges.

Almost exactly coincident with the death of John A. Morris, the "Lottery King," a new anti-lottery law went into effect in Florida. The apoplectic stroke followed the passage of the act by the Legislature, and the act was signed by the Governor the day after Morris expired.

Yachtsmen have all opened their clubhouses for the season, and now they will spend a week putting the finishing touches on their yachts and getting them ready for next year's big regattas. Nearly all the racing yachts are now in commission, but it takes a great deal of sailing to get them in trim for the hard contests that will begin with the regatta of the Atlantic Club, on Tuesday, June 11.
OTTAWA, Ontario, June 1. -- The official opening of the Sault Ste. Marie Canal will be celebrated June 13.

To be charmed by the beauty, gracefulness, intelligence, and sweet notes of birds is evidence, according to Mr. Chapman, of an inborn love of nature. Such love he rates as a priceless gift which should not be lost through lack of encouragement and instruction. "Properly developed," he says, "it should prove a never-failing source of pleasure and inspiration."

It was hoped General Headquarters of New-York would make an allowance of ammunition for revolver practice to officers, in order that they could properly perfect themselves in the use of this weapon, with which they have recently been supplied. General Headquarters has, however, refused to supply the needed ammunition, so revolver practice will hardly become a feature of instruction and competition at present.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., June 1. -- The Long Island Railroad Company this morning had Mayor H.S. Sanford and Public Works Commissioner H.W. Sharkey enjoined from interfering with its tracks on Flushing Street, this city.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 1. -- The six-mile marching contest between Company E, Third Regiment, Elizabeth, and Company F of Rahway to-night resulted in a victory for the Elizabeth company by the close margin of 0:56. Company E started with 37 men, and finished with 21. Owing to the heat 16 dropped out. The Rahway company started with 27 men, and only 3 dropped out.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 1. -- The end of a long and successful season at Lakewood is reached to-day. The Laurel House, following its long-established custom, closed its doors this morning. The number of guests who took their leave to-day far exceeded that of last year; in fact, the house has had one of the most prosperous years known since its establishment -- a season recalling the times when the Laurel was the only hotel.

Those who braved the heat yesterday at the Polo Grounds witnessed one of the worst exhibitions of baseball ever played on those grounds. Chris Von Der Ahe's contingent of players from St. Louis crossed bats with the New-Yorks, and the home team made a sorry exhibition. Breitenstein pitches for St. Louis, and he held the New-Yorks down to ten hits, which netted 2 runs.

After considerable delay and several changes, June 17 has finally been decided upon as the day for the formal opening of the Harlem Ship Canal. It was intended at first to have the opening Decoration Day, but Mayor Strong decided that June 6 would be better, and named that date. The North Side Board of Trade then took the matter in hand and settled on June 17.
ALBANY, June 1. -- The first pictures received for the contemplated gallery of notable railroad men for the State Railroad Commissioners' Department were those of Vanderbilt and Depew.

The public hearing yesterday before the full Board of Aldermen on the applications of the Third Avenue Railroad Company and the Metropolitan Traction Company, each asking for franchises for a cable road on St. Nicholas Avenue and through King's Bridge Road to the city line, was largely attended in the interest of both companies. Nearly every member of the Common Council was present.
